target_sentence: ⴰⵔ ⵙⵙⵎⵔⴰⵙⵏ ⵉⵎⵣⵣⴻⵣⵔⵓⵢⵏ ⵉⵖⴱⵓⵍⴰ ⵉⵎⵣⵡⵓⵔⴰ ⴷ ⴽⵔⴰ ⵏⵏⵉⴹⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵏⵥⴰⵜⵏ ⵃⵎⴰ ⴰⴷ ⵉⵍⴽⵎ ⵙ ⵢⴰⵜ ⵜⵎⴰⵎⴽⵜ ⵜⴰⵏⴱⵔⵉⴷⵜ ⴳ ⴽⵔⴰ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵏⵜⵍ, ⵉⵍⵎⵎⴰ ⵜⵉⵔⵔⴰ ⵏ ⵓⵎⵣⵔⵓⵢ ⵣⵓⵏⴷ ⵉⵎⵉⵎⵉⴹⴰⵏ ⵉⵣⵔⵉⵏ.

source_sentence: The research will have to be justified by linking its importance to already existing knowledge about the topic.
target_sentence: ⵉⵇⵇⴰⵏⴷ ⴰⴷ ⵉⵥⵍⵉ ⵓⵔⵣⵣⵓ ⵙ ⵓⵣⴷⴰⵢ ⵏ ⵡⴰⵜⵉⴳ ⵏⵏⵙ ⵙ ⵜⵓⵙⵙⵏⵉⵡⵉⵏ ⵏⵏⴰ ⵉⵍⵍⴰ ⵏⵉⵜ ⴳ ⵓⵙⵏⵜⵍ.

source_sentence: Generally, a hypothesis is used to make predictions that can be tested by observing the outcome of an experiment.
target_sentence: ⵙ ⵓⵎⴰⵜⴰ, ⴷⴰ ⵜⵜⵓⵙⵎⵔⴰⵙ ⵜⵓⵔⴷⴰ ⴰⴼⴰⴷ ⴰⴷ ⴳⵉⵏ ⵉⵙⵏⵎⴰⵍⵏ ⵏⵏⴰ ⵉⵣⵎⵔⵏ ⴰⴷ ⵜⵜⵓⵙⵜⴰⵍⵏ ⴳ ⴰⴷⴷⴰⵢ ⴷⴰ ⵜⵜⵓⵃⵟⵟⵓ ⵜⵢⴰⴼⵓⵜ ⵏ ⵜⵉⵔⵉⵎⵜ.

source_sentence: This careful language is used because researchers recognize that alternative hypotheses may also be consistent with the observations.
target_sentence: ⴰⵔ ⵜⵜⵓⵙⵎⵔⴰⵙ ⵜⵓⵜⵍⴰⵢⵜ ⴰⴷ ⵜⵓⵏⵖⵉⴷⵜ ⴰⵛⴽⵓ ⵙⵙⵏ ⵉⵎⵔⵣⴰ ⵎⴰⵙ ⴷ ⵣⵎⵔⵏ ⵜⵓⵔⴷⵉⵡⵉⵏ ⵖⵉⵏⵜ ⴰⴷ ⵣⴷⵉⵏⵜ ⴰⴽⴷ ⵜⴰⵏⵏⴰⵢⵉⵏ ⴰⵡⴷ.

source_sentence: As the accuracy of observation improves with time, the hypothesis may no longer provide an accurate prediction.
target_sentence: ⴰⴽⴷ ⵓⵖⵓⴷⵓ ⵏ ⵜⵏⵏⴰⵢⵜ ⵙ ⴷⴰⵜ ⵏ ⵜⵉⵣⵉ, ⵜⵣⵎⵔ ⴰⵔ ⵓⵔ ⵉⵇⵇⵉⵎ ⵓⵙⵏⵉⵎⴰⵍ ⴰⵎⵏⵖⵓⴷ ⵖⵓⵔ ⵜⵓⵔⴷⴰ.

source_sentence: "Artistic research has been defined by the School of Dance and Circus (Dans och Cirkushögskolan, DOCH), Stockholm in the following manner – ""Artistic research is to investigate and test with the purpose of gaining knowledge within and for our artistic disciplines."
target_sentence: ‘’ⵜⵜⵓⵏⵎⴰⵍⵏ ⵉⵔⵣⵣⵓⵜⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵥⵓⵕⵉ ⵙⴳ ⴷⴰⵔ ⵜⵉⵏⵎⵍ ⵏ ⵓⵔⴽⴰⵣ ⴷ ⵓⵙⵉⵔⴽ ⴳ ⵙⵜⵓⴽⵀⵓⵍⵎ ⵙ ⵜⵎⴰⵎⴽⵜ ⴰⴷ: ‘’ⴰⵔⵣⵣⵓ ⵏ ⵜⵥⵓⵕⵉ ⵉⴳⴰ ⵓⵣⵣⵔⴰⵢ ⴷ ⵓⵙⵜⴰⵍ ⵃⵎⴰ ⴰⴷ ⴰⵎⵣⵏ ⵜⵓⵙⵙⵏⴰ ⴰⵎⵎⴰⵙ ⵏ ⵜⵎⵥⵍⴰⵢⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵥⵓⵕⵉ ⴷ ⵅⴼ ⵓⵢⵏⵏⴰⵖ’’.

source_sentence: Artistic research aims to enhance knowledge and understanding with presentation of the arts.
target_sentence: ⴷⴰ ⴽⴽⴰⵜⵏⵜ ⵉⵔⵣⵣⵓⵜⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵥⵓⵕⵉ ⴰⴷ ⵙⴷⵓⵙⵏ ⵜⵓⵙⵙⵏⴰ ⴷ ⵓⵔⵎⵎⵓⵙ ⴰⴽⴷ ⵓⵙⴼⵙⵔ ⵏ ⵜⵥⵓⵕⵉ.

source_sentence: "According to artist Hakan Topal, in artistic research, ""perhaps more so than other disciplines, intuition is utilized as a method to identify a wide range of new and unexpected productive modalities""."
target_sentence: ⴷⴰⵔ ⵓⵏⴰⵥⵓⵕ ⵀⴰⵏ ⵜⵓⴱⴰⵍ, ⴳ ⵉⵔⵣⵣⵓⵜⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵥⵓⵕⵉ, ‘’ⵄⵏⵉⵖ ⵓⴳⴳⴰⵔ ⵏⵏⵙ ⴳ ⵜⵎⵥⵍⴰⵢⵉⵏ, ⴰⵔ ⵜⵜⵓⵙⵎⵔⴰⵙ ⵜⵡⵏⴳⵉⵎⵜ ⵣⵓⵏⴷ ⵢⴰⵜ ⵜⵖⴰⵔⵙⵜ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵡⵜⵜⵓ ⵏ ⴽⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵜⴱⵔⵉⴷⵉⵏ ⵜⵉⵎⴰⵢⵏⵓⵜⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵏⴼⵍⵓⵍ ⵏⵏⴰ ⵓⵔ ⵉⵜⵜⵓⴷⵎⵉⵏ’’.

source_sentence: Background research could include, for example, geographical or procedural research.
target_sentence: ⵖⵉⵏ ⴰⴷ ⵙⵎⵓⵏⵏ ⵉⵔⵣⵣⵓⵜⵏ ⵉⵅⴰⵜⴰⵔⵏ ⵙ ⵓⵎⴷⵢⴰ, ⵉⵔⵣⵣⵓⵜⵏ ⵉⵊⵖⵔⴰⴼⵉⵢⵏ ⵏⵖ ⴰⵎⴰⵅⴼⴰⵏ.

source_sentence: The literature review identifies flaws or holes in previous research which provides justification for the study.
target_sentence: ⴰⵔ ⵉⵙⵡⵓⵜⵜⵓ ⵓⵙⴼⵙⵔ ⵏ ⵜⵙⴽⵍⴰⵏⵉⵏ ⵓⴷⵎⴰⵡⵏ ⵏ ⵓⵇⵓⴹⴻⴹ ⵏⵖ ⵏ ⵜⴱⴱⴰⵢⴷⴰⵔⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵔⵣⵣⵓⵜⵏ ⵉⵣⵔⵉⵏ ⵏⵏⴰ ⵢⴰⴽⴽⴰⵜⵏ ⵜⵉⵎⵛⵓⵛⵛⴰⴹ ⵏ ⵜⵣⵔⴰⵡⵜ.

source_sentence: The research question may be parallel to the hypothesis.
target_sentence: ⵜⵣⵎⵔ ⴰⴷ ⵜⵎⵙⴰⵙⴰ ⵜⵎⵙⴰⵔⵜ ⵏ ⵓⵔⵣⵣⵓ ⴰⴽⴷ ⵜⵓⵔⴷⴰ.

source_sentence: The researcher(s) then analyzes and interprets the data via a variety of statistical methods, engaging in what is known as empirical research.
target_sentence: ⵉⵍⵎⵎⴰ ⴰⵔ ⵉⵙⴼⵙⴰⵢ ⵓⵎⵔⵣⵓ ⴷ ⴰⵔ ⵉⵙⵙⴼⵔⵓ ⵉⵙⴼⴽⴰ ⵙ ⴽⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵜⴱⵔⵉⴷⵉⵏ ⵉⵎⵢⴰⵏⴰⵡⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵙⵏⵎⵜⴰⵢⵉⵏ, ⴷ ⵓⴷⵔⵓ ⴳ ⵓⵢⵏⵏⴰ ⵎⵉ ⵜⵜⵉⵏⵉⵏ ⵉⵔⵣⵣⵓⵏⵜⵏ ⵉⵏⴰⵔⴰⵎⵏ.

source_sentence: "However, some researchers advocate for the reverse approach: starting with articulating findings and discussion of them, moving ""up"" to identification of a research problem that emerges in the findings and literature review."
target_sentence: ''ⵎⵇⵇⴰⵔ ⴷ ⵎⴰⵢⴰⵏ, ⴰⵔ ⵜⵜⵔⴰⵔⴰⵏ ⴽⵔⴰ ⵏ ⵉⵎⵔⵣⴰ ⵅⴼ ⵓⴱⵔⵉⴷ ⴰⵎⴳⴰⵍ: ⴳ ⵓⵎⵣⵡⴰⵔⵓ ⴰⵔ ⵉⵜⵜⵉⵍⵉ ⵓⵙⴼⴰⵡ ⵏ ⵜⵢⴰⴼⵓⵜⵉⵏ ⴷ ⵓⵎⵔⴰⵔⴰ ⵏⵏⵙⵏⵜ, ⴷ ⵓⵎⵎⵓⵜⵢ ⵙ ''ⵓⵙⵡⵜⵜⵓ ⵏ ⵜⵎⵓⴽⵔⵉⵙⵜ ⵏ ⵓⵔⵣⵣⵓ ⵏⵏⴰ ⴷⴰ ⵉⵜⵜⴱⴰⵢⴰⵏ ⴳ ⵓⵙⴹⵀⵔ ⵏ ⵜⵢⴰⴼⵓⵜⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵙⴽⵍⴰ''.

source_sentence: Qualitative research is often used as a method of exploratory research as a basis for later quantitative research hypotheses.
target_sentence: ⴰⵔ ⴱⴰⵀⵔⴰ ⵉⵜⵜⵓⵙⵎⵔⴰⵙ ⵓⵔⵣⵣⵓ ⴰⵎⴰⵏⴰⵡ ⵣⵓⵏⴷ ⵢⴰⵜ ⵜⵖⴰⵔⴰⵙⵜ ⵏ ⵓⵔⵣⵣⵓ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵏⵓⴱⴱⵛ ⵣⵓⵏⴷ ⵜⵉⵔⵙⵍⵜ ⵏ ⵜⵓⵔⴷⵉⵡⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵓⵔⵣⵣⵓ ⴰⵏⵛⵜⴰⵏ ⴷ ⵢⵓⵛⴽⴰⵏ.

source_sentence: Quantitative research is linked with the philosophical and theoretical stance of positivism.
target_sentence: ⴰⵔⵣⵣⵓ ⴰⵏⵛⵜⴰⵏ ⵉⵣⴷⵉ ⵙ ⵡⴰⴷⴷⴰⴷ ⴰⴼⵍⵙⴰⴼ ⴷ ⵓⵎⵉⵥⵉⵕ ⵏ ⵓⴷⵖⴰ.

source_sentence: Quantitative research is concerned with testing hypotheses derived from theory or being able to estimate the size of a phenomenon of interest.
target_sentence: ⴰⵔ ⵜⵜ ⵉⵜⵜⴰⵡⵉ ⵓⵔⵣⵣⵓ ⴰⵏⵛⵜⴰⵏ ⴳ ⵓⵙⵜⴰⵍ ⵏ ⵜⵓⵔⴷⵉⵡⵉⵏ ⵏⵏⴰ ⴷ ⵉⴷⴷⴰⵏ ⵙⴳ ⵜⵎⵉⵥⵉⵕⵜ ⵏⵖ ⵜⴰⵣⵎⵔⵜ ⵏ ⵉⵎⵉⵍⵖ ⵏ ⵓⴽⵙⴰⵢ ⵏ ⵜⵓⵎⴰⵏⵜ.

source_sentence: If the intent is to generalize from the research participants to a larger population, the researcher will employ probability sampling to select participants.
target_sentence: ⵎⴽ ⵉⴳⴰ ⵓⵡⵜⵜⴰⵙ ⴰⵙⵎⴰⵜⴰ ⵙⴳ ⵉⵎⴷⵔⴰⵡⵏ ⴳ ⵓⵔⵣⵣⵓ ⵅⴼ ⵡⵓⵟⵟⵓⵏ ⵉⴳⴳⵓⵜⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵎⵣⴷⴰⵖ, ⵇⴰⴷ ⵉⵙⵙⵎⵔⴰⵙ ⵓⵔⵣⵣⵓ ⵜⵓⵙⵙⵉⴼⵉⵏ ⵜⵉⴹⴰⴽⴰⴷⵉⵏ ⵃⵎⴰ ⴰⴷ ⵙⵜⵉⵏ ⵉⵎⴰⴷⵔⴰⵡⵏ.

source_sentence: Secondary data is data that already exists, such as census data, which can be re-used for the research.
target_sentence: ⵉⵙⵎⵎⴰⵍⵏ ⵉⵙⵉⵏⴰⵏⵏ ⴳⴰⵏ ⵜⵏ ⵉⵙⵎⵎⴰⵍ ⵏⵏⴰ ⵏⵉⴽ ⵉⵍⵍⴰⵏ, ⵣⵓⵏⴷ ⵉⵙⵎⵎⴰⵍⵏ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵡⵊⴷ, ⵏⵏⴰ ⵉⵖⵉⵏ ⴰⴷ ⵜⵜⵓⵙⵎⵔⴰⵙ ⵜⵉⴽⴽⵍⵜ ⵢⴰⴹⵏ ⴳ ⵓⵔⵣⵣⵓ.

source_sentence: This method has benefits that using one method alone cannot offer.
target_sentence: ⵙ ⴰⵢⴷⴷⵖ ⵏ ⵜⵖⴰⵔⴰⵙⵜ ⴽⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵢⴰⴼⵓⵜⵉⵏ ⵓⵔ ⵉⵏⵏⵉ ⴰⴷ ⵜⵏ ⵉⴼⴽ ⵓⵙⵙⵎⵔⵙ ⵏ ⵢⴰⵜ ⵜⵖⴰⵔⴰⵙⵜ ⵉⵡⴰⴹⵓ ⵏⵏⵙ.

source_sentence: Non-empirical research is not an absolute alternative to empirical research because they may be used together to strengthen a research approach.
target_sentence: ⵉⵔⵣⵣⵓⵜⵏ ⵓⵔ ⵉⴳⵉⵏ ⵉⵏⴰⵔⴰⵎⵏ ⵓⵔ ⴳⵉⵏ ⵉⵎⴽⴽⵉⵙⵉ ⵏ ⵉⵔⵣⵣⵓⵜ ⵉⵏⴰⵔⴰⵎⵏ ⴰⵛⴽⵓ ⵉⵣⵎⵔ ⴰⴷ ⵜⵜⵓⵙⵎⵔⴰⵙⵏ ⵇⵇⴰⵃ ⵙ ⵙⵉⵏ ⵃⵎⴰ ⴰⴷ ⵓⵜⵜⵓⵙⴷⵓⵙ ⵜⴱⵔⵉⴷⵜ ⵏ ⵓⵔⵣⵣⵓ.

source_sentence: The management of research ethics is inconsistent across countries and there is no universally accepted approach to how it should be addressed.
target_sentence: ⵜⴰⵎⵀⵍⴰ ⵏ ⵜⵖⴰⵔⵉⵡⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵓⵔⵣⵣⵓ ⵓⵔ ⵜⵥⴹⵉ ⴳⵔ ⵜⵎⵉⵣⴰⵔ ⴷ ⵓⵔ ⵜⵍⵍⵉ ⴰⵡⴷ ⵢⴰⵜ ⵜⵖⴰⵔⴰⵙⵜ ⵉⵖⵣⴰⵏⵏ ⴳ ⵓⵎⴰⴹⴰⵍ ⵅⴼ ⵜⵎⴰⵎⴽⵜ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵖⵓⴷⵓ ⵏⵏⵙ.

source_sentence: Regardless of approach, the application of ethical theory to specific controversial topics is known as applied ethics and research ethics can be viewed as a form of applied ethics because ethical theory is applied in real-world research scenarios.
target_sentence: ⵙ ⵎⴽⵉⵏⵏⴰ ⵜⵔⴰ ⵜⴳⵜ ⵜⵖⴰⵔⴰⵙⵜ ⵏ ⵓⴹⴼⵓⵕ, ⵉⵍⵍⴰ ⵓⵙⴽⴽⵉⵔ ⵏ ⵜⵉⵔⵎⵉⵜ ⵜⴰⵖⴰⵔⵏⵜ ⴳ ⵉⵙⵏⵜⴰⵍ ⵉⵥⵍⵉⵏ ⴳ ⵓⵎⵔⴰⵔⴰ ⴷ ⵎⵖⵏⵏⴰ ⵉⵎⵇⵇⵓⵔⵏ, ⵉⵜⵜⵡⴰⵙⵙⴰⵏ ⵙ ⵜⵖⴰⵔⵉⵡⵉⵏ ⵜⵓⵙⵏⵉⵙⵉⵏⵉⵏ ⴷ ⵜⵖⴰⵔⵉⵡⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵓⵔⵣⵣⵓ ⵉⵣⵎⵔ ⴰⴷ ⵉⴳ ⵢⴰⵏ ⵡⵓⵏⵓⵖ ⵙⴳ ⵡⵓⵏⵓⵖⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵖⴰⵔⵉⵡⵉⵏ ⵜⵓⵙⵏⵉⵙⵉⵏⵉⵏ ⴰⵛⴽⵓ ⴷⴰ ⵜⵜⵉⵍⵉ ⵜⵎⵥⵕⵉⵜ ⵜⴰⵖⴰⵔⴰⵏⵜ ⴳ ⵊⴰⵊ ⵏ ⵉⵙⵉⵏⴰⵔⵢⵓⵜⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵔⵣⵣⵓⵜⵏ ⴳ ⵓⵎⴰⴹⴰⵍ ⵏ ⵜⵉⴷⵜ.

source_sentence: Research ethics is most developed as a concept in medical research, the most notable Code being the 1964 Declaration of Helsinki.
target_sentence: ⵜⵖⴰⵔⵉⵡⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵓⵔⵣⵣⵓ ⴰⵔ ⴱⴰⵀⵔⴰ ⵉⵜⵜⴱⵓⵖⵍⵍⵓⵏ ⵣⵓⵏⴷ ⴰⵔⵎⵎⵓⵙ ⴳ ⵉⵔⵣⵣⵓⵜⵏ ⵏ ⵓⵙⴳⴳⵏⴰⴼ, ⴷ ⵜⴳⵔⵉⵡⵜ ⵜⴰⵎⵇⵇⵔⴰⵏⵜ ⵜⴳⴰ ⵜⵜ ⵓⵍⵖⵓ ⵏ ⵀⵉⵍⵉⵏⵙⴽⵉ ⴳ ⵓⵙⴳⴳⵯⴰⵙ ⵏ 1964.

source_sentence: Meta-research concerns itself with the detection of bias, methodological flaws, and other errors and inefficiencies.
target_sentence: ⵥⵍⵉⵏ ⵉⵔⵣⵣⵓⵜⵏ ⵏ ⵓⴼⵍⵍⴰ ⵙ ⵓⵣⵣⵔⴰⵢ ⵏ ⵜⵓⴷⵎⴰⵡⵉⵏ, ⴷ ⵉⵎⵍⴰⴷⵏ ⵏ ⵜⴰⵔⵔⴰⵢⵜ, ⵓⵍⴰ ⴽⵔⴰ ⵏⵏⵉⴹⵏ ⵙⴳ ⵜⵣⴳⴳⴰⵍ ⵓⵍⴰ ⴰⵙⵇⵓⴹⴻⴹ.

source_sentence: Periphery scholars face the challenges of exclusion and linguicism in research and academic publication.
target_sentence: ⴰⵔ ⵜⵜⵏⴰⵍⵏ ⵉⵎⵔⵣⴰ ⴽⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵜⴱⴱⴰⵢⴹⴰⵕⵉⵏ ⴷ ⵜⵓⴳⴳⵓⴳⵜ ⴷ ⵜⵓⵜⵍⴰⵢⴰⵏⵜ ⴳ ⵓⵔⵣⵣⵓ ⴷ ⵓⵙⴼⵙⵔ ⴰⴽⴰⴷⵉⵎⵉⵢ.

source_sentence: Peer review does not certify the correctness of the results, only that, in the opinion of the reviewer, the experiments themselves were sound (based on the description supplied by the experimenter).
target_sentence: ⵓⵔ ⵉⵙⵙⵉⵏ ⵓⵙⴼⵙⵔ ⵏ ⵉⵏⴳⴳⵓⵜⵏ ⵙ ⵓⵖⵣⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵢⴰⴼⵓⵜⵉⵏ, ⵎⴰⵛⴰ ⴰⵔ ⵉⵜⵜⴰⵏⵏⴰⵢ ⵎⴰⵙ ⵣⴷⴷⵉⴳⵏⵜ ⵜⵢⴰⴼⵓⵜⵉⵏ ⵏⵏⴰⵖ ⵙ ⵉⵅⴼⴰⵡⵏ ⵏⵏⵙⵏⵜ (ⵅⴼ ⵓⵢⵏⵏⴰ ⵉⵍⵍⴰⵏ ⴳ ⵓⵙⵏⵓⵎⵎⵍ ⵏⵏⴰ ⵉⴼⴽⴰ ⴱⴰⴱ ⵏ ⵜⵉⵔⵎⵉⵜ).

source_sentence: The systematic, careful collection of measurements or counts of relevant quantities is often the critical difference between pseudo-sciences, such as alchemy, and science, such as chemistry or biology.

source_sentence: "The operational definition of a thing often relies on comparisons with standards: the operational definition of ""mass"" ultimately relies on the use of an artifact, such as a particular kilogram of platinum-iridium kept in a laboratory in France."
target_sentence: ''ⴰⵔ ⵉⵜⴱⴷⴷⴰ ⵓⵙⵏⵎⵍ ⴰⵡⵓⵔⴰⵏ ⵏ ⴽⵔⴰ ⵏ ⵜⵖⴰⵡⵙⴰ ⴳ ⴽⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵉⴽⴽⴰⵍ ⵅⴼ ⵉⴷⵎⵣⴰⵣⴰⵍⵏ ⴰⴽⴷ ⴰⵏⵉⵙⵎⴰⵏ: ⴰⵙⵏⵎⵍ ⴰⵙⵡⵓⵔⴰⵏ ⵏ ''ⴰⴳⵓⴷⵉ'' ⴷⴰ ⵉⵜⴱⴷⴷⴰ ⴳ ⵜⴳⵉⵔⴰ ⵅⴼ ⵓⵙⵙⵎⵔⵙ ⵏ ⵜⴳⵣⵣⵓⵎⵜ ⵜⴰⴷⵔⵉⵣⴰⵏⵜ, ⵣⵓⵏⴷ ⴽⵉⵍⵓⴳⵔⴰⵎ ⵏ ⴽⵔⴰ ⵏ ⵍⴱⵍⴰⵜⵉⵏ-ⵉⵔⵉⴷⵢⵓⵎ ⴰⵎⵃⴼⵓⴹ ⴳ ⵓⵙⴰⵔⵎ ⴳ ⴼⵕⴰⵏⵚⴰ.

target_sentence: ⴰⵔ ⴱⴰⵀⵔⴰ ⵙⴼⵉⵔⵉⵙⵏⵜ ⵜⵎⴰⴽⵜⴰⵜⵉⵏ ⵜⵉⵎⵙⵙⴰⵏⵉⵏ ⵙ ⵜⴼⵔⴷⵉⵙⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵙⵖⴰⵍⵏ ⵏⵏⵙⵏⵜ ⵏⵏⴰ ⵉⵥⴹⴰⵕⵏ ⴰⴷ ⵜⵏ ⵉⵙⵏⵎⴰⵍ ⴷⴼⴼⵉⵔ ⵏ ⵎⴰⵢⵏⵏⴰ ⵙ ⵎⴰⴷ ⵉⵥⵍⵉⵏ ⵙ ⵜⴼⵔⴷⴰⵙⵉⵏ ⵜⵉⴽⵎⴰⵎⵉⵏ ⵜⵉⵣⴰⵢⴽⵓⵜⵉⵏ ⴰⴷⴷⴰⵢ ⵉⵍⴽⵎ ⵜⴰⵡⵓⵔⵉ.

source_sentence: It took thousands of years of measurements, from the Chaldean, Indian, Persian, Greek, Arabic, and European astronomers, to fully record the motion of planet Earth.

source_sentence: The observed difference for Mercury's precession between Newtonian theory and observation was one of the things that occurred to Albert Einstein as a possible early test of his theory of General relativity.

source_sentence: A scientific theory is an explanation of an aspect of the natural world and universe that has been repeatedly tested and verified in accordance with the scientific method, using accepted protocols of observation, measurement, and evaluation of results.
target_sentence: ⵜⵉⵥⵉⵕⵉ ⵜⴰⵎⴰⵙⵙⴰⵏⵜ ⵏⵜⵜⴰⵜ ⴰⴷ ⵉⵙⴼⵔⵓⵏ ⵢⴰⵜ ⵜⵙⴳⴰ ⵖ ⵓⵎⴰⴹⴰⵍ ⴰⴳⴰⵎⴰⵏ ⴷ ⵓⵖⵣⵓⵔⴰⵏ ⵍⵍⵉ ⵥⵍⵉⵏ ⵜⵓⴳⵜ ⵏⵜⵉⴽⴽⴰⵍ ⴰⴳⵉⵣ ⵔⵣⵣⵓⵏ ⵙ ⵜⵖⴰⵔⴰⵙⵜ ⵜⴰⵎⴰⵙⵙⴰⵏⵜ, ⴰⴷ ⵙⵡⵓⵔⵉⵏ ⵙ ⵓⴱⵔⵓⵜⵓⴽⵓⵍ ⵍⵍⵉ ⵙ ⵏⵥⴹⴰⵔ ⴰⴷ ⵏⵙⵜⵍ ⵏⵥⵕ ⵜⵢⴰⴼⵓⵜⵉⵏ ⵏⵏⵙ.

source_sentence: Established scientific theories have withstood rigorous scrutiny and embody scientific knowledge.

source_sentence: "Stephen Jay Gould wrote that ""...facts and theories are different things, not rungs in a hierarchy of increasing certainty."

source_sentence: The meaning of the term scientific theory (often contracted to theory for brevity) as used in the disciplines of science is significantly different from the common vernacular usage of theory.
target_sentence: ⴰⵏⴰⵎⴽ ⵏ ⵓⵔⵎⵎⵓⵙ ⵏ ⵜⵉⵥⵉⵕⵜ ⵜⵉⵎⴰⵙⵙⴰⵏⵉⵏ ( ⵍⵍⵉ ⵏⵏ ⵉⵃⵛⴰⵏ ⵖ ⵜⵉⵥⵉⵕⵜ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵉⴷⵔⵓⵙ) ⵎⴽ ⵍⵍⵉ ⵉⵜⴰⵡⵙⵎⵔⴰⵙ ⵖ ⵜⵥⵍⴰⵢⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵎⴰⵙⵙⴰⵏⵉⵏ ⵉⵎⵣⴰⵔⴰⵢ ⵢⴰⵏ ⵓⵎⵣⴰⵔⴰⵢ ⵉⴳⵓⵜⵏ ⵖ ⵓⵙⵎⵔⵙ ⵏ ⵜⵓⵜⵍⴰⵢⵜ ⵏ ⵜⵉⵥⵉⵕⵜ.

source_sentence: In everyday speech, theory can imply an explanation that represents an unsubstantiated and speculative guess, whereas in science it describes an explanation that has been tested and is widely accepted as valid.
target_sentence: ⴳ ⵜⵉⵏⴰⵡⵜ ⵜⴰⴽⵓⵢⴰⵙⵜ, ⵜⵥⴹⴰⵔ ⵜⵉⵥⵉⵕⵜ ⴰⴷ ⵟⵟⴼ ⵢⴰⵏ ⵓⵙⵙⴼⵔⵓ ⵍⵍⵉ ⴽⴰ ⵏⵇⵇⴷⵔ ⵓⵔ ⵉⵟⵟⴰⴼ ⵉⵏⴰⴳⴰⵏ, ⵎⴰⵛⵛ ⵖ ⵜⵎⴰⵙⵙⴰⵏⵜ ⴰⵔ ⵉⵜⵉⵍⵉ ⵢⴰⵏ ⵓⵙⵙⴼⵔⵓ ⵏⵙⴽⵔ ⴰⵙ ⵢⴰⵏ ⵉⵔⵉⵎ ⵏⵚⵚⵃⵓⵜ ⵏⵣⵍⵓⵣⵓⵜ ⴰⵛⴽⵓ ⵉⴳⴰ ⴰⵎⴷⴰⴷ.

source_sentence: Some theories are so well-established that they are unlikely ever to be fundamentally changed (for example, scientific theories such as evolution, heliocentric theory, cell theory, theory of plate tectonics, germ theory of disease, etc.).
target_sentence: ⴽⵔⴰ ⵏ ⵜⵎⴰⴳⵓⵏⵉⵏ ⵜⵜⵓⵢⴰⵎⴰⵥⵏⵜ ⴰⵔ ⴰⵏ ⵓⵙⵡⵉⵔ ⵏⵏⴰ ⵓⵔ ⵉⵏⵏⵉⵏ ⴰⴷ ⵜⵜⵏⵜ ⵢⴰⵊⵊ ⴰⴷ ⵜⵜⵓⵙⵏⴼⴰⵍⵜ ⵉⵙⵏⴼⵉⵍⵏ ⵉⵥⵓⵕⴰⵏⵏ ⴰⴽⴽⵯ (ⵙ ⵎⴷⵢⴰ, ⵜⵉⵎⴳⵓⵏⵉⵏ ⵜⵉⵎⴰⵙⵙⴰⵏⵉⵏ ⵣⵓⵏⴷ ⴰⴱⵓⵖⵍⵓ, ⴷ ⵜⵉⵎⴳⵓⵔⵉ ⵜⴰⴳⴳⴰⵡⴰⵏⵜ, ⴷ ⵜⵎⴳⵓⵔⵉ ⵏ ⵜⵖⵔⴰⵙⵉⵏ, ⴷ ⵜⵉⵎⴳⵓⵔⵉ ⵏ ⵜⴼⵉⵍⵉⵏ ⵜⵉⵜⴰⴽⵜⵓⵏⵢⵢⵉⵏ, ⴷ ⵜⵎⴳⵓⵔⵉ ⵏ ⵜⴱⵅⵛⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵎⴰⴹⵓⵏⵜ, ⴷ ⵡⵉⵢⵢⴰⴹ).

source_sentence: Scientific theories are testable and make falsifiable predictions.
target_sentence: ⵜⵉⵥⵉⵕⵉⵏ ⵜⵉⵎⴰⵙⵙⴰⵏⵉⵏ ⵍⴰⵇⵏ ⵜⵜ ⵉ ⵢⵉⵔⵉⵎ ⴰⵔ ⵜⵙⴽⴰⵔ ⵉⵙⵏⵉⵎⴰⵍⵏ ⵉⵣⴳⵍⵏ.

source_sentence: The defining characteristic of all scientific knowledge, including theories, is the ability to make falsifiable or testable predictions.
target_sentence: ⴷ ⵜⴼⵉⵔⵉⵙⵜ ⵏⵏⴰ ⴷⴰ ⵉⵙⵏⵓⵃⵢⵓⵏ ⴳⵔ ⵇⵇⴰⵃ ⵜⵓⵙⵙⵏⵉⵡⵉⵏ ⵜⵉⵎⴰⵙⵙⴰⵏⵉⵏ, ⵏⵏⴰ ⴳ ⴰⵎⵓⵓⵏⵜ ⵜⵎⵥⵕⵉⵜⵉⵏ, ⵉⴳⴰ ⵜⵜ ⵜⴰⵣⵎⵔⵜ ⵅⴼ ⵜⵎⴳⴳⵉⵜ ⵏ ⵉⵙⵏⵉⵎⴰⵍⵏ ⵏⵏⴰ ⵉⵖⵉⵏ ⴰⴷ ⵉⵣⴳⵍ ⵏⵖ ⵉⵔⵉⵎ.

source_sentence: It is well-supported by many independent strands of evidence, rather than a single foundation.
target_sentence: ⴰⵔ ⵜⵜⵓⵙⴷⵓⵙ ⵙ ⵢⴰⵜ ⵜⵎⴰⵎⴽⵜ ⵉⵖⵓⴷⴰⵏ ⵙ ⴽⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵏⵎⵎⴰⵍⵏ ⵉⵥⵍⵉⵏ, ⴳ ⵡⴰⵏⵙⴰ ⵏ ⴰⴷ ⵜⴳ ⵢⴰⵜ ⵜⵉⵔⵙⵍⵜ.

source_sentence: "The theory of biological evolution is more than ""just a theory""."
target_sentence: ‘’ⵜⵉⵎⵥⵕⵉⵜ ⵏ ⵓⴱⵓⵖⵍⵓ ⴰⴱⵢⵓⵍⵓⵊⵉⵢ ⵉⴳⴰ ⵓⴳⴳⴰⵔ ⵏ ''ⵓⵡⵏⴳⵉⵎ ⵏ ⵜⵉⵥⵉⵕⵜ''.

source_sentence: This provides evidence either for or against the hypothesis.
target_sentence: ⵖⵉⴷ ⴰⵔ ⵢⴰⴽⴽⴰ ⵉⵏⵥⴰⵜⵏⵙⵡⴰ ⴰⴽⴷ ⴰⵢⴷⴷⵖ ⵏ ⵜⵓⵔⴷⴰ ⵏⵖ ⵎⴳⴰⵍ ⵏ ⵜⵓⵔⴷⴰ ⴰⴷ.

source_sentence: This can take many years, as it can be difficult or complicated to gather sufficient evidence.
target_sentence: ⵉⵣⵎⵔ ⴰⴷ ⵉⴽⴽ ⵓⵢⵏⵏⴰⵖ ⴽⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵙⴳⴳⵯⴰⵙⵏ, ⴰⵛⴽⵓ ⵉⵖⵢ ⴰⴷ ⵉⵛⵇⵇⵓ ⵏⵖ ⴰⴷ ⵉⵔⵡⵉ ⵓⵙⵎⵓⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵏⵥⴰⵜⵏ ⵢⵓⴷⴰⵏ.

source_sentence: The strength of the evidence is evaluated by the scientific community, and the most important experiments will have been replicated by multiple independent groups.
target_sentence: ⴰⵔ ⵙⴽⴰⵔⵏ ⵡⴰⵎⵎⴰⵙⵏ ⵉⵎⴰⵙⵙⴰⵏ ⴰⵙⵉⵜⴳ ⵉ ⵜⴷⵓⵙⵉ ⵏ ⵉⵏⵎⵎⴰⵍⵏ, ⵇⴰⴷ ⵢⵉⵍⵉ ⵓⵍⵙⵏⵜ ⵜⵔⵓⴱⴱⴰ ⵉⵥⵍⵉⵏ ⵉⵎⵢⴰⵏⴰⵡⵏ ⵉ ⴽⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵉⵔⵉⵎⵉⵏ.

source_sentence: In chemistry, there are many acid-base theories providing highly divergent explanations of the underlying nature of acidic and basic compounds, but they are very useful for predicting their chemical behavior.
target_sentence: ⴳ ⵓⴽⵉⵎⵉ, ⵍⵍⴰⵏⵜ ⴽⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵉⵥⵉⵕⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵙⵉⵍⴰ ⵜⴰⵃⵉⵎⴹⵉⵢⵜ ⵏⵏⴰ ⵢⴰⴽⴽⴰⵏ ⵉⵙⵙⴼⵔⵓⵜⵏ ⵉⵎⵣⴰⵔⴰⵢⵏ ⴽⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⴳ ⵓⴳⴰⵎⴰ ⵏⵏⴰ ⵉⵍⵍⴰⵏ ⴷⴼⴼⵉⵔ ⵏ ⵡⵓⴷⴷⵉⵙⵏ ⵉⵃⵉⵎⴹⵉⵢⵏ ⴷ ⵉⴳⵊⴷⴰⵏⵏ, ⵎⴰⵛⴰ ⵜⴼⵓⵍⴽⵉ ⴱⴰⵀⵔⴰ ⵉ ⵓⵙⵏⵉⵎⴰⵍ ⵙ ⵜⵉⴽⵍⵉ ⵜⴰⴽⵉⵎⵉⵜ.

source_sentence: Acceptance of a theory does not require that all of its major predictions be tested, if it is already supported by sufficiently strong evidence.
target_sentence: ⵓⵔ ⴷⴰ ⵜⵜⵃⵜⴰⵊⵊⴰ ⵓⵣⵔⴰⵢ ⵏ ⵜⵉⵥⵕⵉⵜ ⵉⵔⵉⵎ ⵏ ⵇⵇⴰⵃ ⵉⵙⵏⵉⵎⴰⵍⵏ ⵉⵅⴰⵜⴰⵔⵏ, ⵎⴽ ⵜⵜⵓⵙⴷⵓⵙ ⵏⵉⵜ ⵙ ⵉⵏⵎⵎⴰⵍ ⵉⴷⵓⵙⵏ ⵏⵏⴰ ⴳ ⵜⵍⵍⴰ ⵜⵉⵙⵙⵓⴳⵔⴰ.

source_sentence: Solutions may require minor or major changes to the theory, or none at all if a satisfactory explanation is found within the theory's existing framework.
target_sentence: ⵇⴰⴷ ⵉⵔⵉⵏⵜ ⵉⴼⵙⵙⴰⵢⵏ ⴽⵔⴰ ⵏ ⵉⵙⵏⴼⴰⵍⵏ ⵉⴷⵔⵓⵙⵏ ⵏⵖ ⵉⵎⵇⵇⵓⵔⵏ ⴳ ⵜⵎⴰⴳⵓⵏⵜ, ⵏⵖ ⴰⵡⴷ ⵉⵎⵉⵍ ⴰⴽⴽⵯ ⵎⴽ ⵉⴷⴷⴰ ⵓⵙⵙⴼⵔⵓ ⵏ ⵜⵎⴰⴹⵓⵏⵜ ⴳ ⵓⴳⵏⵣⴰ ⵏ ⵖⵉⵍⴰ ⵉ ⵜⵎⴰⴳⵓⵏⵜ.

source_sentence: If modifications to the theory or other explanations seem to be insufficient to account for the new results, then a new theory may be required.
target_sentence: ⵎⴽ ⴳⴰⵏ ⵉⵙⵖⵓⴷⵓⵜⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵎⴳⵓⵔⵉ ⵏⵖ ⴽⵔⴰ ⵏⵏⵉⴹⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵙⵙⴼⵔⵓⵜⵏ ⵓⵔ ⵢⵓⴷⵉⵏ ⴰⴷ ⵉⵙⴱⵉⴷⴷ ⵜⵉⵢⴰⴼⵓⵜⵉⵏ ⵜⵉⵎⴰⵢⵏⵓⵜⵉⵏ, ⴳ ⵜⵉⵣⵉ ⵏⵏⴰⵖ ⵇⴰⴷ ⵢⵉⵍⵉ ⵓⵃⵜⴰⵊ ⵏ ⵜⵎⴰⴳⵓⵏⵜ ⵜⴰⵎⴰⵢⵏⵓⵜ.

source_sentence: This is because it is still the best available explanation for many other phenomena, as verified by its predictive power in other contexts.
target_sentence: ⵎⴰⵏ ⴰⵢⴰ ⵉⵙⵓⵍ ⵓⵙⵙⴼⵔⵓ ⵉⵖⵓⴷⴰⵏ ⵉⵜⵜⵓⴼⴽⴰ ⵉ ⴽⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵓⵎⴰⵏⵉⵏ ⵏⵏⵉⴹⵏ, ⵎⴽⵉⵏⵏⴰ ⵉⵜⵜⵡⴰⵣⵔⴰⵢ ⵙⴳ ⵜⴷⵓⵙⵉ ⵏⵏⵙⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵙⵏⵎⴰⵍⵏ ⴳ ⵉⵎⵏⴰⴹⵏ ⵢⴰⴹⵏ.

source_sentence: After the changes, the accepted theory will explain more phenomena and have greater predictive power (if it did not, the changes would not be adopted); this new explanation will then be open to further replacement or modification.
target_sentence: ⴷ ⴽⵔⴰ ⵏ ⵉⵙⵏⴼⵉⵍⵏ, ⵇⴰⴷ ⵙⵙⴼⵔⵓⵏ ⵜⵉⵎⵥⵕⵉⵜ ⵉⵣⵔⵉⵏ ⴽⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵓⵎⴰⵏⵉⵏ ⵙ ⵢⴰⵏ ⵡⴰⵜⵉⴳ ⵎⵇⵇⵓⵔⵏ ⵏ ⵜⴷⵓⵙⵉ ⵏ ⵉⵙⵏⵎⴰⵍⵏ (ⵎⴽ ⵓⵔ ⵜⵙⵙⴽⵉⵔⵜ ⴰⵢⵏⵏⴰⵖ ⵓⵔ ⵉⵏⵏⵉ ⴰⴷ ⵉⵜⵜⵡⴰⵙⴰⵢ ⵙ ⵉⵏⵎⵎⴰⵍⵏ); ⴷ ⵇⴰⴷ ⵉⵃⵜⴰⵊⵊⴰ ⵓⵙⵙⴼⵔⵓ ⴰⴷ ⴰⵎⴰⵢⵏⵓ ⴷⴼⵉⵔ ⵏ ⵓⵢⵏⵏⴰⵖ ⵉ ⴽⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵏⵎⵎⴰⵍⵏ ⵏⵖ ⵉⵙⵖⵓⴷⵓⵜⵏ.

source_sentence: For example, electricity and magnetism are now known to be two aspects of the same phenomenon, referred to as electromagnetism.
target_sentence: ⵙ ⵓⵎⴷⵢⴰ, ⵉⵜⵜⵡⴰⵙⵙⴰⵏ ⵖⵉⵍⴰ ⵎⴰⵙ ⵉⴳⴰ ⵡⴰⵙⵉⴷⴷ ⴷ ⵓⵎⴰⵖⵏⴰⵟⵉⵙ ⵙⵉⵏ ⵡⵓⴷⵎⴰⵡⵏ ⵏ ⵢⴰⵜ ⵜⵓⵎⴰⵏⵜ, ⴰⵔ ⵜⵜⵓⵙⵙⴽⴰⵏ ⵙ ⵡⴰⵙⵙⴰⵖ ⵏ ⵍⴽⵀⵕⵓⵎⵉⵖⵏⴰⵟⵉⵙⵉ.

source_sentence: This was resolved by the discovery of nuclear fusion, the main energy source of the Sun.
target_sentence: ⵉⵜⵜⵓⵙⴼⵙⴰⵢ ⵎⴰⵏ ⴰⵢⴰ ⵙ ⵜⴱⵔⵉⴷⵜ ⵏ ⵓⴽⵛⵛⵓⵎ ⴰⵏⴰⵡⴰⵡⵉⵢ, ⴰⵖⴱⴰⵍⵓ ⵏ ⵜⵣⵎⵔⵜ ⴰⴳⵊⴷⴰⵏⵜ ⵏ ⵜⴰⴼⵓⴳⵜ.

source_sentence: By omitting from special relativity the luminiferous aether, Einstein stated that time dilation and length contraction measured in an object in relative motion is inertial—that is, the object exhibits constant velocity, which is speed with direction, when measured by its observer.
target_sentence: ⵙⴳ ⵜⴻⵜⵜⵓⵜ ⵏ ⵜⵓⵙⵖⴰⵏⵜ ⵜⴰⵎⵥⵍⴰⵢⵜ, ⵉⴱⴷⵔ ⵉⵏⵛⵟⴰⵢⵏ ⵎⴰⵙ ⵜⵉⵅⵅⵉⵜⵔⵜ ⵏ ⵡⴰⴽⵓⴷ ⴷ ⵜⴱⴷⴷⵉ ⵏ ⵜⴰⵖⵣⵉ ⵏⵏⴰ ⵉⵜⵜⵓⵙⵖⴰⵍⵏ ⴳ ⴽⵔⴰ ⵏ ⵜⴼⴳⴳⴰ ⴳ ⴽⵔⴰ ⵏ ⵓⵎⵓⵙⵙⵓ ⵓⵙⵖⴰⵏ ⵉⴳⴰ ⵜ ⵓⵇⵓⴹⴻⴹ ⵓⵏⵎⴰⵙ- ⵙ ⵓⵏⴰⵎⴽ ⵏⵏⵉⴹⵏ ⴰⵔ ⴷ ⵜⵙⵙⵓⴼⵓⵖ ⵜⴼⴳⴳⴰ ⵢⴰⵏ ⵓⵙⵙⵔⵉⵔⵔⵉ ⴰⵔⵎⵙⵉⴽⵍ, ⵉⴳⴰ ⵓⵙⵙⵔⵉⵔⵔⵉ ⴰⴽⴷ ⵜⵏⵉⵍⴰ, ⴰⵙⵔⴰ ⴳ ⵉⵜⵜⵓⵙⵖⴰⵍ ⵙ ⵜⵏⵎⴰⵜⴰⵔⵜ.

source_sentence: Einstein sought to generalize the invariance principle to all reference frames, whether inertial or accelerating.
target_sentence: ⵉⴷⴷⴰ ⵉⵏⵛⵟⴰⵢⵏ ⵙ ⵓⵙⵎⴰⵜⴰ ⵏ ⵓⵎⵏⵣⴰⵢ ⴰⵔⵎⵙⴽⵉⵍ ⵅⴼ ⵎⴰⴷ ⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⴰⵙⴰⵜⵉ ⴰⵙⴰⵖⵓⵍ, ⵎⵇⵇⴰⵔ ⵉⴳⴰ ⴰⵔⵎⵙⴽⵉⵍ ⵏⵖ ⵢⵓⵣⵣⵍⴰⵏ.

source_sentence: "Even massless energy exerts gravitational motion on local objects by ""curving"" the geometrical ""surface"" of 4D space-time."
target_sentence: ⴰⵡⴷ ⵜⴰⵣⵎⴰⵔⵜ ⵏⵏⴰ ⵓⵔ ⵉⵜⵙⵎⴰⴷⵏ ⴰⵔ ⵜⵙⴽⴰⵔ ⴰⵎⵓⵙⵙⵓ ⴰⵎⵍⴷⴰⵢ ⵅⴼ ⵜⴼⴽⴽⵉⵡⵉⵏ ⵜⵉⴷⵖⵔⴰⵏⵉⵏ ⵙ ⵜⵖⴰⵔⴰⵙⵜ ''ⵉⵃⵓⴷⵔⵏ'' ''ⴰⵣⵓⵔ'' ⴰⵜⵡⴰⵍ 4ⴷ ⴰⵣⵎⵣ.

source_sentence: However, scientific laws are descriptive accounts of how nature will behave under certain conditions.
target_sentence: ⵎⴰⵛⴰ ⴰⵣⵔⴼ/ⴰⵙⵍⴳⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵓⵙⵙⵏⴰ ⵉⴳⴰ ⴰⵙⵉⵟⵟⵏ ⴰⵏⴰⵎⵎⴰⵍ ⵏ ⵜⵎⴰⵎⴽⵜ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵡⵓⵔⵉ ⵏ ⵜⴳⴰⵎⴰ ⴳ ⵢⵉⴷⵙⵏ ⵉⵎⵔⵏⵓⵜⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵖⴰⵔⴰ.

source_sentence: A common misconception is that scientific theories are rudimentary ideas that will eventually graduate into scientific laws when enough data and evidence have been accumulated.
target_sentence: ⵙⴳ ⵉⵣⴳⴳⴰⵍⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵔⵎⵎⵓⵙⵏ ⵎⴰⵙ ⴷ ⵜⵉⵎⴰⴳⵓⵏⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵉⵎⴰⵙⵙⵏⵉⵏ ⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵜⴰⵏⵏⴰⵢⵉⵏ ⵜⵉⵣⴰⵢⴽⵓⵜⵉⵏ ⵔⴰⴷ ⵜⴼⴼⵖ ⴳ ⵜⴳⵉⵔⴰ ⵖⵔ ⵉⵙⵍⴳⴰⵏⵏ ⵉⵎⴰⵙⵙⴰⵏⵏ ⵜⵉⵣⵉ ⴳ ⵎⵓⵏⵜ ⵜⵙⵎⵎⴰⵍⵉⵏ ⴷ ⵉⵎⵙⴽⴰⵏⵏ ⵉⴳⵓⵎⵏ.

source_sentence: Both theories and laws could potentially be falsified by countervailing evidence.
target_sentence: ⴷ ⵉⵖⵢ ⴰⴷ ⵜⵜⵓⵔⵊⴰⵏⴻⵏⵜ ⵜⵎⴰⴳⵓⵏⵉⵏ ⴷ ⵉⵣⵔⴼⴰⵏⵙ ⵜⵏⵉⵍⴰ ⵏ ⵉⵎⵙⴽⴰⵏⵏ ⵉⵔⵔⴰⵣⵏ.

source_sentence: First-order logic is an example of a formal language.

source_sentence: "Several philosophers and historians of science have, however, argued that Popper's definition of theory as a set of falsifiable statements is wrong because, as Philip Kitcher has pointed out, if one took a strictly Popperian view of ""theory"", observations of Uranus when first discovered in 1781 would have ""falsified"" Newton's celestial mechanics."

source_sentence: Astrobiology, formerly known as exobiology, is an interdisciplinary scientific field that studies the origins, early evolution, distribution, and future of life in the universe.

source_sentence: Biochemistry may have begun shortly after the Big Bang, 13.8 billion years ago, during a habitable epoch when the Universe was only 10–17 million years old.

source_sentence: "The term xenobiology is now used in a more specialized sense, to mean ""biology based on foreign chemistry"", whether of extraterrestrial or terrestrial (possibly synthetic) origin."
target_sentence: “ⴷⴰ ⵉⵜⵜⵓⵙⵡⵓⵔⵉ ⵢⵉⵔⵎ ⵏ ⵜⴱⵢⵓⵍⵓⵊⵉⵜ ⵏ ⵉⵏⴱⵕⵕⴰⵜⵏ ⴷⵖⵉ ⵙ ⵓⵏⴰⵎⴽ ⴰⵎⵥⵍⴰⵢ ⵓⴳⴰⵔ, ⵉ ⵓⵏⴰⵎⴽ ⵏ ““ⵜⴱⵢⵓⵍⵓⵊⵉⵜ ⵉⵙⴽⴰⵜⵜⵉⵏ ⵅⴼ ⵜⴽⵉⵎⵉⵜ ⵜⴰⵏⴱⵕⵕⴰⵜ””, ⵙⵡ ⵉⵍⵍ ⴱⵕⵕⴰ ⵏ ⵡⴰⴽⴰⵍ ⵏⵖ ⵉⵍⴰ ⴰⵥⵖⵕ ⵏ ⵡⴰⴽⴰⵍ (ⵉⵖⵢ ⴰⴷ ⵉⴳ ⴰⵎⴳⵓⵔⴰⵏ).”

source_sentence: Though once considered outside the mainstream of scientific inquiry, astrobiology has become a formalized field of study.

source_sentence: In 1959, NASA funded its first exobiology project, and in 1960, NASA founded an Exobiology Program, which is now one of four main elements of NASA's current Astrobiology Program.
target_sentence: ⴳ ⵓⵙⴳⴳⵯⴰⵙ ⵏ 1959, ⵜⵍⵍⴰ ⵏⴰⵣⴰ (NASA) ⴷ ⵓⵙⵖⵏⵓ ⵏⵏⵙ ⴰⵎⵣⵡⴰⵔⵓ ⴳ ⵜⴱⵢⵓⵍⵓⵊⵉⵜ ⵜⴰⵏⴱⵕⵕⴰⵏⵜ, ⴳ ⵓⵙⴳⴳⵯⴰⵙ ⵏ 1960, ⵜⵙⴽⴰ ⵏⴰⵣⴰ ⴰⵖⴰⵡⴰⵙ ⵏ ⵜⴱⵢⵓⵍⵓⵊⵉⵜ ⵜⵏⴱⵕⵕⴰⵏⵜ, ⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵢⴰⵏ ⵙⴳ ⴽⴽⵓⵥ ⵏ ⵉⴼⵕⴹⵉⵚⵏ ⵉⴷⵙⵍⴰⵏⵏ ⵉ ⵓⵖⴰⵡⴰⵙ ⵏ ⵜⴱⵢⵓⵍⵓⵊⵉⵜ ⵏ ⵜⵙⵏⵉⵜⵔⵉⵜ ⵉⴹⴼⴰⵕⵏ ⵉ ⵏⴰⵣⴰ.

source_sentence: Advancements in the fields of astrobiology, observational astronomy and discovery of large varieties of extremophiles with extraordinary capability to thrive in the harshest environments on Earth, have led to speculation that life may possibly be thriving on many of the extraterrestrial bodies in the universe.
target_sentence: ⵢⵓⵡⵉ ⴷ ⵓⴱⵓⵖⵍⵓ ⴳ ⵢⵉⴳⵔⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵜⴱⵢⵓⵍⵓⵊⵉⵜ ⵏ ⵜⵙⵏⵉⵜⵔⵉⵜ ⴷ ⵜⵙⵏⵉⵜⵔⵉⵜ ⵏ ⵡⵓⴹⵓⴼ ⴷ ⵜⵉⴼⵉ ⵏ ⵡⴰⵏⴰⵡⵏ ⴳⴳⵓⴷⵉⵏⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵎⵉⵍⵉⵜⵏ ⵉⵎⵔⴰⵔⵏ ⵙ ⵜⵣⵎⵎⴰⵔ ⵜⵓⴷⴷⵉⵙⵉⵏ ⵜⵉⴳⵎⵉ ⵏ ⵜⴳⴰⵎⴰ ⵡⴼ ⵡⴰⴽⴰⵍ, ⴰⵔ ⵜⵓⵔⴷⴰⵡⵉⵏ ⵉⵙ ⵜⵣⵎⵔ ⵜⵓⴷⵔⵜ ⴰⴷ ⵜⵉⵍⵉ ⴱⵕⵕⴰ ⵏ ⵡⴰⴽⴰⵍ ⴳ ⵓⵖⵣⵡⵔ.

source_sentence: Missions specifically designed to search for current life on Mars were the Viking program and Beagle 2 probes.

source_sentence: In late 2008, the Phoenix lander probed the environment for past and present planetary habitability of microbial life on Mars, and researched the history of water there.

source_sentence: "The term's meanings changed in the early 20th century when American social scientists, beginning with Thorstein Veblen, translated ideas from the German concept of Technik into ""technology."""
target_sentence: ⵜⵜⵓⵙⵏⴼⵍⵏ ⵉⵏⴰⵎⴽⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵙⵉⵙⵙⵏ ⴳ ⵓⵙⴰⵜⵓ ⵡⵉⵙⵙ 20, ⴷⴷⴰ ⴳ ⵙⴽⵔⵏ ⵉⵎⵓⵙⵏⴰⵡⵏ ⵉⵎⴰⵙⵙⵏⴰⵎⵓⵏ ⵉⵎⵉⵔⵉⴽⴰⵏⵉⵢⵏ, ⵙ ⵓⵙⵙⵏⵜⵉ ⵜⵓⵔⵙⵜⵉⵏ ⴼⵉⴱⵍⵏ, ⵉⵙⵙⵓⵖⵍⵏ ⵜⵉⵡⵏⴳⵉⵎⵉⵏ ⵙⴳ ⵓⵙⵉⵙⵙⵏ ⴰⵍⵎⴰⵏⵉ ⵏ ⵜⵉⴽⵏⵉⴽ ⵖⵔ ⵜⵉⴽⵏⵓⵍⵓⵊⵢⴰ.

source_sentence: "In 1937, the American sociologist Read Bain wrote that ""technology includes all tools, machines, utensils, weapons, instruments, housing, clothing, communicating and transporting devices and the skills by which we produce and use them."""
target_sentence: ⴳ ⵓⵙⴳⴳⵯⴰⵙ ⵏ 1937, ⵢⴰⵔⵓ ⵓⵎⵓⵙⵙⵏⴰⵎⵓⵏ ⴰⵎⵉⵔⵉⴽⴰⵏⵉ ⵔⵉⴷ ⴱⴰⵢⵏ ⴰⵏ; ⵜⴰⵜⵉⴽⵏⵓⵍⵓⵊⵉⵜ ⵜⵙⵎⴰⵏ ⴰⴽⴽⵯ ⵉⵙⴳⴳⵓⵔⵏ ⴷ ⵉⵎⴰⵙⵙⵏ ⴷ ⵉⵇⵛⵓⵛⵏ ⴷ ⵉⵎⵔⵉⴳⵏ ⴷ ⵉⵙⴳⴳⵓⵔⵏ ⴷ ⵓⵣⴷⴷⵓⵖ ⴷ ⵜⵎⵍⵙⴰ ⴷ ⵉⵏⴳⵎⴰⵎⵏ ⵏ ⵓⵎⵢⴰⵡⴰⴹ ⴷ ⵓⵙⵏⵖⵍ ⴷ ⵉⴼⵓⴽⵙⵏ ⵏⵏⴰ ⵏⵙⵏⴼⵍⵓⵍ ⴷ ⴰⵔ ⵜⵜ ⵏⵙⵙⵎⵔⴰⵙ.

source_sentence: "More recently, scholars have borrowed from European philosophers of ""technique"" to extend the meaning of technology to various forms of instrumental reason, as in Foucault's work on technologies of the self (techniques de soi)."

source_sentence: "to invent useful things or to solve problems"" and ""a machine, piece of equipment, method, etc.,"

source_sentence: The term is often used to imply a specific field of technology, or to refer to high technology or just consumer electronics, rather than technology as a whole.

source_sentence: "W. Brian Arthur defines technology in a similarly broad way as ""a means to fulfill a human purpose."""
target_sentence: ⴷ ⵉⵙⵉⵙⵙⵉⵏ ⵡⵉⵍⵢⴰⵎ ⴱⵔⵢⴰⵏ ⴰⵔⵜⵓⵔ ⵜⴰⵜⵉⴽⵏⵓⵍⵓⵊⵉⵜ ⵙ ⵜⴱⵔⵉⴷⵜ ⵜⴰⵎⵉⵔⵉⵡⵜ ⵢⴰⴽⵙⵓⵍⵏ, ⵉⵙ ⵜⴳⴰ ⴰⵎⵎⴰⴽ ⵎⴰⵔ ⴰⴷ ⵢⴰⵡⴹ ⵓⴼⴳⴰⵏ ⴰⵙⵓⵖⴷ ⵏⵏⵙ.

source_sentence: "When combined with another term, such as ""medical technology"" or ""space technology,"" it refers to the state of the respective field's knowledge and tools. """

source_sentence: Additionally, technology is the application of mathematics, science, and the arts for the benefit of life as it is known.
target_sentence: ⵙ ⵜⵉⵔⵏⵓⵜ ⵏ ⵎⴰⵏⴰⵢⴰ, ⵜⴳⴰ ⵜⵉⴽⵏⵓⵍⵓⵊⵉⵜ ⴰⵙⵙⵎⵔⵙ ⵏ ⵜⵓⵙⵏⴰⴽⵜ ⴷ ⵜⵎⴰⵙⵙⴰⵏⵉⵏ ⴷ ⵜⵥⵓⵕⵉⵡⵉⵏ ⵖⴼ ⵜⵓⴷⵔⵜ ⵉⵎⴽ ⵜⵢⴰⵙⵙⴰⵏ.

source_sentence: Engineering is the goal-oriented process of designing and making tools and systems to exploit natural phenomena for practical human means, often (but not always) using results and techniques from science.
target_sentence: ⴰⵜⵡⴰⵍ ⵜⴳⴰⵜ ⵜⵎⴳⴳⵉⵜ ⵉⵏⵎⵏ ⵖⵔ ⵓⵙⵓⵖⴷ ⵉ ⵓⵎⵎⴰⴽ ⴷ ⵓⵙⵙⴽⴰⵔ ⵏ ⵉⵙⴳⴳⵓⵔⵏ ⴷ ⵉⴳⵔⵔⴰⵢⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵎⴰⵙⵙⵏ ⵉⵏⴰⴼⴳⴰⵏ ⵉⵎⴰⵙⵙⴰⵏⴻⵏ, ⴷ ⵡⴰⵍⴰ (ⵎⴰⴽⴰ ⵓⵔ ⵉⴷ ⴰⵀⴰ) ⴰⵙⵙⵎⵔⵙ ⵏ ⵜⵢⴰⴼⵓⵜⵉⵏ ⴷ ⵜⵉⵇⵏⵉⵜⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵓⵙⵙⵏⴰ.

source_sentence: For example, science might study the flow of electrons in electrical conductors by using already-existing tools and knowledge.

source_sentence: The exact relations between science and technology, in particular, have been debated by scientists, historians, and policymakers in the late 20th century, in part because the debate can inform the funding of basic and applied science.

source_sentence: Early humans evolved from a species of foraging hominids which were already bipedal, with a brain mass approximately one third of modern humans.

source_sentence: "The late cultural critic Neil Postman distinguished tool-using societies from technological societies and from what he called ""technopolies,"" societies that are dominated by the ideology of technological and scientific progress to the exclusion or harm of other cultural practices, values, and world-views."

source_sentence: "In 2005, futurist Ray Kurzweil predicted that the future of technology would mainly consist of an overlapping ""GNR Revolution"" of genetics, nanotechnology and robotics, with robotics being the most important of the three."

source_sentence: Artificial intelligence (AI) is intelligence demonstrated by machines, as opposed to the natural intelligence displayed by humans or animals.

source_sentence: AI research has tried and discarded many different approaches during its lifetime, including simulating the brain, modeling human problem solving, formal logic, large databases of knowledge and imitating animal behavior.
target_sentence: ⵓⵔⵎⵏ ⵉⵔⵣⵣⵓⵜⵏ ⵏ ⵛⵡⵉⵢⵜ ⵜⴰⵎⴳⵓⵔⴰⵏⵜ ⴷ ⵜⵏⴹⵡ ⴽⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵡⴰⵎⵎⴰⴽⵏ ⵉⵎⵣⴰⵔⴰⵢⵏ ⴳ ⵜⵓⴷⵔⵜ ⵏⵏⵙ, ⴳ ⵢⴰⵎⵓ ⵡⵓⵏⵓⴷ ⵏ ⵓⵏⵍⵍⵉ, ⴷ ⵓⵙⵎⴷⵢⴰ ⵏ ⵓⴼⵙⴰⵢ ⵏ ⵉⵎⵓⴽⵔⵉⵙⵏ ⵏ ⵓⴼⴳⴰⵏ, ⴷ ⵓⵎⴳⵏ ⵓⵏⵚⵉⴱ, ⴷ ⵉⵍⴳⴰⵎⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵏⵎⵎⴰⵍⵏ ⵉⵅⴰⵜⴰⵔⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵓⵙⵙⵏⴰ ⴷ ⵜⴹⴼⵕⵜ ⵏ ⵜⴽⵍⵉ ⵏ ⵓⵎⵓⴷⵔ.

source_sentence: The traditional goals of AI research include reasoning, knowledge representation, planning, learning, natural language processing, perception and the ability to move and manipulate objects.
target_sentence: ⵙⵎⴰⵏ ⵉⵙⵓⵖⴰⴷ ⵉⵣⴰⵢⴽⵓⵜⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵔⵣⵣⵓⵜⵏ ⵏ ⵛⵛⵡⵉⵢⵜ ⵜⴰⵎⴳⵓⵔⴰⵏⵜ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵡⵉⵏⴳⵎ, ⴷ ⵓⵙⵎⴷⵢⴰ ⵏ ⵜⵓⵙⵙⵏⴰ,ⴷ ⵓⵖⴰⵡⵙ, ⴷ ⵓⵍⵎⵎⵓⴷ, ⴷ ⵓⵙⵎⴽⵍ ⵏ ⵜⵓⵜⵍⴰⵢⵜ ⵜⴰⵖⴰⵔⴰⵏⵜ, ⴷ ⴰⵜⴰⵎ ⴷ ⵢⵉⵖⵉⵢ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵎⵎⵛⵜⴳ ⵏ ⵜⵖⴰⵡⵙⵉⵡⵉⵏ ⴷ ⵓⵙⵎⴽⵍ ⵏⵏⵙ.

target_sentence: ⵜⵜⵓⵙⵏⵜⴰⵢ ⵜⵣⵔⴰⵡⵜ ⵏ ⵓⵎⴳⵉⵏ ⴰⵎⵉⴽⴰⵏⵉⴽ ⵏⵖⴷ ⵓⵏⵚⵉⴱ ⴰⴽⴷ ⵉⴼⵍⵙⴰⴼⵏ ⴷ ⵉⵎⵓⵙⵏⴰⵡⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵓⵙⵏⴰⴽⵜ ⴳ ⵉⵙⴰⵜⵜⵓⵜⵏ ⵉⵣⴰⵢⴽⵓⵜⵏ.

source_sentence: The Church-Turing thesis, along with concurrent discoveries in neurobiology, information theory and cybernetics, this led researchers to consider the possibility of building an electronic brain.
target_sentence: ⵜⵓⵡⵉⴷ ⵜⴷⵓⴽⵜⵓⵕⵜ ⵏⵜⵛⵓⵔⵛ ⵜⵓⵔⵉⵏ ⵜⴰⵎⴰⵏ ⵢⵉⴼⵉⵜⵏ ⴷ ⵢⵓⵙⴰⵏ ⴳ ⵜⴱⵢⵓⵍⵓⵊⵉⵜ ⵜⴰⵔⵏⴰⵏⵜ, ⴷ ⵜⵎⴰⴳⵓⵏⵜ ⵏ ⵉⵏⵖⵎⵉⵙⵏ ⴷ ⵜⵓⵙⵙⵏⴰ ⵏ ⵓⵏⴱⴰⴹ ⵉⵎⵉⵙ, ⵙ ⵉⵎⵔⵣⵓⵜⵏ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵡⵉⵏⴳⵎ ⴳ ⵜⵎⴰⵎⴽⵜ ⵏ ⵓⵙⴽⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵓⵏⵍⵍⵉ ⵉⵍⵉⴽⵟⵕⵓⵏⵉ.

source_sentence: Attendees Allen Newell (CMU), Herbert Simon (CMU), John McCarthy (MIT), Marvin Minsky (MIT) and Arthur Samuel (IBM) became the founders and leaders of AI research.
target_sentence: ⵜⴳⴰ ⵜⵉⵍⵉⵜ ⴰⵍⵉⵏ ⵏⵡⵉⵍ (CMU), ⴷ ⵀⴰⵔⴱⵔⵜ ⵙⵉⵎⵓⵏ (CMU), ⴷ ⵊⵓⵏ ⵎⴽⴰⵔⵜⵉ ( ⴰⵙⵉⵏⴰⴳ ⵏ ⵎⴰⵙⴰⵜⵛⵓⵙⵜⵛ ⵉ ⵜⵉⴽⵏⵓⵍⵓⵊⵉⵜ), ⴷ ⵎⴰⵔⴼⵏ ⵎⵉⵏⵙⴽⵉ ( ⴰⵙⵉⵏⴰⴳ ⵏ ⵎⴰⵙⴰⵜⵛⵓⵙⵜⵙ ⵉ ⵜⵉⴽⵏⵓⵍⵓⵊⵉⵜ), ⴷ ⴰⵔⵜⵔ ⵚⴰⵎⵡⵉⵍ (IBM), ⵉⵎⵙⵙⵏⵜⵉⵏ ⴷ ⵉⵎⵓⵣⵔⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵔⵣⵣⵓⵜⵏ ⵏ ⵛⵛⵡⵉⵢⵜ ⵜⴰⵎⴳⵓⵔⴰⵏⵜ.

source_sentence: "AI's founders were optimistic about the future: Herbert Simon predicted, ""machines will be capable, within twenty years, of doing any work a man can do""."
target_sentence: ⵉⵎⵙⵙⵏⵜⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵎⴰⴷⴷⴰⵙⵜ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵓⵔⴼ ⴰⴳⵔⴰⵖⵍⴰⵏ ⵙⴼⴰⵍⵏ ⵙ ⵉⵎⴰⵍ: ⵉⴷⵎⴰ ⵀⵔⴱⵔⵜ ⵙⵉⵎⵓⵏ “ⵇⴰⴷ ⵉⵖⵉⵢⵏ ⵉⵎⴰⵙⵙⵏ ⴳ ⵓⴳⵏⴰⵔ ⵏ ⵉⵙⴳⴳⵯⴰⵙⵏ ⴰⴷ ⵙⴽⵔⵏ ⴽⴰ ⵉⴳⴰⵜ ⵜⴰⵡⵓⵔⵉ ⵙ ⵉⵖⵢ ⵓⵔⴳⴰⵣ ⴰⴷ ⵜ ⵉⵙⴽⵔ”.

source_sentence: Progress slowed and in 1974, in response to the criticism of Sir James Lighthill and ongoing pressure from the US Congress to fund more productive projects, both the U.S. and British governments cut off exploratory research in AI.
target_sentence: ⵉⵥⵥⴰⵢ ⵓⵣⵣⵉⴳⵣ ⴳ ⵓⵙⴳⴳⵯⴰⵙ ⵏ 1974, ⴰⵛⴽⵓ ⵉⵙⵎⴷⵔ ⵉ ⵓⵣⵖⵏ ⵏ ⵎⴰⵙⵙ ⵊⵉⵎⵙ ⵍⴰⵢⵜⵉⵍ, ⴷ ⵓⵙⵙⵉⴽⵍ ⵉⵣⴷⵉⵏ ⵙⴳ ⵖⵓⵔ ⵍⴽⵓⵏⴳⵔⵉⵙ ⵏ ⵍⴰⵎⵉⵔⵉⴽ ⵎⴰⵔ ⴰⴷ ⵉⵙⵙⵥⵕⴼ ⵉⵙⵏⴼⴰⵔⵏ ⵡⴰⵍⴰ ⵉⵔⴰⵏ ⴰⴷ ⵉⴽ, ⵜⵙⴱⴷⴷ ⵜⵏⴱⴰⴹⵜ ⵏ ⵍⴰⵎⵉⵔⵉⴽ ⵜⵉⵏ ⴱⵕⵉⵟⴰⵏⵢⴰ ⴰⵔⵣⵣⵓ ⵏ ⵢⵉⴽⵉⵣ ⴳ ⵛⵛⵡⵉⵢⵜ ⵜⴰⵎⴳⵓⵔⴰⵏⵜ.

source_sentence: By 1985, the market for AI had reached over a billion dollars.
target_sentence: ⴷⴷⴰⴳ ⵢⵓⵡⴹ ⵓⵙⴳⴳⵯⴰⵙ ⵏ 1985, ⵉⴳⵓⵍⴰⵏ ⵓⴳⴰⴷⴰⵣ ⵏ ⵛⵛⵡⵉⵢⵜ ⵜⴰⵎⴳⵓⵔⴰⵏⵜ ⴰⵔ ⵓⴳⴳⴰⵔ ⵏ ⵢⵉⴼⴹ ⵉⴳⵏⴷⴰⴷ ⵏ ⵉⴷ ⴷⵓⵍⴰⵕ.

source_sentence: Faster computers, algorithmic improvements, and access to large amounts of data enabled advances in machine learning and perception; data-hungry deep learning methods started to dominate accuracy benchmarks around 2012.
target_sentence: ⵓⵡⵉⵏⴷ ⵉⵍⴳⵎⴰⵎⵏ ⵏ ⵓⵎⵙⵙⵓⴷⵙ ⴰⵎⵙⵔⴱⵉ, ⴷ ⵜⵙⵖⵓⴷⵓⵜⵉⵏ ⵏ ⴰⵍⴳⵓⵔⵉⵜⵎ, ⴷ ⵢⵉⵡⴹ ⵙ ⵉⴳⵓⴷⵉⵢⵏ ⵉⴳⴳⵓⴷⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵏⵎⵎⴰⵍⵏ ⵖⵔ ⵓⵣⵣⵉⴳⵣ ⴳ ⵓⵙⵙⵍⵎⴷ ⵏ ⵉⵎⵉⵙ ⴷ ⵓⵔⵎⵎⵓⵙ; ⵜⵜⵓⵙⵏⵜⴰⵢⵏ ⵡⴰⵎⵎⴰⴽⵏ ⵏ ⵓⵍⵎⵎⵓⴷ ⵉⵖⴱⴰⵏ ⵉⵔⴰⵏ ⵉⵏⵎⵎⴰⵍⵏ ⴳ ⵓⵏⴱⴰⴹ ⵖⴼ ⵉⵙⴼⵔⴰⵏⴻⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵓⵏⵖⵉⴷⵜ ⴳ ⵡⴰⵜⵜⴰⵢⵏ ⵏ ⵓⵙⴳⴳⴰⵙ ⵏ 2012.

source_sentence: AI research divided into competing sub-fields that often failed to communicate with each other.
target_sentence: ⴱⴹⴰⵏ ⵉⵔⵣⵣⵓⵜⵏ ⵏ ⵛⵛⵡⵉⵢⵜ ⵜⴰⵎⴳⴰⵔⴰⵏⵜ ⵖⴼ ⵢⵉⴳⵔⴰⵏ ⴰⵢⵢⴰⵡⵏ ⵉⵜⵎⵛⴰⵃⴰⴷⵏ, ⴰⵔ ⵡⴰⵍⴰ ⵎⵙⴰⵙⴰⵏⵜ ⴳⵔⴰⵙⵏⵜ ⴳ ⵓⵎⵙⴰⵡⴰⴹ.

source_sentence: The research was centered in three institutions: Carnegie Mellon University, Stanford, and MIT, and as described below, each one developed its own style of research.
target_sentence: ⵉⵙⵎⵙⵙⴰ ⵓⵙⵏⵓⴱⴱⵛ ⵖⴼ ⴽⵕⴰⴹ ⵜⵎⵔⵙⴰⵍ: ⵜⴰⵙⴷⴰⵡⵉⵜ ⵏ ⴽⴰⵕⵏⵊⵉ ⵎⵉⵍⵓⵏ, ⴷ ⵙⵜⴰⵏⴼⵓⵔⴷ, ⴷ ⵓⵙⵉⵏⴰⴳ ⵏ ⵎⴰⵙⴰⵜⵛⵓⵙⵜⵛ ⵏ ⵜⵉⴽⵏⵓⵍⵓⵊⵉⵜ, ⴷ ⵉⵎⴽ ⵉⵜⵜⵓⵙⵙⴼⵔⴰ ⴷⴷⴰⵡ ⴰⵙ, ⵜⴱⴱⵓⵖⵍⴰ ⴽⵓ ⵢⵓⵡⵜ ⵙ ⵡⴰⵎⵎⴰⴽ ⵏⵏⵙ ⵉⵎⵥⵍⵉ ⴳ ⵓⵔⵣⵣⵓ.

source_sentence: They called their work by several names: e.g. embodied, situated, behavior-based or developmental.
target_sentence: ⴳⴰⵏ ⵉ ⵜⵡⵓⵔⵉ ⵏⵏⵙⵏ ⴽⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵢⵉⵙⵎⴰⵡⵏ: ⵣⵓⵏⴷ, ⵜⴰⵎⵙⴽⴰⵔⵜ, ⵏⵖⴷ ⵜⴰⵎⵙⵖⴰⵔⴰ, ⵏⵖⴷ ⵜⵍⵍⴰ ⵖⴼ ⵜⵉⴽⵍⵉ, ⵏⵖⴷ ⵜⴰⵏⴼⵍⵉⵜ.

source_sentence: The shared mathematical language permitted a high level of collaboration with more established fields (like mathematics, economics or operations research).
target_sentence: ⵜⵓⴷⵊⴰ ⵜⵓⵜⵍⴰⵢⵜ ⵏ ⵜⵓⵙⵏⴰⴽⵜ ⵉⵛⵛⴰⵔⵏ ⵙ ⵓⵙⵡⵉⵔ ⵢⴰⵜⵜⵓⵢⵏ ⵉ ⵓⵎⵢⵉⵡⴰⵙ ⴰⴽⴷ ⵢⵉⴳⵔⴰⵏ ⵡⴰⵍⴰ ⵉⵜⵜⵎⵔⴰⵏ (ⴰⵎⵎ ⵜⵓⵙⵏⴰⴽⵜ ⵏⵖⴷ ⵜⴰⴷⴰⵎⵙⴰ ⵏⵖⴷ ⵉⵔⵣⵣⵓⵜⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵉⴳⴳⵉⵜⵉⵏ).

source_sentence: Nowadays results of experiments are often rigorously measurable, and are sometimes (with difficulty) reproducible.
target_sentence: ⴳ ⵜⵉⵣⵉ ⴰⴷ, ⴷⴰ ⵡⴰⵍⴰ ⵜⵜⵉⵍⵉⵏⵜ ⵜⵢⴰⴼⵓⵜⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵢⵉⵔⵎⴰⵡⵏ ⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵡⵉⵏ ⵓⵙⵖⴰⵍ ⵙ ⵜⵓⵏⵖⵉⴷⵜ, ⴷ ⵉⵜⵙⵏⵜ ⵜⵉⴽⴽⴰⵍ ( ⵙ ⵛⵇⵇⵉⵢⵜ) ⵜⴳⴰ ⵜⵉⵏ ⵡⴰⵍⵍⴰⵙ.

source_sentence: "These algorithms proved to be insufficient for solving large reasoning problems because they experienced a ""combinatorial explosion"": they became exponentially slower as the problems grew larger."
target_sentence: “ⵙⵓⵔⴰⵏⵜ ⵍⵓⴳⴰⵔⵉⵜⵎⴰⵜ ⵉⵙ ⵓⵔ ⴳⵉⵏⵜ ⵉ ⵓⴼⵙⵙⴰⵢ ⵏ ⵉⵎⵓⴽⵔⵉⵙⵏ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵡⵉⵏⴳⵎ ⴰⵅⴰⵜⴰⵔ, ⴰⵛⴽⵓ ⵎⵔⵔⵜⵏⵜ ⵙ “ⵓⵟⵟⵉⵇⵙ ⴰⵎⵙⵙⵉⴷⴼ”, ⴷ ⵜⴰⵖⵓⵍ ⵜⵥⵥⴰⵢ ⴽⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⴳⴳⴰⴷⵉⵏⵜ ⴰⵙ ⵜⵎⵓⴽⵔⵉⵙⵉⵏ.”

source_sentence: Among the things a comprehensive commonsense knowledge base would contain are: objects, properties, categories and relations between objects; situations, events, states and time; causes and effects; knowledge about knowledge (what we know about what other people know); and many other, less well researched domains.
target_sentence: ⵉⵏⴳⵔ ⵜⵖⴰⵡⵙⵉⵡⵉⵏ ⵏⵏⴰ ⵜⵖⵉⵢ ⴰⴷ ⵜⴰⵎⵥ ⵜⵍⴳⴰⵎⵜ ⵏ ⵜⵓⵙⵙⵏⴰ ⵜⴰⵖⵣⵓⵔⴰⵏⵜ ⵜⵓⵎⴳⵉⵏⵜ: ⵜⵉⵖⴰⵡⵙⵉⵡⵉⵏ, ⴷ ⵉⵎⵥⵍⴰⵢⵏ, ⴷ ⵜⴳⵔⵔⵓⵎⴰ, ⴷ ⵜⵣⴷⴰⵢⵉⵏ ⴳⵔ ⵜⵖⴰⵡⵙⵉⵡⵉⵏ; ⴷ ⵡⴰⴷⴷⴰⴷⵏ, ⴷ ⵉⵎⵣⵣⵓⵜⵏ ⴷ ⵡⴰⴷⴷⴰⴷⵏ ⴷ ⵜⵉⵣⵉ, ⴷ ⵉⵙⵔⴰⴳⵏ ⴷ ⵜⵎⵉⵜⴰⵔ, ⵜⵓⵙⵙⵏⴰ ⵙ ⵜⵓⵙⵙⵏⴰ ( ⵎⴰⵢⴷ ⵏⵙⵙⴻⵏ ⴷ ⵎⴰⵢⴷ ⵙⵙⵏⴻⵏ ⵡⵉⵢⵢⴰⴹ), ⴷ ⴽⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵢⵉⴳⵔⴰⵏ ⵢⴰⴹⵏ ⴳ ⵉⴷⵔⵓⵙ ⵓⵙⵏⵓⴱⴱⵛ.

source_sentence: For example, if a bird comes up in conversation, people typically picture a fist-sized animal that sings and flies.
target_sentence: ⵙ ⵓⵎⴷⵢⴰ, ⵉⴳ ⴷ ⵉⴱⴰⵢⵏ ⵓⴳⴹⵉⴹ ⴳ ⵜⵙⵎⵏⴰⵡⴰⵍⵜ, ⴷⴰ ⵙⵡⵉⵏⴳⵉⵎⵏ ⵎⴷⴷⵏ ⴳ ⵓⵎⵓⴷⵔ ⵙ ⵓⴽⵙⴰⵢ ⵏ ⵜⵓⵎⵎⵉⵥⵜ ⴰⵔ ⵉⵜⵜⵉⵔⵉⵔ ⴰⵔ ⵉⵜⵜⴰⵢⵍⴰⵍ.

source_sentence: Almost nothing is simply true or false in the way that abstract logic requires.
target_sentence: ⴰⵡⴷ ⵎⴰⵄⵍⵎ ⵉⴳⴰ ⴰⵎⴷⴷⴰⴷ ⵓⵍⴰ ⵉⵣⴳⵍ ⵙ ⵜⴱⵔⵉⴷⵜ ⵏⵏⴰ ⴷⴰ ⵉⵜⵜⴻⵜⵔ ⵡⵓⵎⴳⵉⵏ ⴰⵡⵏⴳⵉⵎ.

source_sentence: Research projects that attempt to build a complete knowledge base of commonsense knowledge (e.g., Cyc) require enormous amounts of laborious ontological engineering—they must be built, by hand, one complicated concept at a time.
target_sentence: ⴷⴰ ⵜⴻⵜⵜⵔⵏ ⵉⵙⵏⴼⴰⵔⵏ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵏⵓⴱⴱⵛ ⵏⵏⴰ ⴷⴰ ⵉⵜⵏⴰⵖⵏ ⴰⴷ ⵙⴽⵓⵏ ⵜⴰⵍⴳⴰⵎⵜ ⵏ ⵜⵓⵙⵙⵏⴰ ⵉⵙⵎⴰⵏ ⵜⵓⵙⵙⵏⴰ ⵜⵓⵎⴳⵉⵏⵜ ( ⵙ ⵓⵎⴷⵢⴰ Cyc), ⴽⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵉⴳⵓⴷⵉⵢⵏ ⵏ ⵓⵜⵡⴰⵍ ⴰⵏⵟⵓⵍⵓⵊⵉⵢ ⵉⵎⵔⴰⵏ - ⵉⵇⵏⴻⵏ ⵓⵙⴽⴰⵏ ⵏⵏⵙ ⵙ ⵓⴼⵓⵙ, ⵙ ⵢⴰⵏ ⵓⵙⵉⵙⵙⵏ ⵉⵔⵡⵉⵏ ⴽⵓ ⵜⵉⴽⵍⵜ.

source_sentence: "They need a way to visualize the future—a representation of the state of the world and be able to make predictions about how their actions will change it—and be able to make choices that maximize the utility (or ""value"") of available choices."
target_sentence: “ⵜⵅⵚⵚⴰⵜⵏ ⵢⴰⵜ ⵜⴱⵔⵉⴷⵜ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵏⵓⵎⵎⵍ ⵏ ⵉⵎⴰⵍ - ⴰⵙⵎⴷⵢⴰ ⵏ ⵡⴰⴷⴷⴰⴷ ⵏ ⵓⵎⴰⴹⴰⵍ ⴷ ⵜⵉⵖⵉⵢⵜ ⵏ ⵜⵉⴳⵉⵜ ⵏ ⵉⵙⵡⵉⴳⵎⵏ ⵙ ⵎⴰⵎⵏⴽ ⵙ ⵔⴰⴷ ⵙⵏⴼⵍⵏ ⵉⴳⴳⵉⵜⵏ ⵏⵏⵙⵏ ⵣⴰⵕⵙ - ⴷ ⵜⵉⵖⵉⵢⵜ ⴰⴷ ⴰⵙⵉⵏ ⵉⵙⵜⴰⵢⵏ ⵉⵜⵜⵔⵏⵓⵏ ⵜⴰⴱⵖⵙⵜ (ⵏⵖⴷ ⴰⵜⵉⴳ), ⵙⴳ ⵉⵙⵜⴰⵢⵏ ⵉⵍⵍⴰⵏ.”

source_sentence: This calls for an agent that can not only assess its environment and make predictions but also evaluate its predictions and adapt based on its assessment.
target_sentence: ⴰⵢⴰ ⵉⵔⴰ ⵜⵉⵍⵉⵜ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵎⴰⴳⴰⵍ ⵓⵔ ⵉⵏⵏⵉⵏ ⴰⴷ ⵉⴳ ⴰⵙⵜⴰⵍ ⵉ ⵜⵡⵏⵏⴰⴹⵜ ⵏⵏⵙ ⴷⴰⵢ, ⴷ ⵉⵙⴽⵔ ⴰⵙⵏⵉⵎⴰⵍ, ⵎⴰⴽⴰ ⴰⵡⴷ ⴰⵙⵜⴰⵍ ⵉ ⵓⵙⵏⵉⵎⴰⵍ ⵏⵏⵙ ⴷ ⵉⴱⴷⴷⵉ ⵖⴼ ⵓⵙⵜⴰⵍ ⵏⵏⵙ.

source_sentence: Classification is used to determine what category something belongs in, and occurs after a program sees a number of examples of things from several categories.
target_sentence: ⴷⴰ ⵜⵜⵓⵙⵎⵔⴰⵙ ⵜⵙⵏⴰⵡⴰⵢⵜ ⵎⴰⵔ ⴰⴷ ⵜⵥⵍⵉ ⵜⴰⴳⵔⵔⵓⵎⴰ ⵏⵏⴰ ⴳ ⵉⵍⵍⴰ ⴽⴰ ⴰⴽⴽⵯ ⵎⵉ, ⴰⵔ ⵉⵜⵊⵕⵓ ⴷⴰⵕⵜ ⴰⴷ ⵢⴰⵏⵏⴰⵢ ⵓⵖⴰⵡⴰⵙ ⴽⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵎⴷⵢⴰⵜⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵖⴰⵡⵙⵉⵡⵉⵏ ⵙⴳ ⴽⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵜⴳⵔⵔⵓⵎⴰ.

source_sentence: Computational learning theory can assess learners by computational complexity, by sample complexity (how much data is required), or by other notions of optimization.

source_sentence: The time has come for adding an ethical dimension to at least some machines.
target_sentence: ⵜⴳⵓⵍⴰⴷ ⵜⵉⵣⵉ ⵏ ⵜⵎⵔⵏⴰⵡⵜ ⵏ ⵓⵣⴰⵔⵓ ⴰⵖⴰⵔⴰⵏ, ⵉ ⵉⵜⵙⵏ ⵉⵎⴰⵙⵙⵏ ⴱⵄⴷⴰ.

source_sentence: Research in machine ethics is key to alleviating concerns with autonomous systems—it could be argued that the notion of autonomous machines without such a dimension is at the root of all fear concerning machine intelligence.
target_sentence: ⴰⵔⵣⵣⵓ ⴳ ⵜⵖⴰⵔⵉⵡⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵎⵉⵙ ⵉⴳⴰ: ⵜⴰⵙⴰⵔⵓⵜ ⵏ ⵓⵙⴼⵙⵉⵙ ⵏ ⵜⴽⵙⵙⴰⴹ ⴳ ⵎⴰⵢⴷ ⵉⵥⵍⵉⵏ ⵙ ⵉⴳⵔⵔⴰⵢⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵎⴰⵍ - ⵏⵖ ⴰⴷ ⵏⵉⵏⵉ ⵎⴰⵙⴷ ⵜⴰⵡⵏⴳⵉⵎⵜ ⵏ ⵉⵎⴰⵙⵙⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵎⴰⵍ ⴱⵍⴰ ⵣⵓⵏⴷ ⴰⵣⴰⵔⵓ ⴰⴷ, ⴰⵛⴽⵓ ⵏⵜⵜⴰⵜ ⴷ ⴰⵥⵓⵕ ⵏ ⵜⴽⵙⵙⴰⴹ ⵉⵍⵍⴰⵏ ⵖⴼ ⵛⵛⵡⵉⵢⵜ ⵏ ⵉⵎⵉⵙ.

source_sentence: Humans should not assume machines or robots would treat us favorably because there is no a priori reason to believe that they would be sympathetic to our system of morality, which has evolved along with our particular biology (which AIs would not share).
target_sentence: ⵉⵅⵙⵙⴰ ⴰⴷ ⵓⵔ ⴽⴰ ⵙⴰⵡⴰⵍⵏ ⵎⵉⴷⴷⵏ ⵖⴼ ⵉⵎⴰⵙⵙⵏ, ⵏⵖⴷ ⵔⵓⴱⵓⵜⴰⵜ ⵀⴰⵜ ⵇⴰⴷ ⵉⴷⵏⵖ ⵜⵎⵢⴰⵡⴰⴹ ⵙ ⵜⴰⵍⵖⴰ ⵜⵓⵎⵏⵉⴳⵜ, ⴰⵛⴽⵓ ⵓⵔ ⵉⵍⵍⵉ ⴰⵡⴷⵢⴰⵏ ⵓⵡⵜⵜⴰⵙ ⵙ ⵔⴰⴷ ⵎⵙⴰⵙⴰⵏ ⴰⴽⴷ ⵓⵏⴳⵔⴰⵡ ⴰⵖⴰⵔⴰⵏ ⵏⵏⵖ, ⵏⵏⴰ ⵉⵜⵜⵓⵙⴱⵓⵖⵍⵍⴰⵏ ⵢⴰⵏ ⵜⴰⵎⴰ ⵏ ⵢⴰⵏ ⴰⴽⴷ ⵜⴰⵡⵙⵙⵏⵜⵓⴷⵔⵜ ⵣⴰⵕⵏⵖ ⵉⵥⵍⵉⵏ ( ⵏⵏⴰ ⵙ ⵓⵔ ⵜⵏⵏⵉ ⴰⴷ ⵓⵛⵓⵔⵏ ⵉⴳⵔⵔⴰⵢⵏ ⵏ ⵛⵛⵡⵉⵢⵜ ⴰⵎⴳⵓⵔⴰⵏ).

source_sentence: One proposal to deal with this is to ensure that the first generally intelligent AI is 'Friendly AI' and will be able to control subsequently developed AIs.
target_sentence: ⵉⵜⵙⵏ ⵉⵙⵓⵎⵔⵏ ⵎⴰⵔ ⴰⴷ ⵜⵙⵡⵓⵔⵉⴷ ⴰⴽⴷ ⵓⵢⴰ; ⴰⵙⵍⴽⵏ ⵏ ⵡⵉⵙ ⴷ ⵛⵡⵡⵉⵢⵜ ⵜⴰⵎⴳⵓⵔⴰⵏⵜ ⵉⵣⵡⴰⵔⵏ, ⵉⵛⵡⴰ ⵙ ⵓⵎⴰⵜⴰ ⵉⴳⴰⵜ ⵛⵛⵡⵉⵢⵜ ⵜⴰⵎⴳⵓⵔⴰⵏⵜ ⴰⵎⴷⴷⴰⴽⵯⵍ, ⴷ ⵇⴰⴷ ⵢⵉⵖⵉⵢ ⴰⴷ ⵉⵏⵏⴱⴹ ⴳ ⵉⴳⵔⵔⴰⵢⵏ ⵏ ⵛⵛⵡⵉⵢⵜ ⵜⴰⵎⴳⵓⵔⴰⵏⵜ ⵉⵜⵜⵓⵙⴱⵓⵖⵍⵍⴰⵏ ⴹⴰⵕⵜ ⵓⵢⵏⵏⴰⵖ.

source_sentence: Biotechnology is a broad area of biology, involving the use of living systems and organisms to develop or make products.
target_sentence: ⴱⵢⵓ-ⵜⵉⴽⵏⵓⵍⵓⵊⵉⵜ ⵜⴳⴰ ⵢⴰⵏ ⵢⵉⴳⵔ ⴰⵎⵉⵔⴰⵡ ⵏ ⴱⵉⵢⵓⵍⵓⵊⵉ, ⵉⵙⵎⴰⵏ ⴰⵙⵙⵎⵔⵙ ⵏ ⵉⵙⵏⵎⴰⵍⵍⴰⵜⵏ ⴷ ⵉⵎⵉⴷⵔⵏ ⵉ ⵓⵙⴱⵓⵖⵍⵓ ⵏⵖⴷ ⴰⵙⴽⴰⵔ ⵏ ⵜⵖⴰⵡⵙⵉⵡⵉⵏ.

source_sentence: The American Chemical Society defines biotechnology as the application of biological organisms, systems, or processes by various industries to learning about the science of life and the improvement of the value of materials and organisms such as pharmaceuticals, crops, and livestock.
target_sentence: ⵜⵙⵙⵉⵙⵉⵏ ⵜⵎⵙⵎⵓⵏⵜ ⵜⴰⴽⵉⵎⵉⵢⵜ ⵏ ⵎⵉⵔⵉⴽⴰⵏ, ⵜⴰⵜⵉⴽⵏⵓⵍⵓⵊⵉⵜ ⵜⴰⵖⴰⵔⴰⵏⵜ ⵙ ⵓⵙⴽⴽⵉⵔ ⵏ ⵉⵎⵖⵏⴰⵡⵏ ⵉⴷⴷⵔⵏ, ⵏⵖⴷ ⵉⵎⴰⴳⴰⵡⵏ ⵏⵖⴷ ⵜⵉⵎⴳⴳⵉⵜⵉⵏ ⵙⴳ ⵉⵎⴳⵓⵔⴰⵏⴻⵏ ⵓⵔ ⵢⴰⴽⵙⵓⵍⵏ ⵉ ⵓⵙⵉⵙⵙⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵓⵎⴰⵙⵙⴰⵏⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵓⴷⵔⵜ ⴷ ⵓⵙⵖⵓⴷⵓ ⵏ ⵡⴰⵜⵉⴳ ⵏ ⵜⴰⵏⴳⵉⵡⵉⵏ ⴷ ⵉⵎⵖⵏⴰⵏ ⵣⵓⵏⴷ ⵉⵙⴰⴼⴰⵔⵏ ⴷ ⵢⵉⵙⵉⵜⵏ ⴷ ⵓⵢⴷⴷⴰ ⴰⵎⵓⴷⵔ.

source_sentence: Bioengineering is the application of the principles of engineering and natural sciences to tissues, cells and molecules.
target_sentence: ⴰⵜⵡⴰⵍ ⴰⵥⵓⵕⴰⵏ ⵜⴳⴰ ⴰⵙⵙⵎⵔⵙ ⵏ ⵉⵎⵏⵣⴰⵢⵏ ⵏ ⵓⵜⵡⴰⵍ ⴷ ⵜⵎⴰⵙⵙⴰⵏⵉⵏ ⵜⵉⵖⴰⵔⴰⵏⵉⵏ ⴳ ⵉⵣⵟⵟⴰⵜⵏ ⴷ ⵜⵉⵍⵎⵉⴽⵜ ⴷ ⵡⴰⵙⵉⵙⵏ.

source_sentence: Through early biotechnology, the earliest farmers selected and bred the best-suited crops, having the highest yields, to produce enough food to support a growing population.
target_sentence: ⵙⴳ ⴱⵉⵄⵜⵉⴽⵏⵓⵍⵓⵊⵉⵜ ⵏ ⵣⵉⴽ, ⵙⴽⵔⵏ ⵉⵎⴽⵔⴰⵣⵏ ⵉⵎⵣⵡⵓⵔⴰ ⴰⵙⵜⴰⵢ ⴷ ⵓⵙⵙⴳⵎ ⵏ ⵢⵉⵙⵉⵢⵏ ⴷ ⵢⵓⵙⴰⵏ, ⵏⵏⴰ ⵉⵍⴰⵏ ⴰⵙⵏⴼⵍⵓⵍ ⵉⴳⴳⵓⴷⵉⵏ, ⵎⴰⵔ ⴰⴷ ⴰⵖⴷ ⴽⵉⵏ ⴰⵢⵏⵏⴰ ⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵡⵓⵜⵛⵉ ⵎⴰⵔ ⴰⴷ ⵏⴰⵡⵙ ⴽⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵎⴷⴷⵏ.

source_sentence: In this process, carbohydrates in the grains broke down into alcohols, such as ethanol.

source_sentence: Although the process of fermentation was not fully understood until Louis Pasteur's work in 1857, it is still the first use of biotechnology to convert a food source into another form.
target_sentence: ⵡⴰⵅⵅⴰ ⵓⵔ ⵡⴰⵍⴰ ⵜⵜⵓⵔⵎⴰⵙ ⵜⵎⴳⴳⵉⵜ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵙⵅⵎⵕ ⴰⵔ ⵜⴰⵡⵓⵔⵉ ⵏ ⵍⵡⵉⵙ ⴱⴰⵙⵜⵓⵔ ⴳ ⵓⵙⴳⴳⵯⴰⵙ ⵏ 1857, ⵎⴰⴽⴰ ⵜⵙⵓⵍ ⵜⴳⴰ ⴰⵙⵙⵎⵔⵙ ⴰⵎⵣⵡⴰⵔⵓ ⵏ ⴱⵢⵓ-ⵜⵉⴽⵏⵓⵍⵓⵊⵉⵜ ⵉⵙⵏⴼⵍⴰⵍⵏ ⴰⵙⴰⴳⵯⵎ ⵏ ⵡⵓⵜⵛⵉ ⵖⵔ ⵜⴰⵍⵖⴰ ⵏⵏⵉⴹⵏ.

source_sentence: The MOSFET (metal-oxide-semiconductor field-effect transistor) was invented by Mohamed M. Atalla and Dawon Kahng in 1959.
target_sentence: ⵉⵜⵜⵓⵙⵏⴼⵍⴻⵍ MOSFET (ⵜⵔⴰⵏⵣⵉⵙⵜⵓⵔ ⵏ ⵓⵏⵏⵓⴹⵙ ⴰⴱⴰⵔⴰⵣ ⵏ ⵓⴽⵙⵉⴷ ⵏ ⵉⵣⵓⵖⴰⵔ ⴷ ⵉⵎⵢⴰⵖⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵎⵢⴰⵡⴰⴹⵉⵏ), ⵖⵓⵔ ⵎⵓⵃⵎⵎⴰⴷ ⵎ, ⵄⴰⵟⴰ ⵍⵍⴰⵀ, ⴷ ⴷⴰⵡⵏ ⴽⴰⵏⵊ ⴳ ⵓⵙⴳⴳⵯⴰⵙ ⵏ 1959.

source_sentence: The first BioFET was the ion-sensitive field-effect transistor (ISFET), invented by Piet Bergveld in 1970.
target_sentence: BioFET ⴰⵎⵣⵡⴰⵔⵓ ⵉⴳⴰⵜ ⵜⵔⴰⵏⵣⵉⵙⵜⵓⵔ ⴱⵓ ⵡⵓⵏⵓⴹ ⴰⴱⴰⵔⴰⵣ, ⵉⵎⵣⵔⵉⵏ ⴰⵢⵓⵏⴰⵜ (ISFET), ⵏⵏⴰ ⵉⵙⵏⴼⵍⴻⵍ ⴱⵉⵢ ⴱⵉⵔⴼⵉⵍⴷ ⴳ ⵓⵙⴳⴳⵯⴰⵙ ⵏ 1970.

source_sentence: By the mid-1980s, other BioFETs had been developed, including the gas sensor FET (GASFET), pressure sensor FET (PRESSFET), chemical field-effect transistor (ChemFET), reference ISFET (REFET), enzyme-modified FET (ENFET) and immunologically modified FET (IMFET).

source_sentence: She was cloned at the Roslin Institute in Scotland by British scientists Sir Ian Wilmut and Keith Campbell and lived there from her birth in 1996 until her death in 2003 when she was six.

source_sentence: Dolly was publicly significant because the effort showed that genetic material from a specific adult cell, designed to express only a distinct subset of its genes, can be redesigned to grow an entirely new organism.

source_sentence: The first mammalian cloning (resulting in Dolly the sheep) had a success rate of 29 embryos per 277 fertilized eggs, which produced three lambs at birth, one of which lived.

source_sentence: "In the futuristic novel Cloud Atlas and subsequent film, one of the story lines focuses on a genetically-engineered fabricant clone named Sonmi~451, one of millions raised in an artificial ""wombtank"", destined to serve from birth."

source_sentence: In the film Us, at some point prior to the 1980s, the US Government creates clones of every citizen of the United States with the intention of using them to control their original counterparts, akin to voodoo dolls.

source_sentence: Genes have been transferred within the same species, across species (creating transgenic organisms), and even across kingdoms.

source_sentence: The first genetically modified animal to be commercialized was the GloFish (2003) and the first genetically modified animal to be approved for food use was the AquAdvantage salmon in 2015.

source_sentence: Animals are generally much harder to transform and the vast majority are still at the research stage.

source_sentence: Livestock is modified with the intention of improving economically important traits such as growth rate, quality of meat, milk composition, disease resistance, and survival.

source_sentence: Although human gene therapy is still relatively new, it has been used to treat genetic disorders such as severe combined immunodeficiency, and Leber's congenital amaurosis.
target_sentence: ⵡⵅⵅⴰ ⴷ ⵉⵙⵓⵍ ⴷ ⴰⵙⵓⵊⵊⵉ ⴰⵊⵉⵏⵉⵢ ⵏ ⵓⴼⴳⴰⵏ ⵉⵙⵓⵍ ⴷ ⴰⵎⴰⵢⵏⵓ ⴷⵓⵔⵖ ⴷⴷ, ⵉⵜⵜⵓⵙⵎⵔⴰⵙ ⴷ ⴰⵙⵓⵊⵊⵉ ⵏ ⵉⵎⵎⵔⵡⴰⵢⵏ ⵉⵊⵉⵏⵉⵢⵏ ⵣⵓⵏ ⴷ ⵜⴰⴷⵔⵙⵉ ⵏ ⵡⴰⴼⴼⴰⵍ ⵜⴰⵎⵛⵛⴰⵔⵜ ⵢⵓⵙⵙⴰⵏ, ⴷ ⵓⴽⵎⵎⵓⴹ ⵏ ⵜⵙⴳⴳⵉⵏ ⵜⵓⵙⴽⵉⵔⵉⵏ ⴰⵎⵓⵔⵓⵙⵉⵙ.

source_sentence: Other concerns are the objectivity and rigor of regulatory authorities, contamination of non-genetically modified food, control of the food supply, patenting of life and the use of intellectual property rights.
target_sentence: ⵙⴳ ⵉⵙⵏⴰⵜⵍⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵡⵓⵔⵉ ⵢⴰⴹⵏ ⵓⵇⵊⵉⵔⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵏⴱⴰⴹⵉⵏ ⵜⵉⵎⵙⵙⵓⴷⵙⵉⵏ, ⴷ ⵡⵓⵍⵓⴼ ⵏ ⵡⵓⵜⵛⵉ ⵓⵔ ⵉⵜⵜⵓⵏⴼⴰⵍⵏ ⵙ ⵓⴽⵙⵓⵢ, ⴷ ⵓⵏⵎⴰⵜⵔ ⵏ ⵉⵙⵓⴳⴰⵎ ⵏ ⵡⵓⵜⵛⵉ, ⴷ ⵓⵣⵎⵎⴻⵎ ⵜⴰⵙⵎⵍⴰ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵙⵖⵏⴰ ⵏ ⵜⵓⴷⵔⵜ, ⴷ ⵓⵙⵎⵔⵙ ⵏ ⵉⵣⵔⴼⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵉⵍⵉⵜ ⵜⴰⵡⵏⴳⵉⵎⵜ.

source_sentence: Countries have adopted regulatory measures to deal with these concerns.

source_sentence: "A broad definition of genetic engineering also includes selective breeding and other means of artificial selection."","
target_sentence: ⵢⴰⵎⵓ ⴳ ⵓⵙⵏⵎⵍ ⴰⴱⴰⵔⴰⵡ ⵏ ⵜⵏⵣⴳⵉⵜ ⵜⵓⴽⵙⴰⵢⵜ ⴰⵍⵜⵓ ⴰⵏⵏⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵜⴰⵢ ⴷ ⵡⵓⴳⴳⴰⵔ ⵏ ⵉⵎⴰⵙⵙⵏ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵜⴰⵢ ⴰⵎⵓⴳⵔⵉ.,"

source_sentence: For example, the grain crop triticale was fully developed in a laboratory in 1930 using various techniques to alter its genome.
target_sentence: ⵙ ⵓⵎⴷⵢⴰ, ⵉⵜⵜⵓⴳⵎⴰ ⵜⵔⵉⵜⵉⴽⴰⵍ ⵏ ⵢⵉⴳⵔⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵎⵏⴷⵉ ⵙ ⵓⵎⴰⵜⴰ ⴳ ⵓⵙⴰⵔⴰⵎ ⴳ ⵓⵙⴳⴳⵯⴰⵙ ⵏ 1930 ⵙ ⵓⵙⵎⵔⵙ ⵏ ⵜⵜⵇⵏⵉⵢⵉⵏ ⵉⵏⴳⴰⵔⴰⵏ ⵉ ⵓⵙⵏⴼⵍ ⵏ ⵍⵊⵉⵏⴰⵜ ⵏⵏⵙ.

source_sentence: "Modern biotechnology is further defined as ""In vitro nucleic acid techniques, including recombinant deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) and direct injection of nucleic acid into cells or organelles, or fusion of cells beyond the taxonomic family."""
target_sentence: ⵜⴰⴱⵢⵓⵜⵉⴽⵏⵓⵍⵓⵊⵉⵢⵜ ⵜⴰⵜⵔⴰⵔⵜ ⵜⴻⵜⵜⵡⴰⵙⵙⵏ ⴰⵍⵜⵓ ⴱⵍⵍⵉ ⵎⴰⵙ ⴷ ⴳ ⵜⵜⵇⵏⵉⵢⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵖⵢⴰⵢⵏ ⵉⵙⵎⵎⴰⵎⵏ ⴼⵉⵜⵔⵓ, ⴳ ⵢⴰⵎⵓ ⵓⵙⵎⵎⴰⵎ ⴷⵢⵓⴽⵙⵉⵔⵉⴱⵓⵏⵓⵢⵉⴽ (ⴰⵖⵢⴰⵢ ⴰⵙⵎⵎⴰⵎ ⵔⵔⵉⴱⵓⵣⵉ ⴰⵎⴷⵔⵓⵙ ⵏ ⵍⵓⴽⵙⵉⵊⵉⵏ) ⴷ ⵜⴳⵣⵣⴰⵢⵜ ⵜⵓⵙⵔⵉⴷⵜ ⵏ ⵉⵙⵎⵎⴰⵎⵏ ⵉⵖⵢⴰⵢⵏ ⴳ ⵜⵖⵔⴰⵙⵉⵏ ⵏⵖ ⴳ ⵉⵔⵉⵙⵏ, ⵏⵖ ⴰⵙⵉⴷⴼ ⵏ ⵜⵖⵔⴰⵙⵉⵏ ⴱⵕⵕⴰ ⵏ ⵜⵎⵏⴰⴹⵜ ⵏ ⵜⴰⵡⵊⴰ ⵜⴰⵙⵏⴰⵡⴰⵢⵜ.""

source_sentence: The definitions focus on the process more than the product, which means there could be GMOS and non-GMOs with very similar genotypes and phenotypes.
target_sentence: ⴱⴷⴷⴰⵏ ⵉⵙⵏⵎⵍⵏ ⵅⴼ ⵜⵉⵔⵎⵉⵜ ⵓⴳⴳⴰⵔ ⵏ ⵜⵢⴰⴼⵓⵜ, ⴰⵢⵏⵏⴰ ⵉⵙⵏⴰⵎⴽⴰⵏ ⵎⴰⵙ ⴷ ⵉⵥⴹⴰⵕ ⴰⴷ ⵢⵉⵍⵉ GMOS ⴷ ⵡⴰⵔ-GMOS ⴰⴽⴷ ⵡⴰⵔ ⴰⵎⵓⵙⵙⵓ ⵖⵔ ⵉⵍⵍⴰ ⵓⵎⴷⵢⴰ ⵏ ⵜⵊⵉⵏⵉⵢⵜ ⴷ ⵉⵎⴷⵢⴰⵜⵏ ⵏ ⵉⴼⵉⵣⵢⴰⵢⵉⵏ ⵉⵔⵎⵢⴰⵖⵏ ⴰⴽⴽⵯ.

source_sentence: It also poses problems as new processes are developed.
target_sentence: ⴰⵔ ⵢⴰⴽⴽⴰ ⴰⵍⵜⵓ ⵜⵉⵎⴽⵔⵉⵙⵉⵏ ⴷ ⵓⵣⵣⵉⴳⵣ ⵏ ⵜⵔⵎⵉⵜⵉⵏ ⵜⵉⵎⴰⵢⵏⵓⵜⵉⵏ.

source_sentence: Genetic engineers must isolate the gene they wish to insert into the host organism.
target_sentence: ⵉⵎⵜⵡⴰⵍⵏ ⵉⵏⵎⴽⵓⵙⴰⵢⵏ ⵉⵇⵇⴰⵏ ⴷ ⴰⴷ ⵥⵍⵉⵏ ⴰⵊⵉⵏⵉⵢ ⵏⴰ ⵔⴰⵏ ⴰⴷ ⵙⵙⵉⴷⴼⵏ ⵖⵔ ⵓⵎⴷⴷⴰⵔ ⵉⴷⴷⵔⵏ.

source_sentence: The gene is then combined with other genetic elements, including a promoter and terminator region and a selectable marker.
target_sentence: ⴰⵔ ⵉⵜⵜⵓⵙⵎⵓⵏ ⵏⴳⵔ ⵓⵊⵉⵏⵉⵢ ⴷ ⵉⴼⵔⴷⵉⵙⵏ ⵉⵎⴽⵙⴰⵢ ⵢⴰⴹⵏ, ⴳ ⵜⴰⵎⵓ ⵜⵎⵏⴰⴹⵜ ⵉⵙⵙⵓⴷⵙⵏ ⴷ ⵜⴳⵙⵔⵉ ⴷ ⵜⵎⴰⵜⴰⵔⵜ ⵉⵍⴰⵇⵏ ⵉ ⵓⵙⵜⴰⵢ.

source_sentence: DNA is generally inserted into animal cells using microinjection, where it can be injected through the cell's nuclear envelope directly into the nucleus, or through the use of viral vectors.
target_sentence: ⵉⵜⵜⵓⵙⴰⴷⴼ ⵓⵙⵎⵎⴰⵎ ⴰⵖⵢⴰⵢ ⵙ ⵓⵎⴰⵜⴰ ⴳ ⵜⵖⵔⴰⵙⵉⵏ ⵜⵉⵎⵓⴷⴰⵔⵉⵏ ⵙ ⵓⵙⵎⵔⵙ ⵏ ⵓⵉⵎⴽⵕⵓⴳⵣⴰⵢ, ⴰⵛⴽⵓ ⵉⵥⴹⴰⵕ ⴰⴷ ⵜⵜⵓⴳⵣⴰⵢ ⵙⴳ ⵓⵜⵜⵍ ⵏ ⴰⵖⵢⴰⵢ ⵏ ⵜⵖⵔⴰⵙⵜ ⵙ ⵡⵓⵙⵔⵉⴷ ⴳ ⵜⵖⵢⴰⵢⵜ, ⵏⵖ ⵙⴳ ⵓⵙⵎⵔⵙ ⵉⵙⵎⴰⵜⵜⴰⵢⵏ ⵏ ⵉⴼⵉⵔⵓⵙⵏ.

source_sentence: In plants this is accomplished through tissue culture.
target_sentence: ⴳ ⵉⵎⵖⴰⵢⵏ ⴰⵔ ⵉⵜⵜⵉⵍⵉ ⵎⴰⵢⴰⵏ ⵙ ⵜⴽⵔⵣⴰ ⵏ ⵉⴼⵙⴰⵏ.

source_sentence: Traditionally the new genetic material was inserted randomly within the host genome.
target_sentence: ⵙ ⵜⴱⵔⵉⴷⵜ ⵜⴰⵇⵇⴱⵓⵔⵜ ⵜⵜⵓⵙⴽⵛⴰⵎ ⵜⵎⵜⵜⴰ ⵜⴰⵎⴽⴽⴰⵙⵓⵜ ⵜⴰⵎⴰⵢⵏⵓⵜ ⵙ ⵡⴰⵔⴰⵍⵓⴳⵏ ⵊⴰⵊ ⵏ ⵓⵊⵉⵏⵓⵎ ⴰⵎⵔⴰⵏⴰⵢ.

source_sentence: There are four families of engineered nucleases: meganucleases, zinc finger nucleases, transcription activator-like effector nucleases (TALENs), and the Cas9-guideRNA system (adapted from CRISPR).
target_sentence: ⵍⵍⴰⵏ ⴽⴽⵓⵥ ⵏ ⵜⴰⵡⵊⵉⵡⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵖⵢⴰⵢⵉⵏ ⵉⵜⵜⵓⵎⴰⵎⴽⵏ ⵙ ⵜⵏⵣⴳⵉⵜ: ⵜⵉⵖⵢⴰⵢ ⵏ ⵥⵥⵏⴽ, ⵜⵉⵖⵢⴰⵢ ⵏ ⵉⴹⵓⴷⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵥⵣⵏⴽ, ⵜⵉⵖⵢⴰⵢ ⵜⵉⵏⵎⴰⵙⵙⵉⵏ ⵉⵔⵡⴰⵙⵏ ⴰⵙⵖⵉⵍ (TALENs), ⴷ ⵓⵏⴳⵔⴰⵡ Cas9-guideRNA (ⵉⵜⵜⵓⵙⵎⴰⵎⴽⵏ ⵙⴳ CRISPR).

source_sentence: In 1972 Paul Berg created the first recombinant DNA molecule when he combined DNA from a monkey virus with that of the lambda virus.
target_sentence: ⴳ ⵓⵙⴳⴳⵯⴰ ⵙⵏ 1972 ⵉⵙⴽⵔ ⴱⵓⵍ ⴱⵉⵔⴳ ⴰⴼⵔⴷⵉⵙ ⵏ ⵓⵖⵢⴰⵢ ⴰⵙⵎⵎⴰⵎ ⴰⵔⵉⴱⵓⵣⵉ ⴰⵎⵣⵡⴰⵔⵓ ⴰⵎⴷⵔⵓⵙ ⵏ ⵍⵓⴽⵙⵉⵊⵉⵏ ⵍⵍⵉⴳ ⵉⵙⵎⴰⵏ ⴰⵙⵎⵎⴰⵎ ⴰⵖⵢⴰⵢ ⵙⴳ ⵓⴼⵉⵔⵓⵙ ⵏ ⵓⴱⴰⵖⵓⵙ ⴷ ⵡⵉⵏ ⵍⴰⵎⴱⴰⴷⴰ.

source_sentence: The bacteria that had successfully incorporated the plasmid was then able to survive in the presence of kanamycin.
target_sentence: ⵜⵥⴹⴰⵕ ⵜⴱⴰⴽⵜⵉⵔⵉⵢⵜ ⵏⵏⴰ ⵉⵙⵙⵓⴷⴼⵏ ⵍⴱⵍⴰⵣⵎⵉⴷ ⴰⴷ ⵜⴷⴷⵔ ⵙ ⵜⵉⵍⵉⵜ ⵏ ⴽⴰⵏⴰⵎⵉⵛⵉⵏ.

source_sentence: In 1974 Rudolf Jaenisch created a transgenic mouse by introducing foreign DNA into its embryo, making it the world's first transgenic animal.
target_sentence: ⴳ ⵓⵙⴳⴳⴰⵙ ⵏ 1974 ⵉⵙⴽⵔ ⵕⵓⴷⵍⵓⴼ ⴷⵊⵉⵏⵉⵛ ⴰⵖⵔⴷⴰ ⵉⵏⴼⵍⵏ ⵙ ⵜⴽⵙⵙⵓⵢⵜⵙ ⵜⴱⵔⵉⴷⵜ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵉⴷⴼ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵎⵎⴰⵎ ⴰⵖⵢⴰⵢ ⵡⴰⵔ ⴰⵏⵉⵊⵉ ⵙ ⵍⵊⵉⵏⵉ ⵏⵏⵙ, ⵏⵏⴰ ⵜ ⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⴷ ⴰⵎⵓⴷⵔ ⴰⵎⵣⵡⵔⵓ ⵉⵏⴼⵍⵏ ⴳ ⵓⵎⴰⴹⴰⵍ.

source_sentence: Mice with genes removed (termed a knockout mouse) were created in 1989.
target_sentence: ⴳ ⵓⵙⴳⴳⵯⴰⵙ ⵏ 1989 ⵜⵜⵓⵙⴽⴰⵔⵏ ⵉⵖⵔⴷⴰⵢⵏ ⵉⵜⵜⵓⵙⴳⵔⵙⵏ ⵙ ⵍⵍⵊⵉⵏⴰⵜ ⵉⵜⵜⵡⴰⴽⴽⵙⵏ (ⵙⵎⵎⴰⵏ ⴰⵙⵏ ⵙ ⵉⵖⵔⴷⴰⵢⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵉⵜⵉ ⵜⴰⵏⴳⴳⴰⵔⵓⵜ).

source_sentence: In 1983 the first genetically engineered plant was developed by Michael W. Bevan, Richard B. Flavell and Mary-Dell Chilton.
target_sentence: ⴳ ⵓⵙⴳⴳⵯⴰⵙ ⵏ 1983 ⵉⵜⵜⵓⵏⴼⵍ ⵓⵎⵓⴳⵔⵉ ⴰⵏⵣⴳⵉ ⴰⴽⵙⵙⵓⵢ ⴰⵎⵣⵡⴰⵔⵓ ⵙⴳ ⵎⴰⵢⴽⵍ ⵡ. ⴱⵉⴼⵏ, ⵔⵉⵜⵛⴰⵔⴷ ⴱ.ⴼⴰⵍⴱⵍ ⴷ ⵍⴰⵔⵉ-ⴷⵉⵍⵍ ⵛⵉⵍⵟⵓⵏ.

source_sentence: In 2000, Vitamin A-enriched golden rice was the first plant developed with increased nutrient value.
target_sentence: ⴳ ⵓⵙⴳⴳⵯⴰⵙ ⵏ 2000, ⵉⴽⴽⴰ ⵜⵜ ⵉⵏⵏ ⵓⴼⵉⵜⴰⵎⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵕⵕⵓⵣ ⴰⵡⵔⵖ ⴰⵙⴱⵍⴰⵙ ⵉⴳⴰ ⴰⵎⵖⴰⵢ ⴰⵎⵣⵡⴰⵔⵓ ⵏⵏ ⵉⵜⵜⵓⵙⵏⴼⵍⵏ ⵙ ⵓⵔⵏⴰⵢ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵙⵓⴷⵙ ⴰⵏⵓⵜⵛⵉ.

source_sentence: The insulin produced by bacteria, branded humulin, was approved for release by the Food and Drug Administration in 1982.
target_sentence: ⴳ ⵓⵙⴳⴳⵯⴰⵙ ⵏ 1982, ⵜⵎⵙⴰⵙⴰ ⵜⵎⵙⵙⵓⴳⵓⵔⵜ ⵏ ⵡⵓⵜⵜⵛⵉ ⴷ ⵉⵙⵓⴼⴰⵔ ⵅⴼ ⵓⵕⵥⵣⵓⵎ ⵏ ⵍⴰⵏⵙⵓⵍⵉⵏ ⵏⵏⴰ ⵜⵙⵏⴼⵍⵓⵍ ⵜⴱⴰⴽⵜⵉⵔⵉⵢⵜ, ⵏⵏⴰ ⵉⵍⴰⵏ ⵀⵓⵎⵓⵍⵉⵏ.

source_sentence: In 1994 Calgene attained approval to commercially release the Flavr Savr tomato, the first genetically modified food.
target_sentence: ⴳ ⵓⵙⴳⴳⵯⴰⵙ ⵏ 1994 ⵢⵓⵡⵉ ⴽⴰⵍⵊⵉⵏ ⴰⵎⵙⴰⵙⴰ ⵏ ⵓⵕⵥⵥⵓⵎ ⵏ ⵓⵟⵎⵟⴰⵎ ⴼⵍⴰⴼⵕ ⵙⴰⴼⵕ ⵉ ⵜⵙⴱⴱⴰⴱⵜ, ⴷ ⵜⴳ ⵓⵜⵛⵓ ⵓⵜⵜⵓⵙⵏⴼⵍⵏ ⵙ ⵜⴽⵙⵙⵓⵢⵜ.

source_sentence: In 2010, scientists at the J. Craig Venter Institute announced that they had created the first synthetic bacterial genome.
target_sentence: ⴳ ⵓⵙⴳⴳⵯⴰⵙ ⵏ 2010, ⵙⵙⵓⴹⵔⴻⵔⵏ ⵉⵎⵓⵙⵏⴰⵡⵏ ⴳ ⵓⵙⵉⵏⴰⴳ ⵏ ⵊⵉⵀ ⴳⵔⵉⴳ ⴼⵉⵏⵜⵔ ⵎⴰⵙ ⵙⵙⴽⵔⵏ ⴰⵊⵉⵏⵢⵓⵎ ⴰⴱⴰⴽⵜⵉⵔⵉⵢ ⴰⵎⵓⴳⵔⵉ ⴰⵎⵣⵡⴰⵔⵓ.

source_sentence: It was released to the US market in 2003.
target_sentence: ⵉⴼⴼⵓⵖ ⵖⵔ ⴰⴳⴰⴷⴰⵣⵏ ⵏ ⵎⴰⵔⵉⴽⴰⵏ "ⵉⵡⵓⵏⴰⴽ ⵉⵎⵓⵏⵏ" ⴳ ⵓⵙⴳⴳⵯⴰⵙ ⵏ 2003.

source_sentence: Genes and other genetic information from a wide range of organisms can be added to a plasmid and inserted into bacteria for storage and modification.
target_sentence: ⵉⵥⴰⴹ ⴰⵔ ⴰⴷ ⵜⵜⵓⵣⴰⵢⴷⵏⵜ ⵍⵊⵉⵏⴰⵜ ⴷ ⵡⵓⴳⴳⴰⵔ ⵏ ⵜⵏⵎⵎⴰⵍⵉⵏ ⵜⵎⴽⴽⵓⵙⴰⵢ ⵙⴳ ⵜⴳⵔⴰⵡⵉⵏ ⵉⴱⴰⵔⵡⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵎⴷⴷⴰⵔⵏ ⵉⴷⴷⵔⵏ ⵖⵔ ⵍⴱⵍⴰⵣⵎⴰ ⴷ ⵓⵙⵙⵉⴷⴼ ⵏⵏⵙ ⴳ ⵜⴱⴰⴽⵜⵉⵔⵉⵢⵜ ⴳ ⵓⵃⵟⵟⵓ ⴷ ⵓⵙⵏⴼⵍ ⵏⵏⵙ

source_sentence: A large number of custom plasmids make manipulating DNA extracted from bacteria relatively easy.
target_sentence: ⵉⵍⵍⴰ ⵢⴰⵏ ⵡⵓⵟⵟⵓⵏ ⵉⴳⴳⵓⵜⵏ ⵏ ⵍⴱⵍⴰⵣⵎⴰ ⵉⵜⵜⵓⵥⵍⴰⵢⵏ ⵏⵏⴰ ⵉⵜⵜⴰⵊⴰⵏ ⵓⵔⴰⵔ ⵙ ⵓⵖⵢⴰⵢ ⴰⵙⵎⵎⴰⵎ ⴷ ⵉⴼⴼⵖⵏ ⵙⴳⵍⴱⴰⴽⵜⵉⵔⵉⵢⴰ ⵉⵡⵀⵏ ⴷⵔⵓⵖ ⴷⴷ.

source_sentence: Scientists can easily manipulate and combine genes within the bacteria to create novel or disrupted proteins and observe the effect this has on various molecular systems.
target_sentence: ⵥⴷⴰⵕⵏ ⵉⵎⵓⵙⵏⴰⵡⵏ ⵙ ⵓⵎⵀⴰⵍ ⴰⴷ ⵓⵔⵔⴰⵏ ⵙ ⵍⵊⵉⵏⴰⵜ ⵙⵙⵉⴷⴼⵏ ⵜⵏⵜ ⵊⴰⵊ ⵏ ⵜⴱⴰⴽⵜⵉⵔⵉⵢⵜ ⵜⵜⴰⴼ ⴰⴷ ⵜⵜⵓⵙⴽⴰⵔⵏⵜ ⵍⴱⵕⵓⵜⵉⵏⴰⵜ ⵜⵉⵎⴰⵢⵓⵜⵉⵏ ⵏⵖ ⵜⵉⵔⵡⵓⵔⵉⵜⵉⵏ ⴷ ⵓⵔⴰⵄⴰ ⵏ ⵡⵓⴹⵓⵚ ⵏⵏⴰ ⴷ ⵉⴼⴼⴰⵍ ⵓⵢⵏⴰ ⵅⴼ ⵛⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵎⴰⴳⵔⴰⵡⵏ ⵉⴼⵓⵍⴰⵏⵏ.

source_sentence: Bacteria have been used in the production of food for a long time, and specific strains have been developed and selected for that work on an industrial scale.
target_sentence: ⵜⵜⵓⵙⵎⵔⴰⵙ ⵜⴱⴰⴽⵜⵉⵔⵉⵢⵜ ⴳ ⵓⵙⵏⴼⵍⵓⵍ ⵏ ⵡⵓⵜⵛⵉ ⵜⵉⵣⵉⵜⴰⵖⵣⵣⴰⴼⵜ, ⴷ ⵜⵜⵓⴳⵎⴰⵏⵜ ⵜⵙⴷⴷⵉⵜⵉⵏ ⵉⵥⵍⵉⵏ ⴷ ⵜⵜⵓⵙⵜⴰⵢⵏⵜ ⵉ ⵜⵡⵓⵔⵉ ⴰⴷ ⵅⴼ ⵓⵎⵏⴰⴹ ⴰⵎⵓⴳⵔⵉ.

source_sentence: Most food-producing bacteria are lactic acid bacteria, and this is where the majority of research into genetically engineering food-producing bacteria has gone.
target_sentence: ⵛⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵜⴱⴰⴽⵜⵉⵔⵉⵢⵜ ⵉⵙⵏⴼⵍⵓⵍⵏ ⵓⵜⵛⵉ ⵜⴳⴰ ⵜⴰⴱⴰⴽⵜⵉⵔⵉⵢⵜ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵎⵎⴰⵎ ⴰⵍⴰⴽⵜⵉⴽⵉ, ⴰⴱⵔⵉⴷ ⴰⴷ ⴰⴳ ⵙⵙⵓⴷⴰⵏ ⵛⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵔⵣⵣⵓⵜⵏ ⴳ ⵜⴱⴰⵊⵜⵉⵔⵉⵢⵜ ⵉⵙⵏⴼⵍⵓⵍⵏ ⵓⵜⵛⵉ ⵜⴰⵏⵎⵣⴳⵉⵜ ⵜⴰⴽⵙⵙⵓⵢⵜ.

source_sentence: The majority are produced in the US and even though regulations are in place to allow production in Europe, as of 2015 no food products derived from bacteria are currently available there.

source_sentence: Many of these proteins are impossible or difficult to obtain via natural methods and they are less likely to be contaminated with pathogens, making them safer.

source_sentence: Other uses for genetically modified bacteria include bioremediation, where the bacteria are used to convert pollutants into a less toxic form.

source_sentence: In the 1980s artist Jon Davis and geneticist Dana Boyd converted the Germanic symbol for femininity (ᛉ) into binary code and then into a DNA sequence, which was then expressed in Escherichia coli.
target_sentence: ⴳ ⵉⵙⴳⴳⵯⴰⵙⵏ ⵏ 1980 ⵏ ⵜⵍⴰⵍⵉⵜ, ⵜⵙⵏⴼⵍⵜ ⵜⵏⴰⵥⵓⵕⵜ ⵊⵓⵏ ⴷⵉⴼⵉⵙ ⴷ ⵜⵎⴰⵙⵙⴰⵏⵜ ⵏ ⵜⴽⵙⵙⵓⵢⵜ ⴷⴰⵏⴰ ⴱⵓⵢⴷ ⵜⴰⵎⴰⵜⴰⵔⵜ ⵏ ⵍⴰⵍⵎⴰⵏ ⵉ ⵜⵓⵜⵎⵜ (ᛉ) ⵖⵔ ⴰⵙⵓⵎⴷ ⴰⵢⵓⴳⴰⵏ ⴷ ⵖⵔ ⵓⵙⴷⴷⵉ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵎⵎⴰⵎ ⴰⵖⵢⴰⵢ, ⵏⵏⴰ ⵙ ⵉⵜⵜⵓⵙⵏⵎⵍ ⴷⴼⴼⵔ ⴰⵢⵏⵏⴰ ⵙ ⵉⵛⵉⵔⵉⵛⵢⴰ ⴽⵓⵍⵉ".

source_sentence: Researchers can use this to control for various factors; including the target location, insert size, and duration of gene expression.

source_sentence: Although primarily still at trial stages, there has been some successes using gene therapy to replace defective genes.

source_sentence: As of 2018, there are a substantial number of clinical trials underway, including treatments for hemophilia, glioblastoma, chronic granulomatous disease, cystic fibrosis and various cancers.
target_sentence: ⵙⴳ ⵓⵙⴳⴳⵯⴰⵙ ⵏ 2018, ⵍⵍⴰⵏⵜ ⵛⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵉⵔⵎⵉⵜⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵉⵙⵉ ⵉⵜⵜⵓⵙⴽⴰⵔⵏ, ⴳ ⴰⵎⵓⵏⵜ ⵉⵙⵎⴽⵍⵏ ⵏ ⵍⵀⵉⵎⵓⴼⵓⵍⵉⵢⴰ, ⴳⵍⵉⵢⵓⴱⵍⴰⵙⵜⵓⵎⴰ, ⴷ ⵜⵎⴰⴹⵓⵏⵜ ⵏ ⵓⵡⵍⴰⵍ ⴰⴹⵕⴹⵓⵕ ⵉⵅⵛⵏⵏ, ⵙⵢⴰⵜⵉⴽ ⴰⴼⵉⴱⵔⵓⵙⵉⵢ ⴷ ⵛⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵉⴼⵓⵔⵔⵓⵢⵏ.

source_sentence: Herpes simplex viruses make promising vectors, having a carrying capacity of over 30kb and providing long term expression, although they are less efficient at gene delivery than other vectors.

source_sentence: Other viruses that have been used as vectors include alphaviruses, flaviviruses, measles viruses, rhabdoviruses, Newcastle disease virus, poxviruses, and picornaviruses.

source_sentence: This does not affect the viruses infectivity, invokes a natural immune response and there is no chance that they will regain their virulence function, which can occur with some other vaccines.

source_sentence: In order to address some of these concerns some GMOs have been developed with traits to help control their spread.

source_sentence: Other environmental and agronomic concerns include a decrease in biodiversity, an increase in secondary pests (non-targeted pests) and evolution of resistant insect pests.
target_sentence: ⵡⵉⵢⵢⴰⴹ ⵉⵏⵣⴳⵓⵎⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵡⴰⵏⵏⴰⴹⵜ ⴷ ⵏ ⵜⴽⵔⵣⴰ ⵓⵎⴰⵏ ⴰⴼⵏⴰⵥ ⵏ ⵜⵎⵢⴰⵏⴰⵡⵜ ⵜⴱⵢⵓⵍⵓⵊⵉⵜ, ⴰⵙⴳⵉⴷⵉ ⵏ ⵟⵟⵕⵓⵕⵜ ⵜⴰⵙⵉⵏⴰⵏⵜ (ⵟⵟⵕⵓⵕⵜ ⵓⵔ ⵉⵜⵜⵡⴰⵜⴰⵙⵏ) ⴷ ⵓⵙⴱⵓⵖⵍⵓ ⵏ ⵟⵟⵕⵓⵕⵜ ⵏ ⵉⴱⵓⵅⵅⴰ ⵉⵏⵣⴱⴰⵢⵏ.

source_sentence: With the ability to genetically engineer humans now possible there are ethical concerns over how far this technology should go, or if it should be used at all.

source_sentence: October 2006 the rigor of the regulatory process, consolidation of control of the food supply in companies that make and sell GMOs, exaggeration of the benefits of genetic modification, or concerns over the use of herbicides with glyphosate.
target_sentence: ⴽⵟⵓⴱⵕ 2006 ⵜⴰⴽⵕⵥⵉ ⵏ ⵜⵣⵉⴳⴳⵣⵜ ⵜⵓⵣⵔⵉⴼⵜ, ⴰⵙⴷⵓⵙ ⵏ ⵜⵉⴹⴰⴼ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵎⴽⵍ ⴰⵎⵙⴰⴷⵓⵔ ⴳ ⵜⵎⵙⵙⵏⵜⴰⵢ ⵍⵍⵉ ⵉⵜⵜⵀⴰⵢⵢⴰⵏ ⴰⵔ ⵣⵣⵏⵣⴰⵏⵜ GMO, ⴰⴼⵜⴰⵢ ⵏ ⵉⴱⵖⵓⵔⵏ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵏⴼⵍ ⴰⵊⵉⵏⵉⵜⵉ, ⵏⵖ ⵉⵏⵣⴳⵓⵎⵏ ⵉⵥⵍⵉⵏ ⵙ ⵓⵙⵎⵔⵙ ⵏ ⵉⵙⴰⴼⴰⵔⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵎⵖⴰⵢⵏ ⴰⴽⴷ ⴳⵍⵉⴼⵓⵣⴰⵜ.

source_sentence: GMOs arrived on the scene as the public confidence in food safety, attributed to recent food scares such as Bovine spongiform encephalopathy and other scandals involving government regulation of products in Europe, was low.
target_sentence: ⴳⵓⵍⴰⵏ ⵏⵏ GMO ⵉⴷⵖⴰⵔⵏ ⴽⵓⴷⵏⵏⴰ ⵜⴷⵔⵓⵙ ⵜⴼⵍⵙⵜ ⵏ ⵓⴳⴷⵓⴷ ⴳ ⵜⵏⴼⵔⵓⵜ ⵜⴰⵎⵙⴰⴷⵓⵔⵜ, ⵍⵍⵉ ⵉⵜⵜⴼⴽⴰⵏ ⵉ ⵜⵓⴳⴷⵉⵡⵉⵏ ⵜⵉⵎⵙⴰⴷⵓⵔⵉⵏ ⵜⵉⵎⴳⴳⵓⵔⴰ ⴰⵎⵎ ⵓⵏⵙⵉⴼⴰⵍⵓⴱⴰⵜⵉ ⵙⴱⵓⵏⵊⵉⴼⵓⵔⵎ ⵏ ⵉⵎⴰⴳⴰⵢⵏ ⴷ ⵡⵉⵢⵢⴰⴹ ⵉⴽⴰⵛⴰⴼⵏ ⵍⵍⵉ ⴳ ⵉⵍⵍⴰ ⵉⵣⵣⵔⴰⴼ ⵓⵏⴱⵉⴹ ⵏ ⵉⴼⴰⵔⵙⵏ ⴳ ⵜⵓⵔⵓⴼⵜ.

source_sentence: Genetic engineering, also called genetic modification or genetic manipulation, is the direct manipulation of an organism's genes using biotechnology.
target_sentence: ⵜⴰⵎⵙⴳⴷⴰ ⵜⴰⵊⵉⵏⵉⵜⵉⴽⵜ, ⵉⵜⵜⵢⴰⵙⵙⵏ ⴰⵡⴷ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵏⴼⵍ ⴰⵊⵉⵏⵉⵜⵉⴽ ⵏⵖ ⴰⵇⴷⴷⵛ ⴰⵊⵉⵏⵉⵜⵉⴽ, ⵜⴳⴰ ⴰⵇⴷⴷⴰⵛ ⵓⵙⵔⵉⴷ ⵏ ⵉⵊⵉⵏⵏ ⵏ ⵢⴰⵏ ⵓⴳⵎⴰⵎ ⵙ ⵡⴰⵍⵍⴰⵍ ⵏ ⵜⴰⴱⵢⵓⵜⵉⴽⵏⵓⵍⵓⵊⵉⵜ.

source_sentence: A construct is usually created and used to insert this DNA into the host organism.

source_sentence: The new DNA can be inserted randomly, or targeted to a specific part of the genome.
target_sentence: ⵉⵖⵉⵢ ⵓⵙⵎⵎⴰⵎ ⴰⵖⵢⴰⵢ ⴰⵎⴰⵢⵏⵓ ⴰⴷ ⵉⵢⵢⵓⵙⴽⵎⵛ ⵙ ⵓⵙⵎⴰⵙⵙⴰ, ⵏⵖ ⴰⵙ ⵜⵜⵓⴼⵔⴰⵏ ⵢⴰⵜ ⵜⴰⴼⵓⵍⵜ ⵉⵥⵍⵉⵏ ⴳ ⵓⵊⵉⵏⵓⵎ.

source_sentence: Rudolf Jaenisch created the first GM animal when he inserted foreign DNA into a mouse in 1974.

source_sentence: Genetically modified food has been sold since 1994, with the release of the Flavr Savr tomato.

source_sentence: By knocking out genes responsible for certain conditions it is possible to create animal model organisms of human diseases.

source_sentence: The rise of commercialised genetically modified crops has provided economic benefit to farmers in many different countries, but has also been the source of most of the controversy surrounding the technology.
target_sentence: ⵜⴼⴽⴰ ⵜⴳⵎⵉ ⵏ ⵜⴽⵔⵣⵉⵡⵉⵏ ⵉⵏⵏⴼⵍⵏ ⴳ ⵜⵊⵉⵏⵉⵜ ⵏⵏⵙⵏ ⵉⵏⵣⵣⴰⵏ ⵉⴱⵖⵓⵔⵏ ⵉ ⵜⴷⴰⵎⵙⴰ ⴷ ⵉⵎⴳⵢⴰⴽⵏ ⴳ ⴽⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵎⵉⵣⴰⵔ, ⵎⴰⵛⴰ ⵉⴳⴰ ⴰⵖⴱⴰⵍⵓ ⵏ ⵓⵎⴰⵜⴰ ⵏ ⵉⵎⵏⵣⴰⵖⵏ ⵉⵍⵍⴰⵏ ⵖⴼ ⵜⵉⴽⵏⵓⵍⵓⵊⵉⵜ.

source_sentence: Gene flow, impact on non-target organisms, control of the food supply and intellectual property rights have also been raised as potential issues.

source_sentence: This is much faster, can be used to insert any genes from any organism (even ones from different domains) and prevents other undesirable genes from also being added.

source_sentence: Drugs, vaccines and other products have been harvested from organisms engineered to produce them.
target_sentence: ⵉⵙⴰⴼⴰⵔⵏ, ⵜⵉⴳⵣⵣⴰⵢⵉⵏ ⴷ ⵡⵉⵢⵢⴰⴹ ⵉⴼⴰⵔⵙⵏ ⵜⵜⵢⴰⴽⴽⴰⵙⵏ ⴷ ⵙⴳ ⵉⵏⴳⵎⴰⵎⵏ ⵍⵍⵉ ⵉⵜⵜⵙⴽⵔⵏ ⵉ ⵓⴼⴰⵔⵙ ⵏⵏⵙⵏ.

source_sentence: Synthetic biology is an emerging discipline that takes genetic engineering a step further by introducing artificially synthesised material into an organism.
target_sentence: ⵜⴰⵎⴰⵙⵙⴰⵏⵜ ⵏ ⵜⵓⴷⵔⵜ ⵜⴰⵎⵙⵓⴽⵏⵜ ⴷ ⵉⵥⵍⵉ ⴷ ⵢⵓⵍⵉⵏ ⴰⵔ ⵉⴷⴽⴽⵉ ⵜⴰⵎⵙⴳⴷⴰ ⵜⴰⵊⵉⵏⵉⵜⵙ ⵓⵙⵉⴷⴼ ⵏ ⵉⵎⴰⵜⵜⵉⵡⵏ ⵉⵎⵙⵓⴽⵏⵏ ⴳ ⵜⵉⵍⵉⵜ ⵉⴷⴷⵔⵏ.

source_sentence: If genetic material from another species is added to the host, the resulting organism is called transgenic.
target_sentence: ⵉⴳ ⵜⴻⵜⵜⵓⵔⵏⴰ ⵜⵎⵜⵜⴰ ⵜⴰⵎⴽⴽⴰⵙⵓⵜ ⵢⴰⵏ ⵡⴰⵏⴰⵡ ⵉ ⵢⴰⵏ ⵓⵎⵙⵏⵓⴱⴳ, ⴷⴰ ⴰⵙ ⵏⵜⵜⵉⵏⵉ ⵉ ⵜⵉⵍⵉⵜ ⴷ ⵉⴼⴼⵖⵏ ⴰⵏⴰⴼⴰⵍ ⴳ ⵜⵊⵉⵏⵉⵜ ⵏⵏⵙ.

source_sentence: In 1973 Herbert Boyer and Stanley Cohen created the first transgenic organism by inserting antibiotic resistance genes into the plasmid of an Escherichia coli bacterium.
target_sentence: ⴳ 1973, ⵉⵙⵏⵓⵍⴼⴰ ⵀⵉⵔⴱⵉⵔⵜ ⴱⵡⴰⵢⵉ ⴷ ⵙⵜⴰⵏⵍⵉ ⴽⵓⵀⵉⵏ ⴰⵏⴳⵎⴰⵎ ⴰⵎⵣⵡⴰⵔⵓ ⵉⵏⵏⴼⵍⵏ ⴳ ⵜⵊⵉⵏⵉⵜ ⵏⵏⵙ ⵙ ⵓⵙⵉⴷⴼ ⵏ ⵉⵊⵉⵏⵏ ⵏ ⵓⵣⴱⴰⵢ ⵉ ⵓⵏⵜⵉⴱⵢⵓⵜⵉⴽ ⴳ ⵓⴱⵍⴰⵣⵎⵉⴷ ⵏ ⵢⴰⵜ ⵜⴱⴰⴽⵜⵉⵔⵜ ⵉⵛⵉⵔⵛⵉⵢⴰ ⴽⵓⵍⵉ.

source_sentence: In 1976 Genentech, the first genetic engineering company, was founded by Herbert Boyer and Robert Swanson and a year later the company produced a human protein (somatostatin) in E.coli.
target_sentence: ⴳ 1976, ⵜⵓⵜⵜⵓⵙⴽⴰ ⵜⵎⵙⵙⵓⵔⵜ ⵜⵎⴰⵣⵡⴰⵔⵓⵜ ⵏ ⵜⵎⵙⴳⴷⴰ ⵜⴰⵊⵉⵏⵉⵜ, ⴳⵉⵏⵉⵏⵜⵉⵛ, ⵙⵖⵓⵔ ⵀⵉⵔⴱⵉⵔⵜ ⴱⵡⴰⵢⵉ ⴷ ⵔⵓⴱⵉⵔⵜ ⵙⵡⴰⵏⵙⵓⵏ ⴷ ⵢⴰⵏ ⵓⵙⴳⴳⵯⴰⵙ ⴷⴼⴼⵉⵔⴰⵙ, ⵜⴼⴰⵔⵙ ⵜⵎⵙⵙⵓⵔⵜ ⴰⴱⵔⵓⵜⵉⵏ ⴰⵏⴼⴳⴰⵏ (ⵙⵓⵎⴰⵜⵓⵙⵜⴰⵜⵉⵏ) ⴳ ⵉⴽⵓⵍⵉ.

source_sentence: The insulin produced by bacteria was approved for release by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in 1982.

source_sentence: "The simplest method, and the first to be used, is ""alanine scanning"", where every position in turn is mutated to the unreactive amino acid alanine."
target_sentence: ⵜⴰⴱⵔⵉⴷⵜ ⴰⴽⵯ ⵜⴰⴼⵔⴰⵔⵜ, ⴷ ⵜⵎⵣⵡⴰⵔⵓⵜ ⵍⵍⵉ ⵉⵜⵜⵓⵙⵎⵔⵙⵏ, ⵉⴳⴰ ⵜⵜ "ⵓⵙⴽⴽⵉ ⵏ ⴰⵍⴰⵏⵉⵏ, ⵍⵍⵉ ⴳ ⵜⵜⵏⴼⴰⵍ ⴽⵓ ⵜⴰⵙⴷⵖⵔⵜ ⴳ ⵜⵡⴰⵍⴰ ⵏⵏⵙ ⵙ ⴰⵍⴰⵏⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵎⵎⴰⵎ ⴰⵎⵉⵏⵉ ⵓⵔ ⵉⵙⵡⵓⵔⵉⵏ."

source_sentence: The process is much the same as that in knockout engineering, except that the construct is designed to increase the function of the gene, usually by providing extra copies of the gene or inducing synthesis of the protein more frequently.
target_sentence: ⵜⵔⵡⴰⵙ ⵜⵣⵉⴳⴳⵣⵜ ⵙ ⵉⵎⵉⴽⴽ ⵜⴰⵎⵙⴷⴳⴰ ⵏ ⵡⵓⴷⵓⵣ ⵙⵍⵉⴷ ⵜⵓⵙⴽⴰ ⵍⵍⵉ ⵉⵜⵜⵓⴳⴰⵏ ⵉ ⵓⵙⵉⵍⵉ ⵏ ⵜⵙⵖⵏⵜ ⵏ ⵓⵊⵉⵏ, ⴳ ⵜⵎⵢⵓⵔⵜ ⵙ ⵜⵉⴽⴽⵉ ⵏ ⵜⵓⵏⵖⵉⵍⵉⵏ ⵜⵉⵎⵔⵏⴰ ⵏ ⵓⵊⵉⵏⵏ ⵏⵖ ⵙ ⵓⵙⵉⴷⴼ ⵏ ⵓⴼⵙⴰⵢ ⵏ ⵓⴱⵔⵓⵜⵉⵏ ⵍⵍⵉ ⴱⴰⵀⵔⴰ ⵉⵍⵍⴰⵏ.

source_sentence: One way to do this is to replace the wild-type gene with a 'fusion' gene, which is a juxtaposition of the wild-type gene with a reporting element such as green fluorescent protein (GFP) that will allow easy visualisation of the products of the genetic modification.
target_sentence: ⵢⴰⵜ ⵜⵖⴰⵔⴰⵜⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵉⴳⴳⵉ ⵉⴳⴰ ⵜⵜ ⴰⵙⵏⴼⵍ ⵏ ⵓⵊⵉⵏ ⴰⵏⴰⵡ ⴰⵔⴰⵎⵢⴰⵔ ⵏ ⵢⴰⵏ ⵓⴼⵉⵏ ⵏ 'ⵓⴼⵙⴰⵢ', ⵍⵍⵉ ⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵢⴰⵏ ⵓⵙⵜⴰⵎⴰ ⵏ ⵓⵊⵉⵏ ⴰⵏⴰⵡ ⴰⵔⴰⵎⵢⴰⵔ ⴰⵍⴷ ⵓⴼⵔⴷⵉⵙ ⵏ ⵓⵎⵢⴰⵙⵙⴰ ⴰⵎⵎ ⵓⴱⵔⵓⵜⵉⵏ ⴰⴼⵍⵓⵔⵉⵏ ⴰⵣⴳⵣⴰⵡ (GFP) ⵍⵍⵉ ⵉⵜⵜⴰⵊⵊⴰⵏ ⴰⵙⴽⵙⵡ ⵉⵍⵎⴹⵏ ⵏ ⵉⴼⴰⵔⵙⵏ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵏⴼⵍ ⴰⵊⵉⵏⵉⵜⵉⴽ.

source_sentence: Expression studies aim to discover where and when specific proteins are produced.
target_sentence: ⴷⴰ ⵜⵜⵏⵢⵢⴰⵛⵏⵜ ⵜⵣⵔⴰⵡⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵡⵏⵏⵉⵜ ⵜⴰⵡⴰⴼⵉⵜ ⵏ ⵎⴰⵏⵉ ⴷ ⵎⴰⵏⵜⵓⵔ ⴰⴷ ⵜⵜⵓⴼⵔⴰⵙⵏ ⵉⴱⵔⵓⵜⵉⵏⵏ ⵉⵥⵍⵉⵏ.

source_sentence: Some genes do not work well in bacteria, so yeast, insect cells or mammalians cells can also be used.

source_sentence: Certain genetically modified microbes can also be used in biomining and bioremediation, due to their ability to extract heavy metals from their environment and incorporate them into compounds that are more easily recoverable.
target_sentence: ⵉⴷⵙⵏ ⵉⵎⵉⴽⵔⵓⴱⵏ ⵉⵏⵏⴼⵍⵏ ⴳ ⵜⵊⵉⵏⵉⵜ ⵏⵏⵙⵏ ⵖⵉⵢⵏ ⴰⴷ ⴰⵡⴷ ⵜⵜⵓⵙⵎⵔⵙⵏ ⴳ ⵓⵙⵎⵙⴽⵍ ⵓⵏⴷⵉⵔ ⴷ ⵜⴽⵏⵏⴰⵡⵜ ⵜⴰⴱⵢⵓⵍⵓⵊⵉⵜ, ⵙ ⵜⵎⵏⵜⵉⵍⵜ ⵏ ⵜⵣⵎⵔⵜ ⵏⵏⵙⵏ ⴰⴷ ⴷ ⵙⵙⵓⴼⵖⵏ ⴰⵍⴷⵓⵏ ⴰⵎⴰⵥⴰⵢ ⵙⴳ ⵜⵡⴰⵏⵏⴰⴹ ⵏⵏⵙⵏ ⴷ ⴰⴷ ⵜ ⵙⴽⵛⵎⵏ ⴳ ⵡⵓⴷⴷⵉⵙⵏ ⵉⵖⵉⵢⵏ ⴰⴷ ⴷ ⵜⵜⵓⵔⴰⵏ ⵙ ⵜⵍⵎⴹⵉ.

source_sentence: Fungal and virus resistant crops have also been developed or are in development.

source_sentence: In 2016 Salmon have been genetically modified with growth hormones to reach normal adult size much faster.

source_sentence: Applications of genetic engineering in conservation are thus far mostly theoretical and have yet to be put into practice.

source_sentence: The Asilomar meeting recommended a set of voluntary guidelines regarding the use of recombinant technology.

source_sentence: One hundred and fifty-seven countries are members of the Protocol and many use it as a reference point for their own regulations.

source_sentence: Most countries that do not allow GMO cultivation do permit research.

target_sentence: ⵉⵎⵉⵍⵉ ⵎⴰⵔⴷⵏ, ⵉⵎⵉⵣⵉ ⴷ ⵓⵙⵍⴳⵏ : ⵜⴰⵙⵔⵜⵉⵜ ⵜⴰⵙⵍⴳⴰⵏⵜ ⵏ ⵉⵡⵓⵏⴰⴽ ⵉⵎⵓⵏⵏ ⵅⴼ ⵓⵙⴰⴷⵓⵔ ⴷ ⵜⴼⵍⵍⴰⵃⵜ ⵉⵜⵜⵓⵙⵏⴼⵍⵏ ⵙ ⵜⵓⴽⴽⵙⵉ, 44 ⴷⴰⵜ ⵜⵍⴰⵍⵉⵜ ⵏ ⵍⵎⴰⵙⵉⵃ. Rev. 733 (2003), ⴷ ⵓⵎⵔⴰⵔ ⵖⴼ ⵎⴰⵏⴰⵢⴰ ⵉⵖⵢ ⵉⵙ ⵉⵍⵍⴰ ⴷⴰⵔ ⵓⵎⵓⵏⵉ ⵏ ⵓⵔⵓⴱⴱⴰ ⵜⵉⵍⴳⴰⵎⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵎⵖⵏⴰⵡⵏ ⵡⴰⵍⴰ ⵉⵜⵜⵓⵙⵎⵎⵉⵙⵉⵏ ⴳ ⵓⵜⴰⵔⵉ ⵉⵇⵊⴻⵕⵏ ⴳ ⵓⵎⴰⴹⴰⵍ.

source_sentence: One of the key issues concerning regulators is whether GM products should be labeled.

source_sentence: These controversies have led to litigation, international trade disputes, and protests, and to restrictive regulation of commercial products in some countries.
target_sentence: ⵓⵡⵉⵏ ⵉⵎⵏⵣⵉⵖⵏ ⴰⴷ ⵙ ⴰⵎⵣⵣⴰⵔⴼⵓ ⴷ ⵉⵏⴱⴹⴰⵡⵏ ⵉⵎⵣⵣⵏⵣⴰⵡⵏ ⵉⵎⴰⴹⵍⴰⵏ ⴷ ⵉⵖⵓⵢⵢⵉⵜⵏ,ⴷ ⵓⵙⵙⵓⴷⵙ ⵉⵏⵏⴳⵣⴰⵏ ⵉ ⵜⵖⴰⵡⵙⵉⵡⵉⵏ ⵜⵉⵎⵣⵣⵏⵣⴰⵢ ⴳ ⴽⵔⴰ ⵏ ⵜⵎⵉⵣⴰⵔ.

source_sentence: Although doubts have been raised, economically most studies have found growing GM crops to be beneficial to farmers.

source_sentence: Many of the environmental impacts regarding GM crops may take many years to be understood and are also evident in conventional agriculture practices.
target_sentence: ⵉⵖⵢ ⵓⵔⵎⴰⵙ ⵏ ⴽⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵉⴹⵉⵚⵏ ⵉⵡⵏⵏⴰⴹⵏ ⵉⵟⴼⵏ ⵙ ⵜⵉⴳⵉ ⵜⴰⵜⴰⵔⵉⵜ ⵉⵙⴳⴳⵯⴰⵙ ⵎⴰⵔ ⴰⴷ ⵉⵜⵢⴰⴽⵣ ⵉⵎⴽⵉⵏⵏⴰ ⵜⴱⴰⵢⵏ ⴳ ⵜⵢⵔⵣⴰ ⵜⴰⵣⴰⵢⴽⵓⵜ.

source_sentence: Few films have informed audiences about genetic engineering, with the exception of the 1978 The Boys from Brazil and the 1993 Jurassic Park, both of which made use of a lesson, a demonstration, and a clip of scientific film.
target_sentence: ⵉⵎⵉⴽ ⵏ ⵉⵙⴰⵔⵓⵜⵏ ⴰⵢⴷ ⵉⵙⵙⴰⵡⴹⵏ ⵉ ⵓⴳⴷⵓⴷ ⴰⵜⵡⴰⵍ ⴰⵜⴰⵔⵉ,ⵖⴰⵙ ⴰⵙⴰⵔⵓ 1978 ⵉⵛⵉⵔⵔⴰⵏ ⵙⴳ ⴱⵔⴰⵥⵉⵍ ⴷ ⵊⵓⵔⴰⵙⵉ ⴱⴰⵔⴽ 1993 ⴽⵓⵍⵍⵓⵜⵏ ⵓⴳⵎⵏ ⴳ ⵜⵎⵙⵉⵔⵜ ⴷ ⵓⴼⵙⴰⵔ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵙⵉⴽⵣ, ⴷ ⵜⴰⴼⵉⵔⵜ ⴳ ⵓⵙⴰⵔⵓ ⴰⵎⴰⵙⵙⴰⵏ.

source_sentence: Nanotechnology, also shortened to nanotech, is the use of matter on an atomic, molecular, and supramolecular scale for industrial purposes.
target_sentence: ⵏⵏⴰⵏⵓ ⵜⵉⴽⵏⵓⵍⵓⵊⵉ ⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵙ ⵓⵣⵣⴳⵣⵍ ⵏⵏⴰⵏⵓⵜⵉⴽ, ⵜⴳⴰ ⴰⵙⵡⵓⵔⵉ ⵙ ⵜⴰⵏⴳⴰ ⴳ ⵎⴰⵢⵥⵍⵉⵏ ⵙ ⵓⴱⵍⴽⵉⵎ ⴷ ⵡⴰⵙⵉⵙ ⴷ ⵡⴰⴼⵍⵍⴰ ⵏ ⵡⴰⵙⵉⵙ ⵉ ⵓⵙⴽⴽⵉⵏ ⴰⵎⴳⵓⵔⴰⵏ.

source_sentence: This definition reflects the fact that quantum mechanical effects are important at this quantum-realm scale, and so the definition shifted from a particular technological goal to a research category inclusive of all types of research and technologies that deal with the special properties of matter which occur below the given size threshold.
target_sentence: ⴰⵙⵉⵙⵙⵏ ⴰⴷ ⴰⵔ ⵢⴰⴽⴽⴰ ⵢⴰⵜ ⵜⵉⴷⵜ ⵏ ⵡⵉⵙ ⴷ ⵉⴹⵉⵚⵏ ⵉⵎⵉⴽⴰⵏⵉⴽⵉⵜⵏ ⵏ ⴽⴰⵏⵟⵓⵎ ⵙⵜⴰⵡⵀⵎⵎⴰⵏ ⴳ ⵜⵎⵙⵖⴰⵍⵜ ⵏ ⵓⵎⴰⴹⴰⵍ ⵏ ⵜⵎⵏⵏⴰⵡⵜ, ⴰⵢⴰ ⴰⵖⴼ ⵉⵜⵜⵓⵙⵏⴼⵍ ⵓⵙⵉⵙⵙⵏ ⵙⴳ ⵓⵙⴰⵖⴷ ⴰⵜⵉⴽⵏⵓⵍⵓⵊⵉ ⵖⵔ ⵜⴳⵔⵔⵓⵎⴰ ⵏ ⵉⵙⵏⵓⴱⴱⵓⵛⵏ ⵢⵓⵎⵥⵏ ⵎⴰⵔⵔⴰ ⴰⵏⴰⵡⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵔⵣⵣⵓⵜⵏ ⴷ ⵜⵉⵇⵏⵉⵢⴰⵜ ⵉⵙⵡⵓⵔⵉⵏ ⵙ ⵉⵏⴰⵎⴰⵥⴰⵏ ⵉⵥⵍⵉⵏ ⵙ ⵜⵎⵜⵜⴰ ⵜⴰⵎⵙⴰⵔⵜ ⵙ ⵜⴰⴷⵔⵙⵉ ⵏ ⵓⵎⵏⴰⵔ ⵉⵍⴰⵇⵏ ⴰⴷ ⵢⵉⵍⵉ.

source_sentence: The associated research and applications are equally diverse, ranging from extensions of conventional device physics to completely new approaches based upon molecular self-assembly, from developing new materials with dimensions on the nanoscale to direct control of matter on the atomic scale.

source_sentence: "The term ""nano-technology"" was first used by Norio Taniguchi in 1974, though it was not widely known."

source_sentence: To put that scale in another context, the comparative size of a nanometer to a meter is the same as that of a marble to the size of the earth.

source_sentence: "In the ""bottom-up"" approach, materials and devices are built from molecular components which assemble themselves chemically by principles of molecular recognition."

source_sentence: The concept of molecular recognition is especially important: molecules can be designed so that a specific configuration or arrangement is favored due to non-covalent intermolecular forces.

source_sentence: Alpha decay is when a nucleus releases an alpha particle, which is two protons and two neutrons, equivalent to a helium nucleus.

source_sentence: This type of radiation is the most dangerous and most difficult to block.

source_sentence: The average number of neutrons released per nucleus that go on to fission another nucleus is referred to as k. Values of k larger than 1 mean that the fission reaction is releasing more neutrons than it absorbs, and therefore is referred to as a self-sustaining chain reaction.

source_sentence: If there are enough immediate decays to carry on the chain reaction, the mass is said to be prompt critical, and the energy release will grow rapidly and uncontrollably, usually leading to an explosion.

source_sentence: However, other progressives have argued that posthumanism, whether it be its philosophical or activist forms, amounts to a shift away from concerns about social justice, from the reform of human institutions and from other Enlightenment preoccupations, toward narcissistic longings for a transcendence of the human body in quest of more exquisite ways of being.

source_sentence: "In keeping with this, many prominent transhumanist advocates, such as Dan Agin, refer to transhumanism's critics, on the political right and left jointly, as ""bioconservatives"" or ""bioluddites"", the latter term alluding to the 19th century anti-industrialisation social movement that opposed the replacement of human manual labourers by machines."

source_sentence: The research required to solve mathematical problems can take years or even centuries of sustained inquiry.

source_sentence: As evidenced by tallies found on bone, in addition to recognizing how to count physical objects, prehistoric peoples may have also recognized how to count abstract quantities, like time—days, seasons, or years.
target_sentence: ⵉⵎⴽ ⵉⵜⵢⴰⴽⵣ ⴳ ⵉⵙⵙⵉⵟⵏ ⵉⵍⵍⴰⵏ ⵖⴼ ⵉⵖⵚⴰⵏ, ⵓⵍⴰ ⵎⴰⵎⴽ ⵙ ⵉⵜⵜⵓⵙⵙⵉⵜⵏ ⵜⵖⴰⵡⵙⵉⵡⵉⵏ ⵜⴰⵏⴳⴰⵎⵉⵏ,ⵉⵖⵢ ⵉⵙ ⴳⴰⵏ ⵉⴳⴷⵓⴷⵏ ⵏ ⴷⴰⵜ ⵓⵎⵣⵔⵓⵢ ⵎⴰⵎⴽ ⵙⵙⵉⵜⵉⵏ ⴰⵏⵛⵜ ⵡⴰⵔⴰⵜⵉⴳ, ⵣⵓⵏⴷ ⵜⵉⵣⵉ- ⵓⵙⵙⴰⵏ ⴷ ⵉⵎⵉⵔⵏ ⵏⵖⴷ ⵉⵙⴳⴳⵯⴰⵙⵏ.

source_sentence: The greatest mathematician of antiquity is often held to be Archimedes (c. 287–212 BC) of Syracuse.
target_sentence: ⴽⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⴰⵢⴷ ⵉⵜⵜⵉⵏⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵡⵉⵙⴷ ⴰⵔⵅⵎⵉⵙⴷ (287-212 ⴷⴰⵜ ⵜⵍⴰⵍⵉⵜ ⵏ ⵍⵎⴰⵙⵉⵃ) ⴰⵢⴷ ⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⴰⵎⵓⵙⵏⴰⵡ ⴰⵅⴰⵜⴰⵔ ⵏ ⵜⵓⵙⵏⴰⴽⵜ ⴳ ⵉⵣⵎⴰⵣ ⵉⵇⴱⵓⵔⵏ.

source_sentence: The Hindu–Arabic numeral system and the rules for the use of its operations, in use throughout the world today, evolved over the course of the first millennium AD in India and were transmitted to the Western world via Islamic mathematics.

source_sentence: Perhaps the foremost mathematician of the 19th century was the German mathematician Carl Friedrich Gauss, who made numerous contributions to fields such as algebra, analysis, differential geometry, matrix theory, number theory, and statistics.

source_sentence: "However, Aristotle also noted a focus on quantity alone may not distinguish mathematics from sciences like physics; in his view, abstraction and studying quantity as a property ""separable in thought"" from real instances set mathematics apart."

source_sentence: A peculiarity of intuitionism is that it rejects some mathematical ideas considered valid according to other definitions.

source_sentence: Intuition and experimentation also play a role in the formulation of conjectures in both mathematics and the (other) sciences.

source_sentence: A distinction is often made between pure mathematics and applied mathematics.

source_sentence: As in most areas of study, the explosion of knowledge in the scientific age has led to specialization: there are now hundreds of specialized areas in mathematics and the latest Mathematics Subject Classification runs to 46 pages.

source_sentence: Many mathematicians talk about the elegance of mathematics, its intrinsic aesthetics and inner beauty.

source_sentence: The polynomial 0, which may be considered to have no terms at all, is called the zero polynomial.

source_sentence: Because the degree of a non-zero polynomial is the largest degree of any one term, this polynomial has degree two.
target_sentence: ⵎⴰⵛⴽⵓ ⵍⴰⵏⵜ ⵜⵙⴽⴼⴰⵍ ⵜⴰⵔ-ⴰⵎⵢⴰ ⵎⵎ ⵉⵡⵜⵜⴰ ⵉⴳⴳⵓⴷⵉⵏ, ⵜⴳⴰ ⵜⴰⵙⴽⴼⵍⵜ ⵜⴰⵅⴰⵜⴰⵔⵜ ⴳ ⵢⵓⵡⵜ ⵜⴳⵓⵔⵉ, ⴷⴰ ⵜⵜⵉⵍⵉ ⵎⵎ ⵉⵡⵜⵜⴰ ⵉⴳⴳⵓⴷⵉⵏ ⴳ ⵜⵙⴽⴼⵍⵜ ⵜⵉⵙⵙ ⵙⵏⴰⵜ.

source_sentence: Polynomials can be classified by the number of terms with nonzero coefficients, so that a one-term polynomial is called a monomial, a two-term polynomial is called a binomial, and a three-term polynomial is called a trinomial.
target_sentence: ⵏⵖⵢ ⴰⴷ ⵏⴳ ⵎⵎ ⵉⵡⵜⵜⴰ ⵉⴳⴳⵓⴷⵉⵏ ⵙⴳ ⵎⵏⵛⴽ ⵏ ⵜⴳⵓⵔⵉⵡⵉⵏ ⵉⵍⴰ ⵉⴳⴳⵉⵜⵏ ⵓⵔ ⵉⴳⵉⵏ ⴰⵎⵢⴰ, ⵉⵎⴽ ⵉⵜⵜⵢⴰⵏⵏⴰ ⵉ ⴱⵓ-ⵉⵡⵜⵜⴰ ⵉⴳⴳⵓⴷⵉⵏ ⵙ ⵢⵓⵡⵜ ⵜⴳⵓⵔⵉ ⵉⵙⵎ ⴱⵓ-ⵢⵓⵡⵏ ⵓⵡⵜⵜⵓ, ⴰⵔ ⵉⵜⵢⴰⵏⵏⴰ ⵉ ⴱⵓ-ⵉⵡⵜⵜⴰ ⵉⴳⴳⵓⴷⵉⵏ ⵙ ⵙⵏⴰⵜ ⵜⴳⵓⵔⵉⵡⵉⵏ ⴱⵓ-ⵙⵉⵏ ⵉⵡⵜⵜⴰ, ⴰⵔ ⵉⵜⵢⴰⵏⵏⴰ ⵉ ⴱⵓ ⵎⵏⵏⴰⵡ ⵏ ⵉⵡⵜⵜⴰ; ⴱⵓ-ⴽⵕⴰⴹ ⵉⵡⵜⵜⴰ.

source_sentence: When it is used to define a function, the domain is not so restricted.
target_sentence: ⵉⴳ ⴷⴰ ⵉⵜⵜⵓⵙⵎⵔⴰⵙ ⵎⴰⵔ ⴰⴷ ⵉⵙⵜⵉ ⵜⴰⵎⵔⵙⵜ, ⵓⵔ ⴷⴰ ⵉⵜⵜⵓⴽⵔⴰⴼ ⵢⵉⴳⵔ.

source_sentence: A polynomial in one indeterminate is called a univariate polynomial, a polynomial in more than one indeterminate is called a multivariate polynomial.
target_sentence: ⴱⵓ ⵉⵡⵜⵜⴰ ⵉⴳⴳⵓⴷⵉⵏ ⴳ ⵢⵓⵡⵏ ⵓⵡⵜⵜⵓ ⵓⵔ ⵉⵜⵢⴰⵙⵙⴰⵏ ⴷⴰ ⴰⵙ ⵏⵜⵜⵉⵏⵉ ⴱⵓ ⵉⵡⵜⵜⴰ ⵉⴳⴳⵓⴷⵉⵏ ⵉⵍⴰⵏ ⵢⵓⵡⵏ ⵓⵙⵏⴼⵍ, ⴱⵓ ⵉⵡⵜⵜⴰ ⵉⴳⴳⵓⴷⵉⵏ ⴳ ⴽⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵓⵔ ⵉⵥⵍⵉⵢⵏ ⴷⴰ ⴰⵙ ⵏⵜⵜⵉⵏⵉ ⴰⵎⴳⴳⵓⴷⵢ ⵏ ⵉⵡⵜⵜⴰ, ⴰⵎⴳⴳⵓⵡⴷⵢ ⵏ ⵉⵙⵏⴼⴰⵍⵏ.

source_sentence: In the case of the field of complex numbers, the irreducible factors are linear.
target_sentence: ⴳ ⵡⴰⴷⴷⴰⴷ ⵏ ⵢⵉⴳⵔ ⵏ ⵉⵎⴹⴰⵏ ⵓⴷⴷⵉⵙⵏ, ⴷⴰ ⵜⴳⴳⴰⵏ ⵉⵎⵙⴽⴰⵔⵏ ⵉⵜⵢⴰⴽⴽⴰⵙⵏ; ⵉⵣⵔⵉⵔⵉⴳ.

source_sentence: If the degree is higher than one, the graph does not have any asymptote.
target_sentence: ⵉⴳ ⵜⴽⴽⴰ ⵜⵙⴽⴼⵍⵜ ⵏⵏⵉⴳ ⵢⴰⵏ, ⵓⵔ ⴷⴰ ⵉⵜⵜⵉⵍⵉ ⵉ ⵡⵓⵏⵓⵖ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵎⵎⴰⵍ ⴰⵡⴷ ⵢⴰⵏ ⵉⵣⵔⵉⵔⵉⴷ ⵉⵏⵎⴰⵍⴰⵏ.

source_sentence: In elementary algebra, methods such as the quadratic formula are taught for solving all first degree and second degree polynomial equations in one variable.
target_sentence: ⴳ ⵍⵊⵉⴱⵔ ⴰⵎⵣⵡⴰⵔⵓ, ⴷⴰ ⵜⵜⵓⵙⵖⵔⴰⵏⵜ ⵜⴱⵔⵉⴷⵉⵏ ⵣⵓⵏⴷ ⵜⴰⵍⵖⴰ ⵜⴰⵎⴽⴽⵓⵥⵜ ⵉ ⵓⴼⵙⵙⴰⵢ ⵏ ⵎⴰⵕⵕⴰ ⵏ ⵜⴳⴷⴰⵣⴰⵍⵉⵏ ⵉⵍⴰⵏ ⴽⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵡⵜⵜⴰ ⵉⵍⵍⴰⵏ ⴳ ⵜⵙⴽⴼⵍⵜ ⵜⴰⵎⵣⵡⴰⵔⵓⵜ ⵓⵍⴰ ⵜⵉⵙⵙ ⵙⵏⴰⵜ ⴳ ⵢⵓⵡⵏ ⵓⵙⵏⴼⵍ.

source_sentence: However, root-finding algorithms may be used to find numerical approximations of the roots of a polynomial expression of any degree.
target_sentence: ⵡⴰⵅⵅⴰ ⵀⴰⴽⴽⴰⴽ ⵏⵖⵢ ⴰⴷ ⵏⵙⵙⵎⵔⵙ ⴰⵍⴳⵓⵔⵉⵜⵎ ⵏ ⵓⵔⵣⵣⵓ ⵅⴼ ⵓⵥⵓⵕ, ⵎⴰⵔ ⴰⴷ ⵏⴰⴼ ⴰⵏⵎⴰⵍⴰ ⵓⵟⵟⵓⵏ ⵉ ⵉⵥⵖⵕⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵜⴰⵍⵖⴰ ⵉⵍⴰⵏ ⵉⵡⵜⵜⴰ ⵉⴳⴳⵓⴷⵉⵏ ⴳ ⴽⴰ ⵉⴳⴰⵜ ⵜⴰⵙⴽⴼⵍⵜ.

source_sentence: Since the 16th century, similar formulas (using cube roots in addition to square roots), but much more complicated are known for equations of degree three and four (see cubic equation and quartic equation).
target_sentence: ⵙⴳ ⵓⵙⴰⵜⵉ ⵡⵉⵙⵙ 16 ⵜⵜⵓⵢⴰⵙⵙⵏⵜ ⵜⴰⵍⵖⵉⵡⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵎⵙⴽⵙⵍ ( ⵙ ⵓⵙⵙⵎⵔⵙ ⵏ ⵉⵣⵖⵕⴰⵏ ⵉⴳⵏⵜⵔⵏ ⴷ ⵉⵣⵖⵕⴰⵏ ⵉⵎⴽⴽⵓⵥⵏ), ⵎⴰⴽⴰ ⵡⴰⵏⵏⴰ ⵡⴰⵍⴰ ⵉⵛⵇⵇⴰⵏ ⵉⴳⴰⵜ ⵜⵉⴳⴷⴰⵣⴰⵍⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵙⴽⴼⵍⵜ ⵜⵉⵙⵙ ⴽⵕⴰⴹⵜ ⴷ ⵜⵉⵙⵙ ⴽⴽⵓⵥⵜ ( ⵥⵕ ⵜⴰⴳⴷⴰⵣⴰⵍⵜ ⵜⴰⴳⵏⵜⵔⵜ ⴷ ⵜⴳⴷⴰⵣⴰⵍⵜ ⵜⴰⵎⴽⴽⵓⵥⵜ).

source_sentence: In 1830, Évariste Galois proved that most equations of degree higher than four cannot be solved by radicals, and showed that for each equation, one may decide whether it is solvable by radicals, and, if it is, solve it.
target_sentence: ⴳ ⵓⵙⴳⴳⵯⴰⵙ ⵏ 1830, ⵉⵙⵡⵔ ⵉⴼⴰⵔⵉⵙⵜ ⴳⴰⵍⵓ ⵏ ⵡⵉⵙⴷ ⴽⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵜⴳⴷⴰⵣⴰⵍⵜ ⵏ ⵜⵙⴽⴼⵍⵜ ⵜⴰⵎⴰⴼⵍⵍⴰⵜ ⵙⴳ ⴽⴽⵓⵥ, ⵓⵔ ⵏⵣⴹⴰⵕ ⴰⵜ ⵏⴼⵙⵉ ⵙ ⵓⵥⵓⵕ, ⵉⵙⵙⴼⵔⵓⴷ ⵉⴷ ⴽⴰ ⵉⴳⴰⵜ ⵜⴰⴳⴷⴰⵣⴰⵍⵜ ⵉⵖⵢ ⵓⴼⴳⴰⵏ ⴰⴷ ⵢⵉⵏⵉ ⵉⵙ ⵜⵍⴰ ⴰⴼⵙⵙⴰⵢ ⵙ ⵜⴱⵔⵉⴷⵜ ⵜⵣⵖⵕⴰⵏⵜ, ⵎⴽ ⵉⵖⵢ, ⵉⴼⵙⵉ ⵜⵜ.

source_sentence: Nevertheless, formulas for solvable equations of degrees 5 and 6 have been published (see quintic function and sextic equation).
target_sentence: ⵡⴰⵅⵅⴰ ⵀⴰⴽⴽⴰⴽ, ⵜⵢⴰⴼⵙⴰⵔⵏⵜ ⵜⴰⵍⵖⵉⵡⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵜⴳⴷⴰⵣⴰⵍⵉⵏ ⵉⵍⴰⵏ ⴰⴼⵙⵙⴰⵢ ⵙ ⵜⵙⴽⴼⵍⵜ ⵜⵉⵙⵙ 5 ⴷ 6 (ⵥⵕ ⵜⴰⵎⵔⵙⵜ ⵜⴰⵎⵙⵎⵎⵓⵙⵜ ⴷ ⵜⴳⴷⴰⵣⴰⵍⵜ ⵜⴰⵎⵚⴹⵉⴹⵜ).

source_sentence: The most efficient algorithms allow solving easily (on a computer) polynomial equations of degree higher than 1,000 (see Root-finding algorithm).
target_sentence: ⴷⴰ ⵜⵜⴰⴷⵊⴰⵏⵜ ⴰⵍⴳⵓⵔⵉⵜⵎ ⵜⵓⵏⵚⵉⴱⵉⵏ ⴰⴷ ⵜⵜⵢⴰⴼⵙⴰⵢⵏⵜ ⵜⴳⴷⴰⵣⴰⵍⵉⵏ ⵉⴷ ⵎⵎ ⵉⵡⵜⵜⴰ ⵙ ⵓⵎⵏⵀⴰⵍ ( ⴳ ⵓⵎⵙⵙⵓⴷⵙ), ⵙ ⵜⵙⴽⴼⵍⵜ ⵉⴽⴽⴰⵏ ⵏⵏⵉⴳ 1,000 ( ⵥⵕ ⴰⵍⴳⵓⵔⵉⵜⵎ ⵏ ⵢⵉⴼ ⵏ ⵉⵣⵖⵕⴰⵏ).

source_sentence: For a set of polynomial equations in several unknowns, there are algorithms to decide whether they have a finite number of complex solutions, and, if this number is finite, for computing the solutions.
target_sentence: ⴳ ⴽⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵜⴳⴷⴰⵣⴰⵍⵉⵏ ⵉⴷ ⵎⵎ ⵉⵡⵜⵜⴰ ⵉⴳⴳⵓⴷⵉⵏ ⴳ ⴽⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵉⴷ ⵡⴰⵔ-ⵉⵙⵎ, ⵍⵍⴰⵏⵜ ⴰⵍⴳⵓⵔⵉⵜⵎ ⵉⵜⵜⵉⵏⵉⵏ ⵉⵙ ⵖⴰⵔⵙⵏ ⵉⴼⵙⵙⴰⵢⵏ ⵎⵥⵍⴰⵢ ⵉⵛⵇⵇⴰⵏ, ⴷ ⵎⴽ ⵉⴳⴰ ⵡⵓⵟⵟⵓⵏ ⴰⴷ ⴰⵎⵥⵍⴰⵢ ⵉ ⵓⵙⵙⵉⵟⵏ ⵏ ⵉⴼⵙⵙⴰⵢⵏ.

source_sentence: A polynomial equation for which one is interested only in the solutions which are integers is called a Diophantine equation.
target_sentence: ⵜⴰⴳⴷⴰⵣⴰⵍⵜ ⴷⴰ ⵜⴳⴳⴰ ⵎⵎ ⵉⵡⵜⵜⴰ ⵉⴳⴳⵓⴷⵉⵏ ⵏⵏⴰ ⵎⵉ ⵢⴰⴽⴽⴰ ⵓⴼⴳⴰⵏ ⵜⴰⵖⴷⴼⵜ ⵙ ⵉⴼⵙⵙⴰⵢⵏ ⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵉⵎⴹⴰⵏ ⵉⵎⴷⴷⴰⴷⵏ ⵙ ⵜⴳⴷⴰⵣⴰⵍⵜ ⴷⵢⵓⴼⴰⵏⵜⵉⵏ.

source_sentence: The coefficients may be taken as real numbers, for real-valued functions.
target_sentence: ⵏⵖⵢ ⴰⴷ ⵏⴳ ⵉⵎⴳⴳⵓⵜⵏ ⴷ ⵓⵟⵟⵓⵏ ⵉⵖⴰⵔⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵉⴳⴳⵉⵜⵉⵏ ⵉⵍⴰⵏ ⴰⵜⵉⴳ ⴰⵖⴰⵔⴰⵏ.

source_sentence: This equivalence explains why linear combinations are called polynomials.
target_sentence: ⴷⴰ ⵉⵙⵙⴼⵔⵓ ⵓⵙⵙⴽⵙⵍ ⴰⴷ ⴰⵎⵏⵜⵉⵍ ⵏ ⵢⵉⵙⵎ ⵏ ⵜⵔⵓⴱⴱⴰ ⵜⵉⵣⵔⵉⵔⵉⴳⵉⵏ ⵉⵍⴰⵏ ⴽⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵡⵜⵜⴰ.

source_sentence: "In the case of coefficients in a ring, ""non-constant"" must be replaced by ""non-constant or non-unit"" (both definitions agree in the case of coefficients in a field)."
target_sentence: ⴳ ⵡⴰⴷⴷⴰⴷ ⵏ ⵉⵎⴳⴳⵓⵜⵏ ⴳ ⵜⵅⵔⵙⵜ ⵉⵇⵏⴻⵏ ⴰⴷ ⵏⵙⵏⴼⵍ ⵓⵏⵏⴰ ⵓⵔ ⵉⵣⵣⴳⴰⵏ ⵖⵔ ⵓⵏⵏⴰ ⵓⵔ ⵉⵡⵉⵔⵏ, ⵏⵖⴷ ⵓⵏⵏⴰ ⵓⵔ ⵉⴳⵣⵉⵎⵏ (ⵉⵙⵓⵙⵙⵏ ⵙⵙⵉⵏ ⵜⵜⵎⵙⴰⵙⴰⵏ ⴳ ⵡⴰⴷⴷⴰⴷ ⵏⵡⴰⴳⴳⵉⵜⵏ ⴳ ⵢⵉⴳⵔ).

source_sentence: When the coefficients belong to integers, rational numbers or a finite field, there are algorithms to test irreducibility and to compute the factorization into irreducible polynomials (see Factorization of polynomials).
target_sentence: ⵉⴳ ⴷⴰ ⵜⵜⵓⵖⵓⵍⵏ ⵡⴰⴳⴳⵉⵜⵏ ⵖⵔ ⵉⵎⴹⴰⵏ ⵉⵎⴷⴷⴰⴷⵏ ⵏⵖⴷ ⵓⵟⵟⵓⵏ ⵓⵎⴳⵉⵏⴻⵏ ⵏⵖⴷ ⵉⴳⵔ ⵉⵥⵍⵉⵏ, ⵜⵍⵍⴰ ⴰⵍⴳⵓⵔⵉⵜⵎ ⵎⴰⵔ ⴰⴷ ⵜⴳ ⵉⵔⵎ ⵏ ⴳⴰⵔ ⵜⴰⵣⵎⵔⵜ ⵏ ⵓⵣⴳⵣⵍ ⴷ ⵓⵙⵙⵉⵟⵏ ⴷ ⵢⵉⴳⴳⵉⵜⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵉⵏⵏⴰ ⵎⵉ ⴳⵓⴷⵉⵏ ⵉⵡⵜⵜⴰ ⵓⵔ ⵉⴳⵉⵏ ⵜⵉⵏ ⵓⵣⴳⵣⵍ (ⵥⵕ ⴰⵙⴼⵙⵉ ⵎⵉ ⴳⴳⵓⴷⵉⵏ ⵉⵡⵜⵜⴰ ⵙ ⵉⵎⵙⴽⵉⵔⵏ).

source_sentence: The characteristic polynomial of a matrix or linear operator contains information about the operator's eigenvalues.
target_sentence: ⵉⵍⵍⴰ ⴳ ⵉⵎⴳⴳⵓⴷⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵡⵜⵜⴰ ⵙ ⵜⵥⵍⵉ ⵜⴷⵔⴰⵙⵜ, ⵏⵖⴷ ⴰⵎⵙⵡⵓⵔⵉ ⴰⵣⵔⵉⵔⵉⴳ ⵖⴼ ⵉⵏⵖⵎⵉⵙⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵉⵏⴷⵉⵜⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵏⴽⴽⵉⵏⵜ ⵏ ⵓⵎⵙⵡⵓⵔⵉ.

source_sentence: However, the elegant and practical notation we use today only developed beginning in the 15th century.
target_sentence: ⵡⴰⵅⵅⴰ ⵀⴰⴽⴽⴰⴽ ⴰⵙⴷⵓⴽⵎ ⴰⵏⵡⵓⵔⵉ ⵉⵥⵉⵍⵏ ⵏⵙⵙⵎⵔⴰⵙ ⴰⵙⵙⴰ ⵉⵜⵜⵓⵙⴱⵓⵖⵍⵍⴰ ⴳ ⵜⵉⵣⵡⵓⵔⵉ ⵏ ⵓⵙⴰⵜⵓ ⵡⵉⵙⵙ 15.

source_sentence: "This ""completes the square"", converting the left side into a perfect square."
target_sentence: ⵖⴰⵢⴰ “ⵉⵜⵙⵎⴰⴷ ⴰⵎⴽⴽⵓⵥ”, ⴷ ⴰⵔ ⵉⵜⵔⴰⵔ ⵜⴰⵙⴳⴰ ⵜⴰⵣⵍⵎⴰⴹⵜ ⴰⴷ ⵜⴳ ⴰⵎⴽⴽⵓⵥ.

source_sentence: Descartes' theorem states that for every four kissing (mutually tangent) circles, their radii satisfy a particular quadratic equation.

target_sentence: ⴰⵙⵏⵎⴰⵍⴰ ⴷⴰ ⵉⵜⵜⵓⵙⵓⴷⵙ ⴳ ⵜⵔⴰⴱⴱⵓⵜⵉⵏ ⵜⴰⵢⵢⴰⵡⵉⵏ ⵉⵇⵏⵏ ⴳⵉⵏⵜ ⵜⵉⵎⵥⴰⵍⵢ ( ⵉⴳ ⴳⴰⵏⵜ ⵜⵓⴷⴷⵉⵣⵉⵏ), ⴳ ⵜⴳⵣⵣⵓⵎⵜ ⵜⴰⴳⵏⵙⵓⵜ ⵏ ⴷⵉⵙⴽ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵏⵎⴰⵍⴰ: ⵉ ⵜⵉⵖⵉⵙⵜ, ⵉⵏⵎⴰⵍⴰ ⵙ ⵜⴰⵍⵖⴰ ⵉⵥⵍⵉⵏ ⴳ ⵜⵔⴰⴱⴱⵓⵜⵉⵏ ⵢⵓⴷⵔⵏ.

source_sentence: The Hilbert–Poincaré series is a formal power series used to study graded algebras.
target_sentence: ⵜⴰⴳⴼⴼⵓⵔⵜ “ⵉⵍⴱⵉⵔ-ⴱⵡⴰⵏⴽⴰⵔⵉ Hilbert–Poincaré” ⵜⴳⴰ ⵜⴰⴳⴼⴼⵓⵔⵜ ⵜⵓⵏⵙⵉⴱⵜ ⵉⵜⵜⵓⵙⵎⵔⴰⵙⵏ ⴳ ⵜⵖⵓⵔⵉ ⵏ ⵍⵊⵉⴱⵔ ⴰⵎⴹⴼⵓⵕ.

source_sentence: In the 17th century, James Gregory worked in the new decimal system on infinite series and published several Maclaurin series.
target_sentence: ⴳ ⵓⵙⴰⵜⵓ ⵡⵉⵙⵙ 17 ⵉⵙⵡⵓⵔⵉ “ⴳⵉⵎⵙ ⴳⵔⵉⴳⵓⵔⵉ James Gregory” ⴳ ⵓⵏⴳⵔⴰⵡ ⴰⵎⵔⴰⵡⴰⵏ ⴰⵎⴰⵢⵏⵓ; ⵖⴼ ⵜⴳⴼⴼⵓⵔⵜ ⵜⴰⵔⵜⵎⵉ, ⴷ ⵉⴼⵙⵔ ⴽⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵜⴳⴼⴼⵓⵔⵉⵏ ⵏ “ⵎⴰⴽⵍⵓⵔⵉⵏ Maclaurin”.

source_sentence: Cauchy (1821) insisted on strict tests of convergence; he showed that if two series are convergent their product is not necessarily so, and with him begins the discovery of effective criteria.
target_sentence: ⵉⵙⴷⴷⵉⴷ “ⴽⵓⵛⵉ” (1821) ⵖⴼ ⵢⵉⵔⵉⵎⵏ ⵉⵏⵎⴰⵍⴰⵏⴻⵏ ⵓⵇⵊⵉⵔⵏ, ⵉⵙⵙⴰⴽⵣ ⵉⴳ ⵎⵎⵍⵎⴰⵍⴰⵏⵜ ⵙⵏⴰⵜ ⵜⴳⴼⴼⵓⵔⵉⵏ ⴰⵎⵥⴰⵔⴰⵡ ⵏⵏⵙ ⵓⵔ ⵉⴷ ⵛⵛⵉⵍ ⴰⵙ ⴰⴷ ⵎⴰⵢⴰⵏ, ⴰⵔ ⵉⴷⵙ ⵜⵜⵓⵙⵏⵜⴰⵢ ⵜⵓⴼⴰⵢⵜ ⵏ ⵉⵏⴰⵡⴰⵢⵏ ⵉⵎⵕⵡⵉⵜⵏ.

source_sentence: A summability method is such an assignment of a limit to a subset of the set of divergent series which properly extends the classical notion of convergence.
target_sentence: ⵜⴰⵖⴰⵔⴰⵙⵜ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵎⵓⵏ ⵜⴳⴰ ⵉⴽⵣ ⴰⵡⵜⵜⵓ ⵉ ⵜⵔⴰⴱⴱⵓⵜ ⵜⴰⵢⵢⴰⵡⵜ ⵏ ⵜⵔⴰⴱⴱⵓⵜ ⵏ ⵜⴳⴼⴼⵓⵔⵉⵏ ⵉⵎⵎⵄⵔⴰⵇⵏ, ⵉⵜⵜⴰⵏⴼⵏ ⵙ ⵜⴰⵍⵖⴰ ⵜⴰⵎⴷⴷⴰⴷⵜ ⴰⵔⵎⵎⵓⵙ ⴰⴽⵍⴰⵙⵉⴽⵉ ⵏ ⵜⵏⵎⵉⵍⴰ.

source_sentence: Indian scholars have been using factorial formulas since at least the 12th century.
target_sentence: ⴷⴰ ⵙⵙⵎⵔⴰⵙⵏ ⵉⵎⴰⵙⵙⵏ ⵉⵀⵉⵏⴷⵉⵢⵏ ⵜⴰⵍⵖⵉⵡⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵎⴳⴳⵓⵜⵏ ⵙⴳ ⵓⵙⴰⵜⵓ ⵡⵉⵙⵙ 12.

source_sentence: In functional languages, the recursive definition is often implemented directly to illustrate recursive functions.
target_sentence: ⴳ ⵜⵓⵜⵍⴰⵢⵉⵏ ⵜⵉⵙⵖⵏⴰⵏ, ⴷⴰ ⵡⴰⵍⴰ ⵉⵜⵜⵓⴳⴰ ⵙ ⵡⵓⵙⵔⵉⴷ ⵓⵙⵉⵙⵙⵏ ⴰⵎⴰⵖⵓⵍ, ⵎⴰⵔ ⴰⴷ ⵉⵙⵙⴼⵔⵓ ⵜⵉⵙⵖⵏⴰ ⵏ ⵜⵎⴰⵖⵓⵍⵜ.

source_sentence: Other implementations (such as computer software such as spreadsheet programs) can often handle larger values.
target_sentence: ⵖⵉⵏⵜ ⵜⵙⵏⵙⵉⵜⵉⵏ ⵢⴰⴹⵏ (ⵣⵓⵏⴷ ⵉⵖⴰⵡⴰⵙⵏ ⵏ ⵓⵎⵙⵙⵓⴷⵙ ⵣⵓⵏⴷ ⵉⵖⴰⵡⴰⵙⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵙⵎⵢⴰⵍⵍⴰⵢⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵙⵎⵎⴰⵍⵏ) ⴰⵙⵎⴽⴷ ⵏ ⵜⵉⵏⴷⵉⵜⵉⵏ ⵜⵉⵅⴰⵜⴰⵔⵉⵏ ⴳ ⴽⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵡⴰⴷⴷⴰⴷⵏ.

source_sentence: Compared to the Pickover definition of the superfactorial, the hyperfactorial grows relatively slowly.
target_sentence: ⵙ ⵓⵣⵎⵣⴰⵣⴰⵍ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵉⵙⵙⵏ ⴱⵉⴽⵓⴼⵔ ⵏ ⵓⵎⵙⵡⵓⵔ ⴰⵎⴰⴳⵓⵔ, ⴷⴰ ⵉⵜⵜⵓⴳⵎ ⵓⵎⵙⵡⵓⵔ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵉⴳⵣ ⵏ ⵜⵉⵍⴰⵍ ⵙ ⵜⵉⵎⵎⵉⵙⵖⵜ.

source_sentence: There are, relatively speaking, no such simple solutions for factorials; no finite combination of sums, products, powers, exponential functions, or logarithms will suffice to express ; but it is possible to find a general formula for factorials using tools such as integrals and limits from calculus.
target_sentence: ⵙ ⵜⵎⵉⵙⵖⵜ ⵓⵔ ⵍⵍⵉⵏ ⵉⴼⵙⵙⴰⵢⵏ ⵓⵏⵣⵉⵍⵏ ⵉ ⵉⵎⴳⴳⵉⵜⵏ, ⵓⵔ ⵜⴳⵉ ⵜⵔⴰⴱⴱⵓⵜ ⵏ ⵡⴰⵜⵉⴳⵏ ⵜⵓⵥⵍⵉⵢⵜ ⵏⵖⴷ ⵉⵙⵏⴼⵍⵓⵍⵏ ⵏⵖⴷ ⵜⵉⵣⵎⴰⵔ ⵏⵖⴷ ⵜⵉⵎⵔⵙⵉⵏ ⵜⴰⴳⴳⴰⴹⵉⵏ ⵏⵖⴷ ⵍⵓⴳⴰⵔⵉⵜⵎ ⵙ ⵏⵔⴰ ⴰⴷ ⵖⵉⴼⵙ ⵏⵙⵉⵡⵍ, ⵎⴰⴽⴰ ⵏⵖⵢ ⴰⴷ ⵏⴰⴼ ⵜⴰⵍⵖⴰ ⵜⴰⵎⴰⵜⵜⵓⵜ ⵉ ⵓⵎⵙⴼⵓⴽⵜⵉ ⵙ ⵓⵙⵙⵎⵔⵙ ⵏ ⵉⵙⴳⴳⵓⵔⵏ ⴰⵎⵎ ⵉⵎⵣⴷⴰⵢⵏ ⴷ ⵉⵡⵜⵜⴰ ⵉ ⵓⵙⵙⵉⵟⵏ ⴰⵎⵢⵓⴼ ⴷ ⴰⵎⵙⵎⴷ.

source_sentence: The integrals we have discussed so far involve transcendental functions, but the gamma function also arises from integrals of purely algebraic functions.
target_sentence: ⵜⵉⵎⵙⵎⴰⴷⵉⵏ ⵅⴼ ⵏⵎⵔⴰⵔⴰ ⴰⵡⴰⵍ ⴰⴷ ⴷⵖⵉ ⵓⵡⵉⵏⴷ ⵜⵉⵎⵔⵙⵉⵜⵉⵏ ⵢⴰⵜⵜⵓⵢⵏ, ⵎⴰⴽⴰ ⵜⴰⵎⵔⵙⵜ ⵏ ⴳⴰⵎⴰ ⵜⵜⵡⴰⵙⴽⴰⵔ ⴰⵡⴷ ⵏⵜⵜⴰⵜ ⴳ ⵜⵎⵙⵎⴰⴷⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵎⵔⵙⵜ ⵏ ⵍⵊⵉⴱⵔ ⵉⴷⵓⵙⵏ.

source_sentence: By taking limits, certain rational products with infinitely many factors can be evaluated in terms of the gamma function as well.
target_sentence: ⵙⴳ ⵢⵉⵙⵢ ⵏ ⵉⵡⵜⵜⴰ, ⵏⵖⵢ ⴰⴷ ⵏⴳ ⴰⵙⵜⴰⵍ ⵉ ⵉⵜⵙⵏ ⵉⵙⵏⴼⵍⵓⵍⵏ ⵓⵎⴳⵉⵏ, ⴳ ⵉⵍⵍⴰ ⵉⵎⵉⴹ ⵡⴰⵔⵜⵎⵉ ⵏ ⵉⴼⴰⵜⵔⵏ ⵙⴳ ⵜⵎⵔⵙⵜ ⵏ ⴳⴰⵎⴰ.

source_sentence: Its history, notably documented by Philip J. Davis in an article that won him the 1963 Chauvenet Prize, reflects many of the major developments within mathematics since the 18th century.
target_sentence: ⴷⴰ ⵢⴰⴽⴽⴰ ⵓⵎⵣⵔⵓⵢ ⵏⵏⵙ ⵏⵏⴰ ⵢⴰⵔⵓ ⴼⵉⵍⵉⴱ ⵊ. ⴷⵉⴼⵉⵙ, ⴳ ⵓⵎⴳⵔⴰⴷ ⵢⵓⵡⵉⵏ ⵜⴰⵙⵎⵖⵔⵜ ⵏ ⵛⵓⴼⵉⵏⵉ ⴱⵔⵉⵣ ⴰⵙⴳⴳⵯⴰⵙ ⵏ1963, ⴽⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵙⴱⵓⵖⵍⵓⵜⵏ ⵉⴷⵙⵍⴰⵏ ⴳ ⵜⵓⵙⵏⴰⴽⵜ ⵙⴳ ⵓⵙⴰⵜⵓ 18.

source_sentence: Instead of finding a specialized proof for each formula, it would be desirable to have a general method of identifying the gamma function.
target_sentence: ⵅⴼ ⴰⴷ ⵉⵜⵢⴰⴼ ⵓⵏⵎⵎⴰⵍ ⵉⵥⵍⵉⵏ ⵉ ⴽⴰ ⵉⴳⴰⵜ ⵜⴰⴳⴷⴰⵣⴰⵍⵜ, ⵢⵓⴼ ⴰⴷ ⴷⴰⵔⴽ ⵜⵉⵍⵉ ⵜⴱⵔⵉⴷⵜ ⵜⴰⵎⴰⵜⵜⵓⵜ ⵏ ⵢⵉⴼ ⵏ ⵜⵎⵔⵙⵜ ⵏ ⴳⴰⵎⴰ.

source_sentence: However, the gamma function does not appear to satisfy any simple differential equation.
target_sentence: ⵡⴰⵅⵅⴰ ⵀⴰⴽⴽⴰⴽ ⵜⴰⵎⵔⵙⵜ ⵏ ⴳⴰⵎⴰ ⴷⴰ ⵜⵎⵙⴰⵙⴰ ⴷ ⴽⴰ ⵉⴳⴰⵜ ⵜⴰⴳⴷⴰⵣⴰⵍⵜ ⵜⴰⵎⵢⴰⴼⵜ ⵜⵓⵏⵣⵉⵍⵜ.

source_sentence: The Bohr–Mollerup theorem is useful because it is relatively easy to prove logarithmic convexity for any of the different formulas used to define the gamma function.
target_sentence: ⵜⴰⵎⴰⴳⵓⵏⵜ ⵏ ⴱⵓⵔⵀ-ⵎⵓⵍⵉⵔⵓ ⵜⵓⴱⵖⵉⵔⵜ, ⴰⵛⴽⵓ ⵉⵡⵀⵏ ⴰⴷ ⵉⵜⵜⵓⵡⵔ ⵡⵓⴹⵓ ⴰⵍⵓⴳⴰⵔⵉⵜⵎⵉ ⵉ ⴽⴰ ⵉⴳⴰⵜ ⵜⴰⵍⵖⵉⵡⵉⵏ ⵉⵎⵣⴰⵔⴰⵢⵏ ⵉⵜⵜⵓⵙⵎⵔⴰⵙⵏ ⵎⴰⵔ ⴰⴷ ⵏⵙⵜⵉ ⵜⴰⵎⵔⵙⵜ ⵏ ⴳⴰⵎⴰ.

source_sentence: As electronic computers became available for the production of tables in the 1950s, several extensive tables for the complex gamma function were published to meet the demand, including a table accurate to 12 decimal places from the U.S. National Bureau of Standards.
target_sentence: ⴷⴷⴰ ⴳ ⴳⴰⵏ ⵉⵏⴳⵎⴰⵎⵏ ⵏ ⵓⵎⵙⵙⵓⴷⵙ ⵉⵍⵉⴽⵜⵔⵓⵏⵉ ⵡⵉⵏ ⵓⵙⵏⴼⵍ ⵏ ⵉⵎⵢⴰⵍⵍⴰⵢⵏ ⴳ 1950, ⵜⵜⵢⴰⴼⵙⴰⵔⵏ ⴽⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵉⵙⵏⵎⴰⵍⵍⴰⵢⵏ ⵉⵙⵎⴰⵏ ⵜⴰⵎⵔⵙⵜ ⵏ ⴳⴰⵎⴰ ⵉⵛⵇⵇⴰⵏ ⵎⴰⵔ ⴰⴷ ⵜⵜⵓⴳ ⵜⵓⵜⵜⵔⴰ, ⴳ ⵢⴰⵎⵓ ⵢⴰⵏ ⵓⵙⵏⵎⴰⵍⵍⴰⵢ ⴰⵎⵖⴷⴰⵏ ⵏ 12 ⵏ ⵜⵓⵣⵓⵏⵜ ⵜⴰⵎⵔⴰⵡⵜ, ⵙⴳ ⵖⵓⵔ ⵓⵙⵉⵔⴰ ⴰⵏⴰⵡⴰⵢ ⴰⵏⴰⵎⵓⵔ ⴰⵎⵉⵔⵉⴽⴰⵏⵉ.

source_sentence: In science, a formula is a concise way of expressing information symbolically, as in a mathematical formula or a chemical formula.
target_sentence: ⴳ ⵜⵓⵙⵏⴰ, ⵜⴰⴳⴷⴰⵣⴰⵍⵜ ⵜⴳⴰ ⵜⴰⴱⵔⵉⴷⵜ ⵉⵙⴰⵏⴼⵏ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵉⵡⵍ ⵖⴼ ⵉⵏⵖⵎⵉⵙⵏ ⵙ ⵜⴰⵍⵖⴰ ⵜⴰⵎⴰⵜⴰⵔⵜ, ⵉⵎⴽ ⵉⵍⵍⴰⵏ ⴳ ⵜⴰⵍⵖⴰ ⵜⵓⵙⵏⴰⴽⵜ ⴷ ⵜⴰⵍⵖⴰ ⵏ ⵛⵉⵎⵉ.

source_sentence: In mathematics, a formula generally refers to an identity which equates one mathematical expression to another, with the most important ones being mathematical theorems.
target_sentence: ⴳ ⵜⵓⵙⵏⴰⴽⵜ ⴷ ⵜⵎⵎⴰⵍ ⵜⴰⵍⵖⴰ ⵙ ⵓⵎⴰⵜⴰ ⵜⴰⵎⴰⴳⵉⵜ ⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⴰⵙⵉⵡⵍ ⵏ ⵜⵓⵙⵏⴰⴽⵜ ⵢⴰⴹⵏ, ⵙⵜⴰⵡⵀⵎⵎⴰⵏⵜ ⴷⵉⴽⵙ ⵜⵎⴰⴳⵓⵏⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵓⵙⵏⴰⴽⵜ.

source_sentence: This convention, while less important in a relatively simple formula, means that mathematicians can more quickly manipulate formulas which are larger and more complex.
target_sentence: ⵜⴰⵎⵢⴰⵇⵇⴰⵏⵜ ⴰⴷ ⵎⵇⵇⴰⵔ ⵓⵔ ⵡⴰⵍⴰ ⵜⵙⵜⴰⵡⵀⵎⵎⴰ ⴳ ⵜⴰⵍⵖⴰ ⵜⴰⵎⵏⵣⴰⵍⵜ, ⴷⴰ ⵜⵜⵉⵏⵉ ⵉⵙ ⵉⵎⵓⵙⵏⴰⵡⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵓⵙⵏⴰⴽⵜ ⵖⵉⵏ ⴰⴷ ⵜⵎⵛⴰⵛⴽⴰⵏ ⵙ ⴽⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵏ ⵓⵙⵔⴱⵉ ⴰⴽⴷ ⵜⴰⵍⵖⵉⵡⵉⵏ ⵜⵉⵅⴰⵜⴰⵔⵉⵏ ⴷ ⵜⵉⵏⵏⴰ ⵡⴰⵍⴰ ⵉⵛⵇⵇⴰⵏ.

source_sentence: For example, H2O is the chemical formula for water, specifying that each molecule consists of two hydrogen (H) atoms and one oxygen (O) atom.
target_sentence: ⵙ ⵓⵎⴷⵢⴰ, H2O ⵜⴳⴰ ⵜⴰⵍⵖⴰ ⵜⴰⴽⵉⵎⵉⵢⵜ ⵏ ⵡⴰⵎⴰⵏ ⵏⵏⴰ ⵉⵙⵜⵜⵉⵏ ⵉⴷ ⴽⵓ ⵉⵎⵉⴽ ⴷⵉⴽⵙ ⵙⵏⴰⵜ ⵜⴱⵍⴽⵉⵎⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵀⵉⴷⵔⵓⵊⵉⵏ (H) ⴷ ⵜⴱⵍⴽⵉⵎⵜ ⵏ ⵓⴽⵙⵉⵊⵉⵏ (O).

source_sentence: In empirical formulas, these proportions begin with a key element and then assign numbers of atoms of the other elements in the compound—as ratios to the key element.
target_sentence: ⴳ ⵜⴰⵍⵖⵉⵡⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵜⵉⵔⵎⵉⵜ, ⴷⴰ ⵜⵜⵓⵙⵏⵜⴰⵢⵏⵜ ⵜⵙⵖⴰⵍⵉⵏ ⴰⴷ ⵙ ⵓⴷⵕⴹⵉⵚ ⴰⴷⵙⵍⴰⵏ ⴷ ⴰⵔ ⵜⵙⵜⵜⵉⵢ ⵎⵏⵏⴰⵡⵜ ⵏ ⵜⴱⵍⴽⵉⵎⵉⵏ ⵏ ⵉⴼⵕⴹⵉⵚⵏ ⵢⴰⴹⵏ ⴳ ⵜⴰⵏⴰⵡⵜ, ⵉⴳⴰⵏ ⵉⵙⵖⴰⵍⵏ ⵏ ⵓⴼⵕⴹⵉⵚ ⴰⴷⵙⵍⴰⵏ.

source_sentence: Some types of ionic compounds, however, cannot be written as empirical formulas which contains only the whole numbers.
